property.summary: Which SAML statements to include.
property.description: Specify the SAML statement types to generate for the SAML assertion.

property.name: PPSAMLSubjectConfirm
property.summary: Subject confirmation method for the SAML assertion.
property.description: Specify the methods so that the destination system can confirm the subject of the SAML assertion.

property.name: PPSAMLNameID
property.summary: Whether the generated token contains a Name Identifier.
property.description: <p>The SAML Subject element cannot contain a Name Identifier, especially if the Subject confirmation method is holder of key. If holder of key, the key represents the same entity as the subject. In this case, the Name Identifier can be omitted.</p><p>Set to 'off' if the SAML assertion expected by the SAML SP, for any reason, decided not to require a Name Identifier for the SAML Subject element.</p>

property.name: PPSAMLNameIDFormat
property.summary: The value of the optional Format attribute of the Name Identifier in the generated SAML query.
property.description: <p>Specify a URI reference that represents the classification of string-based identifier information. Any standard or arbitrary URI is allowed. If the value is an empty string, the DataPower Gateway attempts to determine the value from the AAA context.</p><p>Some SAML protocols require a specified value, such as 'urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:nameid-format:entity' or 'urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:1.1:nameid-format:unspecified'.</p>

property.name: PPSAMLRecipient
property.summary: The value of the Recipient for SAML1.x Response or SAML 2.0 SubjectConfirmationData.
property.description: <p>A URI that specifies the entity or location where an attesting entity can present the assertion. Any standard or arbitrary URI is allowed.</p><ul><li>If the value is an empty string, the optional attribute is not generated.</li><li>If the generated SAML assertion is in version 2.0, specifies the value for the Recipient attribute of the SubjectConfirmationData element.</li><li>If the generated SAML assertion is in version 1.x, specifies the value for the Recipient attribute of the Response element.</li></ul>

property.name: PPSAMLAudience
property.summary: Optional SAML Audience for the assertion.
property.description: <p>SAML Audience is a URI reference that identifies an intended audience. Specify any number of audience URIs to process the generated SAML assertion.</p><ul><li>If the value is an empty string, the SAML audience is not restricted.</li><li>If there are more than one audience URIs, use the '+' character as the delimiter between URIs. In this case, if a URI contains real '+' characters, convert each '+' to '\+'.</li></ul>

property.name: PPSAMLOmitNotBefore
property.summary: Whether the assertion is considered valid in the past.
property.description: <p>If true, the <tt>NotBefore</tt> attribute in the SAML assertion is omitted. The assertion is considered as valid in all its past, even before the time it was issued.</p><p>This behavior is a behavior being required to respond an <tt>AuthnRequest</tt> .</p>

property.name: PPOneTimeUse
property.summary: Whether the generated token is for only one time use.
property.description: <p>If true, the destination system or relying party should not cache the generated token.</p><p>The token being generated might contain the property for this characteristic, which is especially practical for SAML assertions.</p>

property.name: PPSAMLProxy
property.summary: Whether SAML ProxyRestriction is needed.
property.description: If true, the generated SAML assertion provides limitations that the asserting party imposes on relying parties that in turn wish to act as asserting parties and issue subsequent assertions of their own on the basis of the information in the original assertion. A relying party acting as an asserting party must not issue an assertion that itself violates the restrictions specified in this condition on the basis of an assertion containing such a condition.

property.name: PPSAMLProxyAudience
property.summary: Who can issue subsequent assertions of their own on the basis of this assertion.
property.description: <p>Specifies the set of audiences (proxy) to whom the asserting party permits new assertions to be issued on the basis of this assertion.</p><ul><li>If the value is an empty string, the assertion does not contain the Audience element in the ProxyRestriction element.</li><li>If there are more than one audience URIs, use the '+' character as the delimiter between URIs. If a URI contains real '+' characters, convert each '+' to '\+'.</li></ul>

property.name: PPSAMLProxyCount
property.summary: How many times can new assertions be issued before the ultimate use.
property.description: <p>Specifies the maximum number of indirections that the asserting party permits between this assertion and the assertion that is ultimately issued on this basis.</p><p>A value of zero indicates that a relying party must not issue an assertion to another relying party on the basis of this assertion. If greater than zero, any assertions issued must contain a ProxyRestriction element with a Count value of at most one less than this value.</p><p>The maximum value is 65535.</p>

property.name: PPSAMLAuthzAction
property.summary: Specify what action the subject can take on the resource.
property.description: Specify what standard action the subject is authorized to take on the resource. The SAML specification has defined a list of the action identifiers with corresponding namespace URI. Select an action identifier to generate the SAML Authorization statement action.

property.name: PPSAMLAttributes
property.summary: A list of SAML Attribute elements for the SAML assertion postprocessing method.
property.description: Define the information to put in the SAML assertion to generate the Attribute statement. Each SAML attribute requires the Name, NameFormat/Namespace, and Value. The value can be from a DataPower variable carrying predefined format, from a static string, or from the input message.

property.name: PPLTPAInsertCookie
property.summary: Insert a Set-Cookie header in the response.
property.description: Insert a Set-Cookie header in the response that contains the LTPA token that is generated during the postprocessing phase.

property.name: PPTAMPACPropagate
property.summary: Place the existing IBM Security Access Manager Privilege Attribute Certificate token in a HTTP header.
property.display: Generate IBM Security Access Manager Privilege Attribute Certificate token
property.description: The IBM Security Access Manager Privilege Attribute Certificate returned from a prior Authentication or Authorization is added to a HTTP header

property.name: PPTAMHeader
property.summary: The name of the HTTP header to store the token in.
property.description: The Privilege Attribute Certificate is stored in the HTTP header with the entered name. The default name is that used by IBM Security Access Manager WebSeal when placing the header in back-end connections.

property.name: PPTAMHeaderSize
property.summary: The maximum size of Privilege Attribute Certificate token allowed in a single header entry.
property.display: Privilege Attribute Certificate header value size
property.description: Some servers limit the size of HTTP header values. If the size is not zero then the Privilege Attribute Certificate token will be broken down to multiple headers of this length

property.name: PPKerberosUseS4U2Proxy
property.summary: Uses S4U2Proxy (constrained delegation) during the authentication step to generate Kerberos tokens in this step.
property.display: Use constrained delegation when generating Kerberos AP-REQ or SPNEGO tokens in this step.
property.description: Define whether to use constrained delegation during the authentication step to generate this step's Kerberos tokens in order to preserve the identity from the original incoming Kerberos token.

property.name: PPCookieAttributes
property.summary: Use a cookie attribute policy to include additional attributes in the cookie
property.description: Defines a policy for including standard or custom attributes in the cookie. The response message that contains a Set-Cookie header is updated with the attributes defined in the selected policy.

property.name: PPKerberosUseS4U2SelfAndS4U2Proxy
property.summary: Uses S4U2Self (protocol transition) to generate a token to the DataPower DataPower Gateway and subsequently uses S4U2Proxy (constrained delegation) to generate Kerberos tokens in this step.
property.display: Use protocol transition and constrained delegation when generating Kerberos AP-REQ or SPNEGO tokens in this step.
property.description: Controls whether to use protocol transition to generate this step's Kerberos tokens to the DataPower DataPower Gateway to transition from non-Kerberos authentication to Kerberos authentication and subsequently preserve the client identity in the Kerberos token that is generated in this step.

property.name: PPKerberosClientSource
property.summary: Where to get the Kerberos client principal
property.description: Specifies the source of the principal name of the Kerberos client. By default, the output of credential mapping in this AAA policy is used as the client principal name. The client principal is based on the authenticated identity that is followed by the corresponding realm name. For example, if the authenticated user is alice, the client principal name can be HTTP/alice.datapower.com@DATAPOWER.COM. The client principal must be present in the KDC for S4U2Self (protocol transition) to work.

property.name: PPKerberosSelf
property.summary: The principal name of the DataPower Gateway
property.description: Specifies the principal name of the DataPower Gateway when the DataPower Gateway supports S4U2Self that is known as protocol transition. S4U2Self allows the DataPower Gateway to obtain a service ticket from the KDC to itself on behalf of the user that authenticates to the DataPower Gateway by using a non-Kerberos mechanism, for example, by using an LTPA token.

property.name: PPKerberosSelfKeytab
property.summary: The keytab for the DataPower DataPower Gateway
property.description: Specifies the name of an existing Kerberos keytab configuration that defines the keytab for the DataPower DataPower Gateway. This keytab is required to authenticate the DataPower Gateway to the KDC.

property.name: PPKerberosClientCustomURL
property.summary: Specify the URL of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file to use the value of its output as the Kerberos client principal
property.description: Specifies the URL of a custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file. This stylesheet or GatewayScript file returns the client principal name within the <tt>kerberos-client-principal</tt> element. This stylesheet or GatewayScript file gets the following input: <ul><li>The output of all the steps that are executed in this AAA action</li><li>The incoming request message</li></ul>

property.name: PPKerberosClientCtxVar
property.summary: Enter a context variable to use its value as the Kerberos client principal
property.description: Specifies the context variable. The value of this context variable is used as the Kerberos client principal. This context variable must be specified in the var://context/name format. For example, var://context/AAA/krb-client-princ. You can use the set variable action to set this variable before you define the AAA policy.

property.name: PPKerberosServerSource
property.summary: Where to get the Kerberos server principal
property.description: Specifies the source of the principal name of the Kerberos server. By default, the server principal name is the value that is specified by the Kerberos server principal property.

property.name: PPKerberosServerCustomURL
property.summary: Specify the URL of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file to use the value of its output as the Kerberos server principal
property.description: <p>Specifies the location of a custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file. This stylesheet or GatewayScript file returns the server principal name within the <tt>kerberos-server-principal</tt> element. This stylesheet or GatewayScript file gets the following input:</p><ul><li>If constrained delegation is used, the output of only the identity extraction step</li><li>If constrained delegation is not used, the output of all the steps that are executed in this AAA action</li><li>The incoming request message</li></ul>

property.name: PPKerberosServerCtxVar
property.summary: Enter a context variable to use its value as the Kerberos server principal
property.description: Specifies a context variable. The value of this context variable is used as the Kerberos server principal. This context variable must be specified in the var://context/name format. For example, var://context/AAA/krb-server-princ. You can use the set variable action to set this variable before you define the AAA policy.

property.name: PPSSLClientConfigType
property.summary: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets
property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.name: PPSSLClientProfile
property.summary: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets
property.description: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.name: PPLTPAKeyFilePasswordAlias
property.label: Key file password alias
property.summary: The password alias of the password that decrypts the LTPA key file.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the password alias of the password that decrypts the LTPA key file.
property.description: The key file password decrypts certain entries in a WebSphere LTPA key file (v1 and v2). This password is not applicable to Domino key files.

property.name: PPJWT
property.summary: Specify whether to generate a JWT token.
property.description: Control whether to generate a JWT token.

property.name: PPJWTGenerator
property.summary: Configure the JWT Generator.
property.description: Configure settings for JWT Generator, such as the credentials and generating methods.

property.name: URI
property.summary: Namespace URI for the attribute.
property.description: <p>The Namespace URI for the attribute. The Namespace URI must match on a name. If blank, uses the null namespace.</p><p>For example, "http://www.examples.com" would match a message with the following attribute:</p><p>&lt;Attribute AttributeName="cats" AttributeNamespace="http://www.example.com"> &lt;AttributeValue>Winchester&lt;/AttributeValue>&lt;Attribute></p>

<p>The local name of the attribute. For example, "cats" would match a message with the following attribute:</p><p>&lt;Attribute AttributeName="cats" AttributeNamespace="http://www.example.com"> &lt;AttributeValue>Winchester&lt;/AttributeValue>&lt;Attribute></p>
property.summary: Local name of the attribute.
property.name: LocalName
Value
property.summary: Value for the attribute.

value.description: <ul><li>If the decision is "Permit", the client is authorized (the PEP permits access). If the "Permit" response is accompanied by obligations, the client is authorized only if the AAA Policy, acting as the PEP, can understand and discharge the obligations.</li><li>If the decision is "Deny", the client is rejected (the PEP denies access). If the "Deny" response is accompanied by obligations, the client is rejected only if the AAA Policy, acting as the PEP, can understand and discharge the obligations.</li><li>If the decision is "Not Applicable", the behavior is undefined.</li><li>If the decision is "Indeterminate", the behavior is undefined.</li></ul>
value.name: base

value.description: <ul><li>If the decision is "Permit", the client is authorized (the PEP permits access). If the "Permit" response is accompanied by obligations, the client is authorized only if the AAA Policy, acting as the PEP, can understand and discharge the obligations.</li><li>For all other decisions, the client is rejected (the PEP denies access).</li></ul>
value.name: deny-biased

value.description: <ul><li>If the decision is "Deny", the client is rejected (the PEP denies access). If the "Deny" "Deny" response is accompanied by obligations, the client is rejected only if the AAA Policy, acting as the PEP, can understand and discharge the obligations.</li><li>For all other decisions, the client is authorized (the PEP permits access).</li></ul>
value.name: permit-biased

value.display: Contact WS-Trust server for WS-Trust token
value.description: The requester is authenticated by a WS-Trust server. The server authenticates the requester and returns a WS-Trust token that is then used for further communication. When selected, specify the details relevant to access the WS-Trust server.
value.name: ws-trust

value.description: The requester is authenticated by reference to an establish WS-SecureConversation security context. This context must already be established before invoking a AAA policy.
value.name: ws-secureconversation

value.display: Pass identity token to authorization phase
value.description: The extracted identity is passed to the authorization phase for disposition. Authentication, in effect, succeeds.
value.name: token

value.display: Validate Kerberos AP-REQ for server principal
value.description: The requester is authenticated via a Kerberos AP-REQ in the WS-Security header. When selected, specify the Kerberos keytab.
value.name: kerberos

value.description: The requester is authenticated by an encrypted LTPA token. When selected, specify the format and decryption details.
value.name: ltpa

value.description: The requester is authenticated by a certificate that is included with a BinarySecurityToken. When selected, specify the validation credentials to validate the extracted certificate.
value.name: binarytokenx509

value.description: The requester is authenticated by SAF through NSS. A valid NSS client configuration must exist on the DataPower Gateway to use this method.
value.name: zosnss

value.display: Use verified JWT, access token, or ID token
value.description: The requester is authenticated by using the verified JWT, access token, or ID token. If a social login policy is configured in the AAA identity extraction phase, the access token or ID token from the specified social login provider is validated.
value.name: verified-oauth

value.description: The requester is authenticated by an unlisted resource, for example, a stylesheet or GatewayScript file. When selected, specify the URL of this unlisted resource.
value.name: custom

value.description: LTPA token version used by WebSphere Application Server release earlier than version 5.1.0.2 (for z/OS) and prior to version 5.1.1 for other platforms. The default format for releases prior to version 6.1.
value.name: LTPA

value.description: LTPA token version introduced in WebSphere Application Server version 5.1.0.2 (for z/OS) and version 5.1.1 for other platforms. The default format for version 6.1 and later.
value.name: LTPA2

value.description: The LTPA-like Domino Session ID cookie. Domino can consume WebSphere version 1 tokens.
value.name: LTPADomino

type.description: The version of WS-Trust or WS-SecureConversation specifications to use. Generally, these specifications are updated at the same time.
type.name: dmCryptoWSSXVersion

value.description: Use the username and password from the "Authorization:" header sent in the HTTP request. When selected, use TLS to prevent the password from being sent as cleartext.
value.name: http-basic-auth

value.display: Password-carrying UsernameToken element from WS-Security header
value.description: If the SOAP header contains a WS-Security UsernameToken element that carries a password or password-digest, extract the username and password from the element. (When using this method, it is strongly suggested to use TLS to prevent the password from being sent as cleartext.)
value.name: wssec-username

value.display: Derived-key UsernameToken element from WS-Security header
value.description: If the SOAP header contains a WS-Security UsernameToken element that specifies a password-derived symmetric key, extract the username and regenerate the key.
value.name: wssec-derived-key

value.description: If the SOAP header contains a WS-Security BinarySecurityToken element, use the string value of the element as the identity token.
value.name: wssec-binary-token

value.description: Use the established WS-SecureConversation context.
value.name: ws-secure-conversation

value.description: Use the token or referenced in the WS-Trust Base or Supporting elements.
value.name: ws-trust

value.description: If the SOAP header contains a WS-Security BinarySecurityToken element of type Kerberosv5_AP_REQ, use the string value of the element as the identity token.
value.name: kerberos

value.description: Use the SPNEGO token from the "Authorization: Negotiate" header sent in the HTTP request. It must include an optimistic Kerberos mechType token. The string value of the SPNEGO token is used as the identity token.
value.name: kerberos-spnego

value.display: Subject DN of TLS certificate from connection peer
value.description: If the peer, being connected with the device on the other end, sent a certificate in the TLS handshake, use the Subject DN in the certificate as the identity.
value.name: client-ssl

value.description: If the message contains an SAML assertion that contains an SAML Attribute statement, use the name in the Subject element of the Attribute statement as the identity.
value.name: saml-attr-name

value.description: If the message contains an SAML assertion that contains an SAML Authentication statement, use the name in the Subject element of the Authentication statement as the identity.
value.name: saml-authen-name

value.description: Use an SAML Artifact as described in the SAML Browser Artifact Profile.
value.name: saml-artifact

value.description: Use the IP address of the client for authentication.
value.name: client-ip-address

value.display: Subject DN from certificate in message signature
value.description: If the incoming message is digitally signed, verify the signature validity. If the signature is valid, use the Subject DN extracted from the certificate associated with the signature as the identity.
value.name: signer-dn

value.description: Apply the specified XPath expression to the incoming message. The result, which should be a string, is the identity token.
value.name: token

value.description: Find the named cookie in the HTTP Cookie header in the incoming message. The result, which is a URL decoded string, is the identity token.
value.name: cookie-token

value.description: Extract the user identity from an LTPA token. To use a token that is in the message, rather than in the HTTP header, also click "Use WS-Security Token First".
value.name: ltpa

value.description: Extract the identity from the processing metadata, such as protocol headers, system variables, and other custom metadata sources. Uses a processing metadata configuration to identify extracted items. Must use a custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file for authentication.
value.name: metadata

value.description: Extract the identity from the JSON Web Token (JWT).
value.name: jwt

value.description: Apply the specified stylesheet or GatewayScript file to the incoming message to determine the identity.
value.name: custom

value.description: Use the username and password from an HTML login page.
value.name: html-forms-auth

value.display: Redirect to a social login provider
value.description: Redirect the client to the specified endpoint in the social login policy. AAA policy extracts the identity from the ID token that the specified endpoint sends.
value.name: social-login

value.description: Support OAuth 2.0 protocol.
value.name: oauth

value.description: Use a DataPower AAA information file
value.name: xmlfile

value.description: Use a custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file
value.name: custom

property.name: WSSecureConversationCryptoKey
SAMLSourceIDMappingFile
property.summary: File that contains the SAML Artifact mapping.
property.description: The file that contains a mapping of SAML Artifact source IDs to artifact retrieval endpoints. This file is required only if artifacts are retrieved from multiple endpoints and the source ID for these endpoints are encoded in the artifact itself, as per the SAML specification. If there is only one artifact retrieval URL, it can be specified by the SAML Artifact responder URL in the authentication phase.

property.name: PingIdentityCompatibility
property.summary: PingIdentity compatibility.
property.description: Enable PingIdentity compatibility when using SAML for authentication or authorization.

property.name: SAML2MetadataFile
property.summary: File that contains SAML 2.0 metadata.
property.description: The file that contains metadata used in SAML 2.0 protocol message exchanges. This metadata is used to identify Identity Provider endpoints and certificates needed to secure SAML 2.0 message exchanges. This file must have a &lt;md:EntitiesDescriptor> top-level element, with one or more &lt;EntityDescriptor> child elements (one per Identity Provider).

property.name: DoSValve
property.summary: Value to filter out denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.
property.description: Set the maximum times of same XML processing that AAA policy allows for each user request. The AAA policy assumes that more than this value of the same processing is caused by potential DoS flooding attacks. The AAA policy limits the number of times to process the same request. These processes can include encryption, decryption, message signing, or signature verification. Currently, only identity extraction with subject DN from certificate in message signature and authorization with signer certificate for digitally signed messages support this setting. These methods designate the number of signatures or signing reference URIs. <p>The default value is 3. This value means that the AAA policy processes only the first 3 signature and each signature can contain up to 3 reference URIs. Additional signatures or reference URIs are ignored.</p>

property.name: LDAPVersion
property.summary: Version of the LDAP protocol for bind.
property.description: Select the LDAP protocol version to use for the bind operation. The default value is v2.

property.name: EnforceSOAPActor
property.summary: Enforce the S11::actor or S12:role when the message is a WS-Security message.
property.display: Enforce actor or role for WS-Security message
property.description: Most of the times a WS-Security message has an S11:actor or S12:role attribute for its wsse:Security header, we can enforce those attributes when AAA tries to utilize wsse:Security header, for example, there should be only one wsse:Security element having same actor/role, and AAA should only process the wsse:Security header for the designated Actor/Role Identifier. This setting takes effect for all AAA steps except postprocessing, which generally generate new message for next SOAP node. The default value for this setting is 'on', enabling SOAP actor/role enforcement.

property.name: WSSecActorRoleID
property.summary: The assumed S11:actor or S12:role identifier that the AAA policy act as.
property.description: If specified, the AAA policy acts as the assumed actor or role when it consumes the wsse:Security headers. This setting takes effect only when the AAA policy tries to process the incoming WS-Security message before making an authorization decision. Postprocessing does not use this setting. Postprocessing uses its own setting in generating WS-Security messages for the next SOAP node. Some well-known values are as follows: <table border="1"><tr><td valign="left">http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/actor/next</td><td>Every one, including the intermediary and ultimate receiver, receives the message should be able to processing the Security header.</td></tr><tr><td valign="left">http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope/role/none</td><td>No one should process the Security Header.</td></tr><tr><td valign="left">http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope/role/next</td><td>Every one, including the intermediary and ultimate receiver, receives the message should be able to processing the Security header.</td></tr><tr><td valign="left">http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope/role/ultimateReceiver</td><td>The message ultimate receiver can process the Security header. This is the default value if such setting is not configured.</td></tr><tr><td valign="left">&lt;blank or empty string></td><td>The empty string "" (without quotes) indicates that no "actor/role" identifier is configured. if there is no actor/role setting configured, the ultimateReceiver is assumed when processing the message, and no actor/role attribute will be added when generating the WS-Security header. There should not be more than one Security headers omitting the actor/role identifier.</td></tr><tr><td valign="left">USE_MESSAGE_BASE_URI</td><td>The value "USE_MESSAGE_BASE_URI" without quotes indicates that the actor/role identifier will be the base URL of the message, if the SOAP message is transported using HTTP, the base URI is the Request-URI of the http request.</td></tr><tr><td valign="left">any other customized string</td><td>You can input any string to identify the actor or role of the Security header.</td></tr></table><p>The default value is a blank value.</p>

property.name: AUSMHTTPHeader
property.summary: HTTP headers of interest from CA Single Sign-on responses to include in responses or requests if configured
property.description: Specifies the HTTP headers from CA Single Sign-On responses. When specified, these headers are included into the request or response headers based on the setting of the CA Single Sign-on header flow.

property.name: AZSMHTTPHeader
property.summary: HTTP headers of interest from CA Single Sign-on responses to include in responses or requests if configured
property.description: Specifies the HTTP headers from CA Single Sign-On responses. When specified, these headers are included into the request or response headers based on the setting of the CA Single Sign-on header flow.

property.name: DynConfig
property.summary: How to obtain the AAA policy configuration dynamically
property.description: Specifies how to obtain the AAA policy configuration dynamically. Dynamic configuration enables users to configure AAA policy at run time. When enabled, the configuration of AAA is determined dynamically based on the template AAA policy and the parameters that the dynamic configuration custom URL returns.

property.name: ExternalAAATemplate
property.summary: The external AAA policy to use as the template
property.description: Specifies an external AAA policy to use as the template. When specified, it overwrites the configuration of the current AAA policy.

property.name: DynConfigCustomURL
property.summary: The location of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file
property.description: <p>Specifies the location of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file where to obtain the AAA policy configuration. The obtained configuration overwrites the configuration that is defined in the template AAA policy. In the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file, it is recommended that you modify only those properties to be dynamically overwritten in the template AAA policy.</p><p>See the <tt>ModifyAAAPolicy</tt> element in the store:///xml-mgmt.xsd schema to construct a schema-compliant AAA configuration. For the nodeset that the custom URL is expected to return and a sample stylesheet, see the topic in IBM Knowledge Center.</p>

object.description: An AAA policy establishes the configuration to support the authentication and authorization of users requesting resources from the back-end servers. An AAA policy consists of the following components. <table><tr><td valign="top">Identity extraction</td><td>One of many methods that discovers which identity is asserted in the service request. This processing phase answers the question, "What is your name?"</td></tr><tr><td valign="top">Authentication</td><td>One of many methods that authenticates the asserted identity. Methods include communication with external authorities, such as an LDAP server. The identity is accepted as authentic or rejected. When authenticated successfully, the identity is used as a credential.</td></tr><tr><td valign="top">Resource extraction</td><td>One of many methods that discovers which resource service is requested (such as query an account or perform an update) This processing phase answers the question, "What do you want to do?"</td></tr><tr><td valign="top">Credential mapping</td><td>While an identity can be authenticated by one authority as valid, this identity or credential might not be known to the authority that authorizes the requested resource. This processing phase allows the mapping of credentials from one form to another for interoperability between systems.</td></tr><tr><td valign="top">Resource mapping</td><td>While a resource can be identified from the service request, this resource name might not be known to the authority that authorizes use of the requested resource. This processing phase allows the mapping of resource names from one form to another for interoperability between systems.</td></tr><tr><td valign="top">Authorization</td><td>The combination of the authenticated and possibly remapped credential with the requested and possibly remapped resource are submitted to an authority for authorization. That authority could reside elsewhere on the network. The request for service is accepted or rejected.</td></tr><tr><td valign="top">Postprocessing</td><td>Additional processing to perform after authorization, such as the generation of a WS-Trust token or SAML assertion.</td></tr></table>

value.name: none
value.summary: No authentication. This setting is the default value.

value.name: plain
value.summary: Use basic authentication credentials, which are user and password.

property.name: MaximumFrameSize
property.summary: Maximum frame size to allow
property.description: Specify the maximum frame size in bytes to allow. Frames Frames that are larger are rejected. When rejected, the connection is closed. Enter a value in the range 512 - 104857600. The default value is 104857600.

property.name: AutoRetry
property.summary: Whether to enable the automatic retry procedure after an AMQP connection failure
property.description: Indicates whether to enable the automatic retry procedure after an AMQP connection failure. By default, the automatic retry behavior is enabled. This setting does not affect attempts over an established connection.

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Interval to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection
property.description: <p>Specify the interval in seconds to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection. After the number of attempts is reached, attempts to reestablish a failed connection use the interval that is defined by the long retry interval. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 10.</p><p>This setting does not affect attempts over an established connection.</p>

property.name: RetryAttempts
property.summary: Number of attempts for a failed connection to the remote server
property.description: Specify the number of attempts for a failed connection to the remote AMQP server. After the number of attempts is reached, the long retry interval is used. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 6. The special value of 0 disables the long interval, where the retry interval is used forever.

property.name: LongRetryInterval
property.summary: Interval to use after the number of attempts is reached to attempt to reestablish a failed connection
property.description: <p>Specify the interval in seconds to use after the number of attempts is reached to attempt to reestablish a failed connection. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 600.</p><p>This setting does not affect attempts over an established connection.</p>

property.name: ReportingInterval
property.summary: Interval between writing identical messages for failed connection attempts
property.description: Specify the interval in seconds between the writing of identical log message. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 10.
Specify the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and the remote AMQP broker.

object.description: In AMQP, distributed source and target termini are managed by a broker. The broker provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring and polling termini. The broker ensures that sent messages are directed to the correct target terminus or are routed to another server. The AMQP broker configuration on the DataPower Gateway corresponds to an AMQP broker that is running on another host in the network. The configured properties enable communication between the DataPower Gateway and the remote AMQP broker.

property.description: Indicates the maximum number of requests that the API Gateway can handle within a time interval. The value of 0 indicates no limit.

property.name: Rate
Interval
property.summary: Time interval for the rate limit
property.description: Indicates the time interval for the rate limit. Specify a value that is greater than or equal to 1. The default value is 1.

property.name: Unit
property.summary: Time unit for the rate limit
property.description: Indicates the time unit for the rate limit. The default value is second.

property.name: HardLimit
property.summary: Whether to enable hard limit
property.description: <p>Indicates whether to reject requests when the specified rate limit is reached.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the API Gateway rejects requests when the limit is exceeded.</li><li>When disabled, the API Gateway still handles the requests but produces a warning message.</li></ul><p>By default, the API Gateway does not reject requests when the limit is exceeded.</p>

property.name: CacheOnly
property.summary: Use the local cache first to enforce the rate limit
property.description: Specifies whether to use the local cache first to enforce the rate limit. In peer group mode, using the local cache first can prevent transaction delays if communication problems arise across the peer group. However, the transaction count is less precise when this setting is enabled.

property.name: IsClient
property.summary: Whether to apply the rate limit to the client
property.description: Indicates whether to apply the rate limit to the client or to an internal component. Client rate limits return a 429 error when exceeded. Non-client rate limits return a 503 error when exceeded. When set to <tt>off</tt> , rate limit information is not included in the response header.

property.name: UseApiName
property.summary: Whether to use the API name as part of the rate limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the API name as part of the rate limit key.

property.name: UseAppId
property.summary: Whether to use the application ID as part of the rate limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the application ID as part of the rate limit key.

property.name: UseClientId
property.summary: Whether to use the client ID as part of the rate limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the client ID as part of the rate limit key.

property.name: DynamicValue
property.summary: The dynamic value for the rate limit
property.description: Indicates the dynamic value string for the rate limit, which should contain one or more context variables. The dynamic value makes it possible to use a context variable to enforce the rate limit based on parameters other than those defined in the rate limit scheme, such as a user name, incoming IP address, or server name. The context variable can be set in a GatewayScript action and then included in the dynamic value. <p>The following example uses the context object in a GatewayScript action to add the <tt>my.server</tt> variable to the API context.</p><p><tt>context.set("my.server", "server34")</tt></p><p>The dynamic value can then include the variable <tt>my.server</tt> , which resolves to the server name <tt>server34</tt> .</p><p>The default value is an empty string.</p>

property.name: Weight
property.summary: Expression determining how much weight to apply to the limit.
property.description: Specifies a JSONata expression that assigns a weight value to the transaction. For each API call, the value computed by the weight expression is applied to the rate limit. The default value is 1. If the weight expression evaluates to a value that is less than or equal to 0, it is set to 1. An empty string results in an error.

property.name: EnableCache
property.summary: Whether to cache subscriber data
property.description: Specifies whether to cache subscriber entries that are retrieved from the API manager. When enabled, retrieved entries are cached on the API Gateway. Future inquiries search the cache before querying from the API manager.

property.name: CacheCapacity
property.summary: Maximum number of subscriber entries allowed in the cache
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of subscriber entries that can be cached. Enter a value in the range 8 - 51200. The default value is 128. When the limit is exceeded, the least recently used (LRU) entry is removed.

property.name: RoutingPrefix
property.summary: Prefixes of the routing path
property.description: The API Gateway uses the routing prefix to determine which API collection to route the request to. <p>You can use routing prefixes to organize your APIs and plans into collections and subcollections. For example, if you have a collection of APIs serving for a certain purpose, and the APIs are to be used by two segments of your organization, you might create two API collections with the organization name, purpose name, and segment name in the routing prefix. If the organization name is <tt>myorg</tt> , the APIs serve for purpose <tt>purpose1</tt> , and the two segments under the organization is <tt>section1</tt> and <tt>section2</tt> , the resulting URL routing prefixes are <tt>/myorg/purpose1/section1</tt> and <tt>/myorg/purpose1/section2</tt> . The resulting host name routing prefixes are <tt>section1.purpose1.myorg</tt> and <tt>section2.purpose1.myorg</tt> .</p><p>The API Gateway uses the routing prefix to form the complete URI <tt>&lt;routing prefix>&lt;base path>&lt;operation path></tt> and accepts only the incoming requests with this URI. In the complete URI, &lt;base path> is the base path on which the API is served, and &lt;operation path> is the relative path to the base path where the operations are available.</p><p>The default routing prefix is slash (/) when the type is URI and blank when the type is host name. An API collection becomes the default API collection in the API Gateway when the API collection has a default routing prefix. The API Gateway routes a request to the default API collection when other API collections do not match. An API Gateway can have only one default API collection; therefore, regardless of the prefix type, only one API collection can be configured with the default routing prefix.</p>

property.name: DefaultRateLimit
property.summary: Default rate limit for API requests with no API key
property.description: Defines the rate limit scheme for the API requests that do not carry API key credentials for client identification. When not defined, requests without API keys are rejected.

property.name: EnforcePreAssemblyRateLimits

property.description: When this toggle is off, only the limits specified in a Rate Limit action in the assembly will be applied to this API.

property.name: APIProcessingRule

property.description: Defines the processing rule that matches the target API, enforces the rate limiting and security rules of using the API, executes the assembly of the API, and responds to the client.

For an assembly function that is a user-defined policy, configure the assembly function with a mechanism other than a watched file processed by a configuration sequence. Objects created through configuration sequence processing are not persisted to the startup configuration. The preferred method for DataPower configuration for user-defined policies is to define them explicitly so that they persist to the startup configuration.

property.summary: Name of the API
property.name: Name
Version
property.summary: Version of the API
property.description: Specifies the version of the API.

property.name: BasePath
property.summary: The base path for the API
property.description: Specifies the base path on which the API is served, which is relative to the host. When the base path is not specified, the APIs are served directly under the host. The base path does not include the host name or any additional segments for paths or operations. The base path must start but not end with slash (/). All resources in a REST API are defined relative to its base path.

property.name: HtmlPage
property.summary: Location of a static HTML page
property.description: Specifies the name and location of a static HTML page that the API can return. Import the file to the <tt>local:</tt> directory, the <tt>store:</tt> directory, or the <tt>temporary:</tt> directory, or one their subdirectories in the DataPower file system.

property.name: Type
property.summary: Type of the API
property.description: Specifies the API type.
Specifies the assembly to apply to API calls. An assembly comprises a rule that defines the actions to run against the API call and how to handle the errors during assembly execution.
property.summary: The assembly for API invocation
property.name: Assembly
Path
property.summary: Routes to access REST APIs
property.description: Specifies a list of paths through which users access the API operations. A path consists of one or more HTTP operations.

property.name: Consume
property.summary: MIME types that the API can consume
property.description: Specifies a list of MIME types that the API can consume. These MIME types apply to all API operations. You can override the setting for specific operations in the API operation.

property.name: Produce
property.summary: MIME types that the API can produce
property.description: Specifies a list of MIME types that the API can produce. These MIME types apply to all API operations. You can override the setting for specific operations in the API operation.

property.name: SwaggerLocation
property.summary: The name and location of the Swagger document
property.description: <p>When you create the API definition from a Swagger document, specify the name and location of the Swagger document. Prepare the document as follows before you specify the location.</p><ol><li>When the Swagger document is a YAML file, convert it to JSON format.</li><li>Import the JSON file to the <tt>local:</tt> directory, the <tt>temporary:</tt> directory, or one their subdirectories in the DataPower file system.</li></ol><p>When you create the API definition by manually specifying the API properties, this field is not applicable.</p>

property.name: GraphQLSchema
property.summary: GraphQL schema location.
property.description: GraphQL schema location.

property.name: WsdlAdvertisedSchemaLocation
property.summary: The name and location of the WSDL file or archive file with a WSDL file, which should be used to advertise the contract for this API.
property.description: When you create the API definition from a WSDL file, specify the name and location of the WSDL document or archive of the WSDL and its dependencies.

property.name: WsdlValidationSchema
property.summary: The name and location of the top-level WSDL file to use to validate SOAP payloads.
property.description: When you create the API definition from a WSDL file, specify the name and location of the top-level WSDL document itself, which should be used to validate incoming SOAP payloads.

property.name: SecurityRequirement
property.summary: Required security schemes to execute API operations
property.description: Specifies the alternative security requirements to enforce for the API as a whole (that is, there is a logical OR between the security requirements). By default, the security requirement is applied to all operations in the API. But for each API operation, you can override the API-level security by separately specifying security schemes to enforce on the operation level.

property.name: RequireAPIMutualTLS
property.summary: Require mutual TLS protection
property.description: Require mutual TLS protection for this API.

property.name: APIMutualTLSSource
property.summary: Sources to obtain the client certificate for mutual TLS
property.description: Indicates the sources to obtain the client certificate for mutual TLS. Because you can define multiple ways to obtain the source, ensure that you sequence the methods appropriately.

property.name: APIMutualTLSHeaderName
property.summary: HTTP header that contains the client certificate for mutual TLS
property.description: The HTTP header that contains the client certificate for mutual TLS. The default value is <tt>X-Client-Certificate</tt> .

property.name: Properties
property.summary: Custom API properties
property.description: Specifies a list of custom API property entries. An API property is a type of context variable whose value is dependent on the API collection that the API is provisioned in. Collection-specific API properties allow you to use the same API definition in different API collections when a property in a collection requires a unique or different value. A custom property entry specifies one property and the property value for one collection. To add another custom property, or to specify a different property value for another collection, add another entry.

property.name: Schemas
property.summary: API schemas
property.description: Specifies a list of API schema objects that define data types for request or message validation. An API data type consists of a name and the API schema object.

property.name: CORSToggle
property.summary: Whether to enable the API Gateway to handle CORS requests
property.description: Indicates whether to enable the API Gateway to handle the the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) requests <ul><li>When enabled, the API Gateway runs the API CORS action to handle all CORS requests that are made to the API.</li><li>When not enabled, all CORS requests are handled by the assembly or the back end. When preflight requests are passed to the back end, an <tt>OPTIONS</tt> operation must be defined for each path that can be the target of the request. Otherwise, the preflight request to that path can result in an error.</li><li>When a preflight request is received, the API routing action sets the <tt>request.attributes.isCORSPreflight</tt> flag to <tt>true</tt> . This flag is set even when CORS is not enabled in the API definition. This behavior allows for the customized handling of preflight requests.</li></ul>

property.name: ActivityLogToggle
property.summary: Whether to enable logging for API activities
property.description: <p>Indicates whether to enable logging for API activities. The API Gateway runs the API activity log action to generate logs. To generate log data for calls that invoke this API, you must first enable this property and ensure that the following conditions are met.</p><ul><li>The logging type for successful and unsuccessful API invocations is not set to none.</li><li>The activity log action is added in the API rule associated with the API definition.</li></ul><p>When disabled, the API Gateway does not generate any log data for calls that invoke this API.</p>

property.name: Content
property.summary: Type of content to be logged when the API invocation is successful
property.description: Defines the type of content to log when the API invocation is successful.

property.name: ErrorContent
property.summary: Type of content to be logged when the API invocation completes with error
property.description: Defines the type of content to log when the API invocation completes with error.

property.name: MessageBuffering
property.summary: Whether to enable message buffering for the API
property.description: <p>Indicates whether to enable message buffering for the API.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the message payload and the output of the assembly invoke action are read as a binary large object (BLOB).</li><li>When disabled, the message payload and the output of the assembly invoke action are only read by an asynchronous API call.</li></ul>

property.name: DeploymentState
property.summary: Deployment state of the API
property.description: Specifies the deployment state of the API. By default, the deployment state of an API is running.

property.name: ShareRateLimitCount
property.summary: Share rate limit count among all APIs under an application.
property.description: Share rate limit count among all APIs under an application.

object.description: <p>Configure a REST API definition that uses HTTP requests to GET, PUT, POST, and DELETE data.</p>

property.name: Title
property.summary: The title for the API action.

property.description: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the API action. This path is exposed in the debug data by the API Gateway for use by debugging tools. For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.
property.summary: The path which correlates the API action to a specific part of the API specification.
property.name: CorrelationPath

property.description: A descriptive summary for the API Execute Action configuration.
property.summary: Enter a brief descriptive summary for the API Execute Action configuration.

object.description: An API execute action executes the assembly rule that is identified at the runtime for the incoming API request.

value.description: When set to no, don't share rate limit count among all APIs under an application.
value.name: no

property.description: Indicates the name of the burst limit scheme.
property.summary: Name of the burst limit scheme
property.name: Name

property.description: Indicates the maximum allowed burst rate. The value of 0 indicates no limit. A message is rejected when the burst limit is exceeded.
property.summary: Maximum allowed burst rate
property.name: Burst
Interval
property.summary: Time interval for the burst limit
property.description: Indicates the time interval for the burst limit. Specify a value that is greater than or equal to 1. The default value is 1.

property.name: Unit
property.summary: Time unit for the burst limit
property.description: Indicates the time unit for the burst limit. The default value is second.

property.name: CacheOnly
property.summary: Use the local cache first to enforce the burst limit
property.description: Specifies whether to use the local cache first to enforce the burst limit. In peer group mode, using the local cache first can prevent transaction delays if communication problems arise across the peer group. However, the transaction count is less precise when this setting is enabled.

property.name: IsClient
property.summary: Whether to apply the burst limit to the client
property.description: Indicates whether to apply the burst limit to the client or to an internal component. Client burst limits return a 429 error when exceeded. Non-client burst limits return a 503 error when exceeded. When set to <tt>off</tt> , burst limit information is not included in the response header.

property.name: UseApiName
property.summary: Whether to use the API name as part of the burst limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the API name as part of the burst limit key.

property.name: UseAppId
property.summary: Whether to use the application ID as part of the burst limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the application ID as part of the burst limit key.

property.name: UseClientId
property.summary: Whether to use the client ID as part of the burst limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the client ID as part of the burst limit key.

property.name: DynamicValue
property.summary: The dynamic value for the burst limit
property.description: Indicates the dynamic value string for the burst limit, which should contain one or more context variables. The dynamic value makes it possible to use a context variable to enforce the burst limit based on parameters other than those defined in the burst limit scheme, such as a user name, incoming IP address, or server name. The context variable can be set in a GatewayScript action and then included in the dynamic value. <p>The following example uses the context object in a GatewayScript action to add the <tt>my.server</tt> variable to the API context.</p><p><tt>context.set("my.server", "server34")</tt></p><p>The dynamic value can then include the variable <tt>my.server</tt> , which resolves to the server name <tt>server34</tt> .</p><p>The default value is an empty string.</p>

property.name: Weight
property.summary: Expression determining how much weight to apply to the limit.
property.description: Specifies a JSONata expression that assigns a weight value to the transaction. For each API call, the value computed by the weight expression is applied to the burst limit. The default value is 1. If the weight expression evaluates to a value that is less than or equal to 0, it is set to 1. An empty string results in an error.
Indicates the name of the rate limit scheme.

FrontProtocol
property.summary: Source protocol handler (HTTP and HTTPS only)
property.description: Specifies the source protocol handler to handle the traffic between the API requester and the DataPower Gateway. The API Gateway Service can receive requests only through HTTP and HTTPS handlers.

property.name: DocCacheMaxDocs
property.summary: Maximum number of documents cached
property.description: Enter the maximum number of documents to cache. Enter a value in the range 1 - 250000. The default value is 5000.

property.name: DocCacheSize
property.summary: Maximum size of document cache
property.description: Enter the maximum size of the document cache. Regardless of the specified size, no document that is greater than 1073741824 bytes is cached. This restriction applies even if the cache has available space.

property.name: APICollection
property.summary: Applicable API collections
property.description: Specifies a list of collections where each collection packages the plans and subscribers to serve a specific group of clients.

value.description: A path parameter is part of the operation's URL but does not include the host or base path of the API. A path parameter should take the whole section or segment of the path URI. For example, in <tt>/items/{itemId}</tt> , the path parameter is <tt>itemId</tt> .
value.name: path

value.description: A query parameter is appended to the request URL. For example, in <tt>/items?id=###</tt> , the query parameter is <tt>id</tt> .
value.name: query

value.description: A body parameter is the payload that is appended to the HTTP request. You can define only one body parameter. The name of the body parameter has no effect on the parameter itself and is used for documentation purposes only. Because form parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation.
value.name: body

value.description: A form parameter is used to describe the payload of an HTTP request when the consumable MIME type of the request content contains <tt>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</tt> or <tt>multipart/form-data</tt> or both. This is the only parameter type that can be used to send files. Because body parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation. <ul><li>When the content type is <tt>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</tt> , the parameter format is similar to the format of query parameters but as a payload. For example, <tt>foo=1&amp;bar=swagger</tt> indicates that both <tt>foo</tt> and <tt>bar</tt> are form parameters. This is normally used for simple parameters that are being transferred.</li><li>When the content type is <tt>multipart/form-data</tt> , each parameter takes a section in the payload with an internal header. For example, for the header <tt>Content-Disposition: form-data; name="submit-name"</tt> the name of the parameter is <tt>submit-name</tt> . This type of form parameters is more commonly used for file transfers.</li></ul>
value.name: formdata

value.description: Custom headers that are expected as part of the request.
value.name: header

property.name: Security

property.description: Specifies the alternative security requirements to enforce for the operation (that is, there is a logical OR between the security requirements). This setting overrides any declared API-level security.

value.description: A path parameter is part of the operation's URL but does not include the host or base path of the API. A path parameter should take the whole section or segment of the path URI. For example, in <tt>/items/{itemId}</tt> , the path parameter is <tt>itemId</tt> .
value.name: path

value.description: A query parameter is appended to the request URL. For example, in <tt>/items?id=###</tt> , the query parameter is <tt>id</tt> .
value.name: query

value.description: A body parameter is the payload that is appended to the HTTP request. You can define only one body parameter. The name of the body parameter has no effect on the parameter itself and is used for documentation purposes only. Because form parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation.
value.name: body

value.description: A form parameter is used to describe the payload of an HTTP request when the consumable MIME type of the request content contains <tt>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</tt> or <tt>multipart/form-data</tt> or both. This is the only parameter type that can be used to send files. Because body parameters are also in the payload, body and form parameters cannot exist together for the same operation. <ul><li>When the content type is <tt>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</tt> , the parameter format is similar to the format of query parameters but as a payload. For example, <tt>foo=1&amp;bar=swagger</tt> indicates that both <tt>foo</tt> and <tt>bar</tt> are form parameters. This is normally used for simple parameters that are being transferred.</li><li>When the content type is <tt>multipart/form-data</tt> , each parameter takes a section in the payload with an internal header. For example, for the header <tt>Content-Disposition: form-data; name="submit-name"</tt> the name of the parameter is <tt>submit-name</tt> . This type of form parameters is more commonly used for file transfers.</li></ul>
value.name: formdata

value.description: Custom headers that are expected as part of the request.
value.name: header

A descriptive summary for the API Path configuration.
property.summary: Enter a brief descriptive summary for the API Path configuration.
property.name: UserSummary
Path
property.summary: The relative path to access the REST APIs
property.description: <p>Specifies the route to access the REST APIs. The path is appended to the base path to construct the full URI to access the APIs. The path must start but not end with the / character. When the path contains a parameter, make sure that you define the path parameter at either or both the path and operation levels.</p><ul><li>A parameter at the end of the path can contain a + qualifier to match multiple path levels as in the following example. <p><tt>/petstore/{type}/{+category}</tt></p><p>The <tt>{type}</tt> parameter matches one path level. The <tt>{+category}</tt> parameter matches multiple levels. The following paths match this path template.</p><ul><li><tt>/petstore/cats/supplies</tt></li><li><tt>/petstore/cats/supplies/health</tt></li><li><tt>/petstore/cats/supplies/health/medicines</tt></li><li><tt>/petstore/cats/supplies/health/medicines/a/b/c</tt></li></ul></li><li>The parameter at the end of the path can be the <tt>+any</tt> qualified parameter to accept all paths that begin with the base path as in the following example. <p><tt>/{+any}</tt></p></li></ul>

property.name: Operation
property.summary: Operations available on the path
property.description: Describes the operations that can be executed under the path. When no operation is defined, all operations are accepted under this path.

property.description: Indicates the name of the rate limit scheme.
property.summary: Name of the rate limit
property.name: Name

property.description: Indicates the maximum number of requests that the API Gateway can handle within a time interval. The value of 0 indicates no limit.
property.summary: Maximum number of requests to handle
property.name: Rate
Interval
property.summary: Time interval for the rate limit
property.description: Indicates the time interval for the rate limit. Specify a value that is greater than or equal to 1. The default value is 1.

property.name: Unit
property.summary: Time unit for the rate limit
property.description: Indicates the time unit for the rate limit. The default value is second.

property.name: HardLimit
property.summary: Whether to enable hard limit
property.description: <p>Indicates whether to reject requests when the specified rate limit is reached.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the API Gateway rejects requests when the limit is exceeded.</li><li>When disabled, the API Gateway still handles the requests but produces a warning message.</li></ul><p>By default, the API Gateway does not reject requests when the limit is exceeded.</p>

property.name: CacheOnly
property.summary: Use the local cache first to enforce the rate limit
property.description: Specifies whether to use the local cache first to enforce the rate limit. In peer group mode, using the local cache first can prevent transaction delays if communication problems arise across the peer group. However, the transaction count is less precise when this setting is enabled.

property.name: IsClient
property.summary: Whether to apply the rate limit to the client
property.description: Indicates whether to apply the rate limit to the client or to an internal component. Client rate limits return a 429 error when exceeded. Non-client rate limits return a 503 error when exceeded. When set to <tt>off</tt> , rate limit information is not included in the response header.

property.name: UseApiName
property.summary: Whether to use the API name as part of the rate limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the API name as part of the rate limit key.

property.name: UseAppId
property.summary: Whether to use the application ID as part of the rate limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the application ID as part of the rate limit key.

property.name: UseClientId
property.summary: Whether to use the client ID as part of the rate limit key
property.description: Indicates whether to use the client ID as part of the rate limit key.

property.name: DynamicValue
property.summary: The dynamic value for the rate limit
property.description: Indicates the dynamic value string for the rate limit, which should contain one or more context variables. The dynamic value makes it possible to use a context variable to enforce the rate limit based on parameters other than those defined in the rate limit scheme, such as a user name, incoming IP address, or server name. The context variable can be set in a GatewayScript action and then included in the dynamic value. <p>The following example uses the context object in a GatewayScript action to add the <tt>my.server</tt> variable to the API context.</p><p><tt>context.set("my.server", "server34")</tt></p><p>The dynamic value can then include the variable <tt>my.server</tt> , which resolves to the server name <tt>server34</tt> .</p><p>The default value is an empty string.</p>

property.name: Weight
property.summary: Expression determining how much weight to apply to the limit.
property.description: Specifies a JSONata expression that assigns a weight value to the transaction. For each API call, the value computed by the weight expression is applied to the rate limit. The default value is 1. If the weight expression evaluates to a value that is less than or equal to 0, it is set to 1. An empty string results in an error.

property.name: ProductTitle
RateLimit
property.summary: Rate limit scheme
property.description: Specifies the rate limit scheme to enforce. A rate limit scheme defines the maximum rate that is allowed in a specified time interval and the actions to take when the limit is exceeded.

property.name: BurstLimit
property.summary: Burst limit scheme
property.description: Specifies the burst limit scheme to enforce. A burst limit scheme defines the maximum burst rate that is allowed in a specified time interval. The burst limit scheme helps prevent usage spikes that may damage infrastructure. The burst limit takes higher priority than the rate limit, when a message arrives within an interval, the message is first checked against the burst limit scheme and then against the rate limit scheme.

property.name: AssemblyBurstLimit
property.summary: Burst limit scheme to be used by assembly rate limit action.
property.description: Specifies the burst limit scheme to enforce. A burst limit scheme defines the maximum burst rate that is allowed in a specified time interval. The burst limit scheme helps prevent usage spikes that may damage infrastructure. The burst limit takes higher priority than the rate limit, when a message arrives within an interval, the message is first checked against the burst limit scheme and then against the rate limit scheme.

property.name: AssemblyRateLimit
property.summary: Rate limit scheme to be used by assembly rate limit action.
property.description: Specifies the rate limit scheme to enforce. A rate limit scheme defines the maximum rate that is allowed in a specified time interval and the actions to take when the limit is exceeded.

property.name: AssemblyCountLimit
property.summary: Count limit scheme to be used by assembly rate limit action.
property.description: Specifies the count limit scheme to enforce. A count limit scheme defines the maximum count that is allowed and the actions to take when the limit is exceeded.

Specifies the space ID for the product. When space is enabled for a catalog, the catalog can be partitioned to spaces, where each space is used by a different API provider development team and has its own set of management capabilities that pertain specifically to the APIs in that space. Spaces enable each team to manage their APIs independently.
property.summary: ID of the space that the product belongs to in the catalog
property.name: SpaceID

property.description: Specifies the space name for the product. When space is enabled for a catalog, the catalog can be partitioned to spaces, where each space is used by a different API provider development team and has its own set of management capabilities that pertain specifically to the APIs in that space. Spaces enable each team to manage their APIs independently.
property.summary: Name of the space that the product belongs to in the catalog
property.name: SpaceName
API
property.summary: APIs to package into the plan
property.description: Specifies a list of APIs to package into the plan. You expose an API through a plan by associating the API to the plan.

property.name: ExcludeOperation
property.summary: Operations to exclude from the plan
property.description: Specifies a list of operations to exclude from the plan. When you exclude an operation from a plan, this operation is not available for access through this plan.

property.name: Override
property.summary: Rate limit scheme for specific operations
property.description: Specifies a list of operations that have their own rate limit schemes.

property.name: RateLimitScope
property.summary: The scope to apply the rate limit
property.description: Indicates the scope that you want to apply the rate limit to.

object.description: An API is exposed for access through an API plan. An API Plan packages a list of APIs and defines the rate limit schemes to enforce to access the APIs. By default, the rate limit scheme of the plan applies to all operations. However, you can exclude certain operations from the plan or override the plan-level rate limit schemes by specifying operation-specific rate limit schemes.

property.description: Specifies the schema URL for JSON message validation. For example, <tt>local:///petstore.json#/definitions/Pet</tt> . To accept all input, use the string <tt>accept</tt> instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string <tt>reject</tt> instead of entering a URL.
property.summary: JSON schema URL
property.name: JSONSchema

property.description: Specifies the schema URL for GraphQL message validation. For example, <tt>local:///petstore-Pet.graphql</tt> . To accept all input, use the string <tt>accept</tt> instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string <tt>reject</tt> instead of entering a URL.
property.summary: GraphQL schema URL
property.name: GraphQLSchema

property.description: Specifies the type of XML validation to perform, either XML or WSDL.
property.summary: XML type
property.name: XMLType
XMLValidationMode
property.summary: The mode for XML validation
property.description: Specifies the mode to validate XML messages: validate the entire message or only the SOAP body of the message.

property.name: XMLSchemaURL
property.summary: XML schema URL
property.description: Specifies the schema URL for XML message validation. For example, <tt>local:///petstore-Pet.xsd</tt> . To accept all input, use the string <tt>accept</tt> instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string <tt>reject</tt> instead of entering a URL.

property.name: WSDLSchemaURL
property.summary: WSDL schema URL
property.description: Specifies the schema URL for WSDL message validation. For example, <tt>local:///petstore-Pet.wsdl</tt> . To accept all input, use the string <tt>accept</tt> instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string <tt>reject</tt> instead of entering a URL.

property.name: WSDLPortQName
property.summary: Validate messages from a specific wsdl:port
property.description: The QName of the WSDL port that defines the service traffic to validate. The value should be a QName in the form "{namespace-uri}local-part" or "*" for all ports that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for the named port are considered valid.

property.name: WSDLOperationName
property.summary: Validate messages that match the specified wsdl:operation
property.description: The name of the WSDL operation that defines the service traffic to validate. The value should be the unqualified name of the operation or "*" for all operations that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for operations that match the specified name are considered valid.

property.name: WSDLMessageDirectionOrName
property.summary: Validate messages from wsdl:input, wsdl:output, or wsdl:faults that match the given name or direction
property.description: The name or direction of the WSDL input (wsdl:input), output (wsdl:output), or fault (wsdl:fault) that defines the service traffic to be validated. The value should be the name of one or more WSDL input, output, or fault components, or "#input" or "#output" for the request and response directions respectively, or "*" for all inputs, outputs, and faults that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for inputs, outputs, and faults that match the specified name or direction are considered valid. Faults are considered valid for the response direction.

property.name: WSDLAttachmentPart
property.summary: Validate messages defined by mime:content in the WSDL that match the specified message part name
property.description: The name of the WSDL message part that defines the content of a MIME attachment (mime:content/@part). The value should be the unqualified name of the message part. The name is the same as the part attribute on the corresponding mime:content component in the WSDL file. When this property is not defined or has the special value "*", the root MIME part is validated. The root MIME part is bound to a soap:body.

object.description: An API schema configuration defines schemas to validate JSON, XML, WSDL, or SOAP messages for an API path or an API operation.

property.description: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the API action. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.

object.description: <p>An API key security definition defines the credentials that an API client must provide to the API Gateway to identify itself when calling the API operations. You can require that the client must provide only the client ID, or both client ID and client secret, to call an API operation. When you require the client to provide both client ID and client secret, you must create two separate API Security API Key configurations, one of type ID and the other of type Secret.</p>

property.description: The host name or IP address of the mail server.

property.description: The name to access the mailbox on the server; for example, user@example.com.

property.name: Password

property.description: The password for the account that accesses the mailbox on the server.

property.name: PasswordAlias

property.name: DelayBetweenPolls
property.summary: Interval between polling sequences
property.description: <p>The number of seconds to wait after the completion of one polling sequence before starting the next one. A <em>polling sequence</em> is the time to retrieve the messages plus the time to complete their processing. Enter any value of 1 - 65535. The default is 300.</p><p><b>Note:</b> Some mail servers restrict the number of times an account can establish a connection during a specific time period. Ensure that the configured interval complies with any restriction.</p>

property.name: MaxMessagesPerPoll
property.summary: Maximum number of messages to retrieve in each polling cycle
property.description: The maximum number of mail messages to retrieve in each polling cycle. Enter any value of 1 - 100. The default is 5.

property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.description: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

object.description: The AS1 handler is a Post Office Protocol (POP) handler. The handler manages the polling of a mailbox on a mail server. The mailbox receives mail messages from external partners. The handler retrieves and deletes mail messages on each polling cycle. Each mail message that the handler retrieves results in one transaction.
