property.name: UserSummary
LocalAddress
property.label: IP address
property.summary: Enter the IP address or host alias on which the service listens.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the IP address or host alias to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. The default value indicates that the service listens on all IP addresses.
property.description: Specifies the address to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. The default value indicates that the service listens on all IP addresses.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.hoverhelp: Enter the port to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. Enter a value in the range of 1 - 65535. The default value is 80.
property.description: Specifies the port to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 80.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.summary: HTTP version for client side connections
property.description: Select the HTTP version for client side connections. The default value is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: AllowedFeatures
property.summary: Methods and versions to allow for incoming requests
property.description: Specifies the methods and versions to allow for incoming HTTP requests.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Whether to negotiate persistent connections on front side
property.description: Indicates whether to negotiate persistent connections where appropriate on front side. The default is enabled.

property.name: MaxPersistentConnectionsReuse
property.summary: The maximum number of times a persistent connection is reused on the front side
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of times a persistent connection is reused on the front side. When the maximum reuse count is reached, an explicit <tt>HTTP Connection: close</tt> header is sent in the response and the TCP connection is closed. The default value is 0, which means unlimited reuse.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Indicate whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections.
property.description: <p>Whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections.</p><p>The default is off. If enabled, the DataPower service uses GZIP to compress HTTP transmissions when the <tt>Accept-Encoding</tt> HTTP header indicates that compressed documents can be processed.</p><p>The <tt>Transfer-Encoding</tt> HTTP header indicates compression.</p>

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: The length of the longest incoming URL to accept
property.description: Specifies the length of the longest incoming URL to accept. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier. Enter a value in the range 1 - 128000. The default value is 16384.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum aggregate length of incoming HTTP headers to allow
property.description: Specifies the maximum aggregate length of incoming HTTP headers to allow. Enter a value in the range 5 - 128000. The default value is 128000.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.summary: Maximum number of headers to allow in HTTP requests
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of headers to allow in the incoming request messages. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum length of the name part of an HTTP header
property.description: Specifies the maximum length of HTTP header names. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting specifies the maximum length of the name portion for HTTP headers. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum length of the value part of an HTTP header
property.description: Specifies the maximum length of HTTP header values to allow. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting specifies the maximum length of the value portion of that header. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxQueryStringLen
property.summary: Maximum length of the HTTP query string to allow
property.description: The portion of the URL after the question mark (?) is known as the query string. This property specifies its maximum length in bytes. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

Specifies the access control list to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an access control list denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.
property.summary: The access control list to allow or deny access to this service
property.name: ACL

property.description: Specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The DataPower Gateway transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. The default value is Protocol, which represents ISO-8859-1, Latin 1.
property.summary: Character encoding of the original basic authentication values
property.name: CredentialCharset
SSLProxy

property.description: Specifies a TLS proxy profile for securing the communication between the requesting client and the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.summary: IP address, host name, or load balancer group name of the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.
property.description: Specifies the IP address, host name, or name of a load balancer group of the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: RemotePort
property.summary: Destination port on the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.
property.description: Specifies the destination port on the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: RemoteSSLProxy
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.
property.description: <p>Specifies a TLS proxy profile for securing the communication between the DataPower Gateway and the remote Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.</p>

property.name: RemoteConnectionTimeout
property.summary: Connection timeout
property.description: Specifies the number of seconds that the DataPower Gateway waits to establish a connection to the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 86400. The default value is 60.

property.name: XMLManager
property.summary: An XML manager
property.description: Specifies an existing XML manager. An XML manager obtains and manages XML documents, stylesheets, and other document resources on behalf of one or more services.

property.name: EnablePassthrough
property.summary: Whether to pass the original AS2 requests to DataPower service processing policy
property.description: Controls whether to pass the original AS2 requests to the processing policy of DataPower service. <ul><li>When enabled, the AS2 proxy handler passes the original AS2 requests to DataPower service processing policy.</li><li>When disabled, the AS2 proxy handler first uses the cryptographic information in the partner exchange profile to decrypt the incoming AS2 requests and verify the signature. The AS2 proxy handler then passes the decrypted request body with signature removed to DataPower service for processing.</li></ul>

property.name: EnableVisibilityEvent
property.summary: Whether to send visibility events to the MEIG visibility event endpoint
property.description: Controls whether to send the visibility events generated by the AS2 proxy handler to the MEIG visibility event endpoint. These visibility events are correlated to those generated by the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server in one transaction thread.

property.name: VisibilityEventEndpoint
property.summary: The location of the MEIG visibility event endpoint
property.description: Specifies the URL of the MEIG visibility event endpoint. Enter the URL in the format of static IBM MQ URL that provides the information about the IBM MQ server name, queue manager name, and name of the channel configured in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server. For example, dpmq://NAME_OF_MQ_OBJECT/?RequestQueue=QUEUE_NAME_FOR_VISIBILITY_EVENT

property.name: EnableHmacAuthentication
property.summary: Whether to use HMAC to secure visibility event delivery
property.description: Controls whether to use Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) to secure all visibility events sent to the visibility event endpoint. If HMAC is enabled in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server, you must enable HMAC authentication in the AS2 proxy handler to avoid message rejection.

property.name: HmacPassphrase
property.summary: HMAC passphrase
property.description: Specifies the passphrase used to calculate the HMAC token for message authentication and integrity check in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: HmacPassphraseAlias
property.summary: HMAC passphrase alias
property.description: Specifies the password alias of the passphrase used to calculate the HMAC token for message authentication and integrity checking in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: SSLClientConfigType
property.summary: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and the remote Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.
property.description: <p>The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and the remote Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server. This communication must be TLS protected. You can define the TLS proxy profile for this communication in one of the following places:</p><ul><li>Define the TLS profile in the user agent that is assigned to the XML manager for the DataPower service service.</li><li>Define the TLS profile here.</li></ul><p>Ensure that the TLS profile is defined in one of these places. Without the remote TLS profile, processing is stopped and an error is logged.</p>

property.name: SSLClient
property.summary: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets
property.description: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

object.description: A MEIG AS2 proxy handler receives AS2 requests over HTTP or HTTPS and forwards them to the backend which is assumed to be an IBM Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway (MEIG) server. AS2 proxy handlers conform to gateway specifications of RFC 2616 and AS2 specification of RFC 4130.

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 80) that specifies the port monitored by the HTTP service.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.summary: Front side HTTP version
property.description: Select the HTTP version to use on the front (client) side connection. The default is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: AllowedFeatures
property.summary: Request methods and versions must be of only the allowed types
property.description: Specifies the allowed methods and versions for incoming HTTP requests.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Enable/Disable persistent connections on front side
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Enable/Disable GZIP compression
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression functionality on front side.

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted
property.description: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted in bytes. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum Aggregate Size of Incoming Headers
property.description: The maximum aggregate byte size of incoming HTTP headers.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.summary: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.display: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.description: The maximum number of headers allowed in the request message. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the name portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the value portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxQueryStringLen
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.description: The portion of the URL after a ? is the query string. This property specifies its maximum length in bytes. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use an TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile.
property.description: Select an existing TLS proxy profile from the list to assign the TLS proxy profile to this handler. Click the + button to create a new TLS proxy profile and assign that TLS proxy profile to the handler.

This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

property.description: This AAA Policy will be used to authenticate inbound messages recieved on this protocol handler.
property.name: AAAPolicy
CredentialCharset
property.summary: Character encoding of the original basic authentication values
property.description: Specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The DataPower Gateway transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. Defaults to Protocol which is ISO-8859-1, Latin 1.

property.description: the TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

object.description: The configuration for a front side HTTP protocol handler. This handler receives HTTP requests sent to the device and forwards them to the appropriate gateway. It conforms to gateway specifications of RFC 2616.

value.description: The FTP server will have an ephemeral virtual file system with subdirectories created by configuration. The contents of this file system are private to an individual FTP control connection to the FTP server. The contents of this file system will not persist after this FTP control connection ends.
value.name: virtual-ephemeral

value.description: The FTP server will have a persistent virtual file system with subdirectories created by configuration. The contents of this file system are shared by all FTP control connections to this FTP server with the same authenticated user identity. The user identity is determined by the FTP user name and, if used, by the TLS certificate. The contents of this file system will persist after all FTP control connections end for a duration defined by Persistent Filesystem Timeout. This mode is required to support checkpoint/restart using the REST command.
value.name: virtual-persistent

value.description: The FTP server has a transparent file system. The files and directories shown are those on the back end of the associated DataPower service.
value.name: transparent

property.description: Enter the directory in the virtual file system of the FTP server where the FTP client can find this directory.
property.summary: Directory in virtual file system of the FTP server
property.name: VirtualPath

property.description: Enter the directory in the virtual file system of the FTP server where the responses to files that are stored in this directory will go.
property.summary: Virtual directory in which to put responses
property.name: ResponseDirectory

value.description: Allows, but does not require, the FTP client to use the PASV command to open data connections to the FTP server.
value.name: allow

value.description: Does not allow the FTP client to use the PASV command to open data connections to the FTP server. The FTP server will open all data connections to the FTP client (as directed by the FTP PORT command). This mode is not always compatible with firewalls.
value.name: disallow

value.description: Requires the FTP client to use the PASV command to open all data connections with the FTP server. This mode is useful when the FTP server is behind a firewall device that requires clients to use passive mode.
value.name: require

value.description: Does not allow the FTP client to encrypt data connections.
value.name: disallow

value.description: Allows, but does not require, the FTP client to encrypt data connections. TLS must be allowed on data connections.
value.name: allow

value.description: Requires the FTP client to encrypt data connections. TLS should be required on data connections.
value.name: require

value.description: Indicates that no response is made available to the client. Any response from the backend server is dropped.
value.name: none

value.description: Indicates that the response is made available as a file in the virtual file system that can be read by the FTP client. The directory for responses is configured on a per-virtual directory basis. The suffix specified by Response Suffix is added to the input file name and stored in the directory specified by Response Storage.
value.name: virtual-filesystem

value.description: Stores response files in temporary storage on the system. This storage has limited size. Using temporary storage reduces the available system storage for processing. Temporary storage should not be used when using a virtual persistent file system. In virtual persistent file systems, it is highly unlikely that there would be enough space. After a system restart or power cycle, response files are not available.
value.name: temporary

value.description: Stores response files on the top level directory of the specified NFS server. Only the NFS server limits the storage space.
value.name: nfs

object.name: AS3SourceProtocolHandler

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address
property.description: <p>Enter the address on which the FTP server service listens. The default of 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases can help ease migration tasks among machines. If the FTP server service is listening on a virtual IP address managed by a standby control group with the self-balancing feature enabled, incoming control and data connections will always go to the active member of the standby control group.</p>

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Local TCP port for the FTP server
property.description: <p>Enter the port that is monitored by the FTP Server service. This port is the port on which FTP control connections can be established. This port does not control the TCP port that is used for the data connections. If the FTP client uses the <b>PASV</b> command, data connections will use an arbitrary, unused TCP port. Defaults to 21. Valid range is 1 through 65535.</p>

property.name: FilesystemType
property.summary: The type of filesystem the FTP server will present
property.description: <p>Select the file system type that is presented by the FTP server.</p><ul><li>If Virtual Ephemeral or Virtual Persistent is chosen, the client can write files to all directories. These files are shown in directory listings but cannot be retrieved. For file system responses, the responses are shown and can be retrieved, renamed, and deleted by the client.</li><li>If Transparent is chosen, the file system shows the contents of the equivalent path of the server on the back-end of the Multi-Protocol Gateway with which this FTP server is associated.</li></ul><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: PersistentFilesystemTimeout
property.summary: Controls how long a Virtual Persistent file system with no active connections is retained
property.description: Enter the duration in seconds that a connection to a virtual file system is retained after all FTP control connections from user identities are disconnected. When the timeout expires, the virtual file system object is destroyed. All of the response files that were not deleted by the FTP client are deleted from their storage area. Default to 600 (10 minutes). Valid range is 1 to 43,200 seconds (12 hours).

property.name: VirtualDirectories
property.summary: Create directory in virtual file system of FTP server
property.description: In virtual mode, create a directory in the virtual file system that is presented by this FTP server. The FTP client can use all of these directories to write file to be processed. The root directory (/) is always present and cannot be created. Its response directory is always the root directory.

property.name: DefaultDirectory
property.summary: Default for current working directory
property.description: Enter the initial working directory on the FTP server (after users connect and authenticate). When using a virtual file system and the working directory is not the root directory, the specified directory must be one of the configured virtual directories. The default is the root directory (/).

property.name: MaxFilenameLength
property.summary: Maximum length of a file name on the server
property.description: Enter the maximum file name length on the FTP server. Defaults to 256 characters. Valid range is 1 through 4000.

<p>Select an Access Control List to apply. The ACL allows or denies access to the FTP server based on the IP address of the FTP client. When attached to a server, the default for an ACL is to deny all access. To deny access to only select IP addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0). Then, create deny entries for the desired hosts.</p>
property.name: ACL
RequireTLS
property.summary: Control whether FTP control connections require TLS encryption
property.description: <p>Specify whether FTP control connections require explicit TLS encryption. If required, the following rules apply: <ul><li>The FTP client must use the FTP <b>AUTH TLS</b> command before any other command.</li><li>You must specify an TLS profile to secure connections.</li></ul></p><p>This property does not control encryption of data transfers.</p>

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use an TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile.
property.description: <p>Specify an TLS proxy profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.</p>

<p>Selects the AAA Policy to perform authentication of user names and passwords provided to the FTP server by the client with the <b>USER</b> and <b>PASS</b> commands. If the authentication succeeds, the FTP client may use all the features of the FTP server. If the authentication fails, a 530 error is returned, and the user can attempt to authenticate again. Without this AAA Policy configured, any user name and password will be accepted.</p>
property.summary: AAA policy for validating user name and password
property.name: PasswordAAAPolicy

property.description: <p>Selects the AAA Policy to perform secondary authentication of the information provided in the TLS/TLS certificate provided during TLS negotiation after the <b>AUTH TLS</b> command to the FTP server. Primary authentication is done by the TLS Profile, it can completely reject a certificate. This authentication stage controls whether an FTP password will be demanded or not. If the result of this authentication succeeds, the FTP client will only have to use the <b>USER</b> command to login after the <b>AUTH TLS</b>. If this authentication fails, the FTP client will have to use both the <b>USER</b> and <b>PASS</b> commands to complete the login process. If no Certificate AAA Policy is configured, <b>USER</b> and <b>PASS</b> will always be required. If the <b>AUTH TLS</b> command is not used by the FTP client, <b>USER</b> and <b>PASS</b> will always be required.</p>
property.summary: AAA Policy for determining whether password is required
property.name: CertificateAAAPolicy
AllowCCC
property.summary: Control use of CCC command
property.description: <p>Specify whether the FTP <b>CCC</b> command can be used to turn off TLS encryption of the FTP control connection after user authentication. If allowed, the <b>CCC</b> command can be used to turn off encryption after authentication. Turning off encryption is necessary when the FTP control connection crosses a firewall or NAT device that needs to sniff the control connection. Turning off encryption eliminates the secrecy of the files being transferred and allows TCP packets injection attacks.</p>

property.name: Passive
property.summary: Control use of passive mode
property.description: Control use of the FTP PASV and EPSV commands by the FTP client, as an alternative to the PORT and EPRT commands. The default is to allow PORT, EPRT, PASV, and EPSV. Other settings either require PASV or EPSV, or require PORT or EPRT. If an acceptable PORT, EPRT, PASV, or EPSV command is not received, the STOR, STOU, RETR, LIST, and NLST data transfer commands will fail. (This FTP server will never attempt to connect to the deprecated default FTP data port at TCP port 20.)

property.name: UsePasvPortRange
property.summary: Enable using a limited range of TCP port numbers for Passive connections.
property.display: Limit Port Range for Passive Connections
property.description: <p>When enabled, when a PASV or EPSV command is received from the FTP client, instead of selecting any free listening TCP port in the range 1024 to 65534, allow configuration of a restricted port range. This may be used when a firewall wants to allow incoming FTP data connections only on a limited range of ports, particularly when it cannot "sniff" the FTP control connection.</p><p>Note that the size of the range specified limits how many FTP clients can be in the state between receiving the 227 response code to the PASV or EPSV command, and establishing the FTP data TCP connection. Pressure on this limited resource can be controlled by adjusting the passive data connection idle timeout.</p><p>While it is perfectly legal to configure multiple FTP servers on the same system to use the same (or overlapping) passive port ranges, realize that they are contending for a common resource in the TCP implementation.</p><p>However, it is not wise to use a port range that overlaps with other services (HTTP servers, etc.) that are configured on the system. There is no configuration checking for such conflicts, and other configured services will allocate the ports first, and they will not be available for the FTP server. (The FTP server allocates these listening ports dynamically.)</p>

property.name: PasvMinPort
property.summary: Lowest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the lowest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not greater than Maximum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvMaxPort
property.summary: Highest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the highest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not less than Minimum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvIdleTimeOut
property.summary: Idle timeout for a passive data connection
property.description: <p>Specifies the number of seconds that the server waits for a client to establish a passive connection. Use an integer in the range of 5 through 300. The default is 60.</p><p>This setting controls the amount of time in seconds between when the FTP server issues code 227 (Entering Passive Mode) in response to the <b>PASV</b> or <b>EPSV</b> command from the FTP client and when the FTP client must establish a TCP data connection to the listening port and issue a data transfer command.</p><ul><li>If the data connection is not established within the timeout period, the listening port will be closed. If a data transfer command is issued after the port is closed, the command fails with code 425 and the <tt>Failed to open data connection</tt> message.</li><li>If the data connection is established but no data transfer command is issued within the timeout period, the TCP data connection will be closed. Any data transfer command after the timeout will be treated as if the <b>PASV</b> or <b>EPSV</b> command was never issued. The command fails with code 425 and the <tt>Require PASV or PORT command first</tt> message.</li></ul>

property.name: DisablePASVIPCheck
property.summary: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check
property.display: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check
property.description: <p>This option will disable the IP security check that is done when processing the FTP PASV command. The check verifies that the IP address of the client connecting to the data connection is the same as the one that established the control connection.</p><p>The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server. Turn the option on if there is a specific reason the incoming connection will not be coming from the same client as the control connection (i.e. from a load balancer).</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: DisablePORTIPCheck
property.summary: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check
property.display: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check
property.description: <p>This option will disable the IP security check that verifies that outgoing data connections can only connect to the client.</p><p>The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server.</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: UseAlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Use Alternate PASV IP Address
property.description: <p>When on, this option will enable the ability to override the IP address that is presented to the FTP client when the server is in passive mode.</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: AlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Alternate PASV IP Address
property.description: <p>The numeric IP address that will be returned to the FTP client in response to a PASV command. This does not change the IP address that the FTP server will listen on, which is always the IP address that the FTP data connection was made to. This is used in certain situations when the FTP server is behind a firewall that is not FTP-aware.</p>

property.name: AllowLISTCmd
property.summary: Enable LIST command support
property.description: <p>When on, the server will make a distinction between the LIST and NLST commands. When off, the server will always respond with an NLST when requesting a file listing.</p><p>The default value for this option is off</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: AllowDELECmd
property.summary: Enable DELE (delete) support
property.description: <p>When on, allows the DELE (delete) command to be passed to the FTP back-end server. This is only valid in Transparent Filesystem type.</p><p>The default value for this option is off</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: DataEncryption
property.summary: Control use of data encryption for file transfers
property.description: Select the use of encryption for data connections (file transfers). Data encryption is controlled by the FTP PROT P command.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Control use of MODE Z command to compress data transfer
property.description: <p>Specify whether the FTP client can use FTP <b>MODE Z</b> compression. After enabling FTP compression, the FTP client can use the zlib method to compress data transfers.</p>

property.name: AllowSTOU
property.summary: Control use of STOU command for unique file names
property.description: <p>Specify whether the FTP client can use the FTP <b>STOU</b> command. When enabled, the FTP server generates a unique file name for each transferred file.</p>

property.name: UniqueFilenamePrefix
property.summary: Prefix of all unique filenames generated by STOU
property.description: <p>Enter the prefix (leading characters) for file names that are generated when using the FTP <b>STOU</b> command. When defining the prefix, the directory separator (/) is not allowed. The default is to not add a prefix, which is an empty string.</p><p><b>Note:</b> The software adds a numeric suffix.</p>

property.name: AllowREST
property.summary: Control use of the REST command for interrupted file transfers
property.description: <p>Controls whether the FTP client can use the FTP <b>REST</b> command to continue the transfer of a file after an interruption in the data transfer. This is supported in the BSD stream style described in draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt. (The MODE B style that is described in RFC 959 is not supported.) The FTP server must be configured with a virtual persistent file system.</p><p>For written files, the server will delay the actual processing until a timeout expires or until the next FTP command other than a <b>SIZE</b> or <b>REST</b> command. This processing allows the FTP client can return and resume to the transfer using the <b>SIZE</b>, <b>REST</b>, and <b>STOR</b> commands. The argument to the <b>REST</b> command <em>must</em> be the same as the byte count returned by the <b>SIZE</b> command.</p><p><b>Note:</b> The response code to all <b>STOR</b> commands on this server will always be 226. The response codes does not reflect the success of the transaction.</p><p>This capability is also supported for reading the response files, if the server is configured for a Response Type of Virtual Filesystem.</p><p><b>Note:</b> The generation of response files are delayed until the transaction is completed.</p>

property.name: RestartTimeout
property.summary: Time that the STOR command waits for a restart
property.description: <p>When restart (<b>REST</b>) is enabled, the number of seconds that the FTP client has to reconnect to the server and use the <b>SIZE</b>, <b>REST</b>, and <b>STOR</b> commands to continue an interrupted file transfer. If this period of time elapses, the data that was received to this point on the TCP data connection will be passed to the Multi-Protocol Gateway. This timeout is canceled if another command (other than <b>SIZE</b> or <b>REST</b>) is received on the FTP control connection.</p>

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.summary: Inactivity limit on FTP control connection
property.description: Enter the number of seconds that the FTP control connection can be idle. After the specified duration elapses, the FTP server closes the control connection. Defaults to 0, which disables the timeout.

property.name: ResponseType
property.summary: How to make response available to FTP client
property.description: Select how to make response files available for gateway transactions started by an FTP STOR or SOUT operation.

property.name: ResponseStorage
property.summary: Where to store response files
property.description: Select where response files are stored.

property.name: TemporaryStorageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of temporary file system
property.description: Enter in megabytes the maximum size for the temporary file system size. Defaults to 32 MB. Valid range is 1 MB through 2048 MB.

property.name: ResponseNFSMount
property.summary: NFS mount to store response files in
property.description: <p>When Response Type is Virtual File System and Response Storage is NFS, select an NFS static mount to apply. Each response file will have a unique file name in the NFS directory. The name of the response file is not related to the file name that the virtual file system presents to the FTP client. Generally, this NFS directory is not made available through the FTP server. This directory should not be used for any other purpose.</p>

property.name: ResponseSuffix
property.summary: URL file name suffix to response file
property.description: When the response type is a virtual file system or an FTP client, enter the suffix to add when generating response files. The directory separator (/) is not allowed. If the response type is a virtual file system and the FTP client is writing in virtual directories that do not have a response directory or if the response directory is the same as the virtual directory, this value must have a non-empty value. If empty, the response would try to overwrite the request, which is not allowed. Defaults to an empty string.

property.name: ResponseURL
property.summary: URL for generating a response via FTP client
property.description: <p>When Response Type is FTP Client, enter the URL to use when generating response files. This URL enables a response to be written using FTP commands. The URL must be an FTP URL that starts with <tt>ftp://</tt> . The URL should include a directory, but not a file name. The URL cannot include query parameters. The default is to have no response generated (an empty string).</p>

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

object.description: AS3 Handler

property.description: With allow selected, the range of IP addresses is granted access to the service. With deny selected, the range of IP address is denied access to the service.
property.name: Access

property.description: An IP address and network mask that defines a contiguous range of IP addresses, either granted or denied access to the current service.
property.name: Address

object.description: <p>An access control list (ACL) consists of a sequence of allow and deny clauses. Each clause identifies an IP address or range of addresses that allow or deny access to a service.</p><p>After associating an ACL with a service, the ACL grants access to addresses in allow clauses and denies access to all other addresses.</p><p>Candidate addresses are sequentially evaluated against each clause in the ACL. A candidate address is denied or granted access in accordance with the first clause that matches. Consequently, the order of the clauses in the ACL is vital.</p><p>An ACL with only deny clauses effectively disables a service by denying access to all addresses. To complete the ACL, include an allow clause to ensure that all addresses that are not explicitly denied access are granted access.</p>

property.hoverhelp: <p>Enter the set of access policies that define the access privileges for the profile. When more than one policy applies to a resource, the most specific policy is used. To create access policies, enter a correctly formatted policy statement.</p><p>A policy statement takes the <tt><i>address</i> / <i>domain</i> / <i>resource</i> ?Access= <i>privileges</i> &amp; <i>field</i> = <i>value</i></tt> general format.</p><dl><dt><i>address</i></dt><dd>The complete local IP address or host alias. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any address.</dd><dt><i>domain</i></dt><dd>The complete name of the application domain. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any application domain.</dd><dt>resource</dt><dd>The complete value for the resource type. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any resource type.</dd><dt><i>privileges</i></dt><dd>The privileges to apply. Separate permissions with the plus sign (+). For example, <tt>a+d+x+r+w</tt> defines add, delete, execute, read, and write privileges.</dd><dt><i>field</i></dt><dd>The complete name of a specific property in the configuration; for example, <tt>Name</tt> .</dd><dt><i>value</i></dt><dd>The PCRE match expression for the property value; For example, <tt>foo(.*)bar</tt> .</dd></dl>

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state

Specifies the descriptive summary for the analytics endpoint.
property.summary: Descriptive summary for the Gateway Peering Manager
property.name: UserSummary
AnalyticsServerURL
property.summary: URL to offload the collected API event data
property.description: <p>Specifies the URL to offload the collected API event data. This URL can start with <tt>http</tt> or <tt>https</tt> for an Elasticsearch server or start with <tt>dpkafka</tt> for a Kafka server</p><ul><li>For an Elasticsearch server, specify the full URL to the endpoint starting with the <tt>http</tt> or <tt>https</tt> protocol identifier. With HTTPS, you must assign a TLS client profile.</li><li>For a Kafka server, specify only the name of the existing Kafka cluster configuration after the <tt>dpkafka</tt> protocol identifier. To complete the complete the URL, you must specify which request topic to offload analytics data.</li></ul>

property.name: SSLClient
property.summary: TLS client profile to secure connections
property.description: <p>Specifies the TLS client profile to secure connections with the analytics endpoint. With HTTPS, you must assign a TLS client profile.</p><p>This property is meaningful only when HTTPS is used to connect to the analytics endpoint.</p>

property.name: RequestTopic
property.summary: Name of the Kafka request topic to offload analytics data
property.description: <p>Specifies the name of the Kafka request topic to offload analytics data.</p><p>This property is meaningful only when Kafka is the analytics endpoint.</p>

property.name: MaxRecords
property.summary: Maximum number of records that can be buffered
property.description: <p>Specifies the maximum number of records that can be buffered. The collected analytics data is offloaded when 10% of this value set or the defined interval is reached.</p><p>The value must be a power of 2. Enter a value in the range 256 - 65536. The default value is 1024.</p>

property.name: MaxRecordsMemoryKB
property.summary: Maximum size of each record
property.description: Specifies the maximum size of each record in kilobytes. Enter a value in the range 4 - 1024. The default value is 512.

property.name: MaxDeliveryMemoryMB
property.summary: Maximum size for each delivery
property.description: Specifies the maximum memory for each delivery through the analytics endpoint in megabytes. Enter a value in the range 1 - 1024. The default value is 512.

property.name: Interval
property.summary: Interval between offloads
property.description: <p>Specifies the interval in seconds between offloads. Data is offloaded at this interval or when the 10% of the value set for maximum records is reached.</p><p>Enter a value in the range 1 - 3600. The default value is 600.</p>

property.name: DeliveryConnections
property.summary: number of connection to establish per delivery to the remote server
property.description: <p>Specifies the number of connection to establish per delivery to the remote server to offload analytics data. Each connection can carry a bulk activity log.</p><p>Enter a value in the range 1 - 100. The default value is 1.</p><p>This property is meaningful only when Kafka is the analytics endpoint.</p>

object.description: Configure an analytics endpoint to buffer API event data and offload the collected data as a bulk activity log to a remote server. When offloaded, you can use this data for display and analysis.

property.name: EnforceAPISecurity

property.description: The API security definitions and requirements are configured on the API definition or operation. The routed definition and operation dictate the security that the transaction must fulfill.

property.name: StopOnError
property.summary: Controls whether to stop processing if client security fails.
property.description: Whether to stop processing if client security fails. If failed, stops the assembly and return an error.

property.name: SecretRequired
property.summary: Controls whether to require the client secret.
property.description: Whether to require the client secret. When required, the secret is compared to the registered secret on the application that is identified by the client ID.

property.name: ExtractCredentialMethod
property.summary: Specifies the method to extract client credentials from the request
property.description: <p>The method to extract client credentials from the request.</p><ul><li>For all methods except HTTP, use the ID name and the Secret name to specify the locations that contains the ID and the location that contain the secret. <ul><li>When cookie, specify which cookie.</li><li>When context variable, specify which runtime context variable.</li><li>When form data, specify the form data.</li><li>When header, specify which header.</li><li>When query parameter, specify which query parameter.</li></ul></li><li>For the HTTP method, use the HTTP type to specify the format of the <tt>Authorization</tt> header, which expects the basic form in the <tt>Basic <i>base64_id:secret</i></tt> format.</li></ul>

property.name: IdName
property.summary: Specifies the location where to find the client ID to extract.
property.description: <p>The location where to find the client ID to extract.</p><ul><li>When cookie, specify which cookie.</li><li>When context variable, specify which runtime context variable.</li><li>When form data, specify the form data.</li><li>When header, specify which header.</li><li>When query parameter, specify which query parameter.</li></ul>

property.name: SecretName
property.summary: Specifies the location where to find the secret to extract.
property.description: <p>The location where to find the secret to extract.</p><ul><li>When cookie, specify which cookie.</li><li>When context variable, specify which runtime context variable.</li><li>When form data, specify the form data.</li><li>When header, specify which header.</li><li>When query parameter, specify which query parameter.</li></ul>

property.name: HTTPType
property.summary: Specifies the format of the Authorization header.
property.description: The format of the <tt>Authorization</tt> header.

property.name: AuthenticateClientMethod
property.summary: Specifies the method to authenticate the extracted client credentials
property.description: The method to authenticate the extracted client credentials. When third-party, specify the user-registry to authenticate the extracted client credentials.

property.name: UserRegistry
property.summary: Specifies the API registry to authenticate the extracted client credentials.
property.description: The API registry to authenticate the extracted client credentials. The supported registries are API authentication URL and API LDAP.

property.name: Url
property.summary: The URL to be invoked.
property.description: Specifies the URL to be invoked. You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the <tt>$(api.properties.property_name)</tt> format, where <tt>property_name</tt> is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short <tt>$(property_name)</tt> format when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.
Specifies the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and the target URL.
property.summary: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and the target URL
property.name: SSLClient
Timeout
property.summary: The time to wait for a reply from the target
property.description: Specifies the duration in seconds to wait before the DataPower Gateway receives a reply from the target. The default value is 60.

property.name: UserName
property.summary: The user name for HTTP basic authentication
property.description: Specifies the user name to use for HTTP basic authentication.
Specifies the password alias of the user password to use for HTTP basic authentication.
property.summary: The password alias of the user password for HTTP basic authentication
property.name: Password
Method
property.summary: The HTTP method for the invocation
property.description: Specifies the HTTP method to use for the invocation.

property.name: BackendType
property.summary: The message type of backend payload
property.description: The message type of backend payload.

property.name: Compression
property.summary: Whether to enable HTTP compression.
property.description: Controls whether to enable HTTP compression.

property.name: CacheType
property.summary: How to cache documents
property.description: Controls how to cache documents. This property takes effect only when a response is received from the target. When it is set, the invoke action always returns the non-expired response that is previously saved in cache.

property.name: TimeToLive
property.summary: The validity period for documents in the cache.
property.description: Sets the validity period in seconds for documents in the cache. The default value is 900.

property.name: CacheUnsafeResponse
property.summary: Cache Response to POST and PUT Requests
property.display: Cache Response to POST and PUT Requests
property.description: Caches responses to POST and PUT requests when the cache policy type is set to time to live. The response to these requests is the result of an action on the server that might change its resource state. You might want to cache responses to these requests when you know that the action (for example: HTTP POST) will not change the server state.
The string to use as a key for the cache. If omitted, the entire URL string is used as the key.
property.summary: The string to use as a key for the cache.
property.name: CacheKey
FollowRedirects
property.summary: Whether to follow the redirects.
property.description: Some protocols generate redirects as part of the protocol; for example, an HTTP 304 response code. When enabled, the invoke action attempts to transparently resolve redirects.

property.name: UseHTTP10
property.summary: Restrict to HTTP 1.0
property.description: Controls whether to restrict HTTP transactions to version 1.0.

property.name: DoChunkedUpload
property.summary: Whether to enable uploading of HTTP 1.1 chunked-encoded documents
property.description: Controls the ability to send chunked-encoded documents to the target server. When the device employs the HTTP 1.1 protocol, the body of the document can be delimited by either <tt>Content-Length</tt> or chunked encoding. While all servers understand how to interpret <tt>Content-Length</tt> , many applications fail to understand chunked encoding. For this reason, <tt>Content-Length</tt> is the standard method used. However, the use of <tt>Content-Length</tt> interferes with the ability of the device to fully stream. To stream full documents to the target server, set this property to <tt>on</tt> . However, the target server must be RFC 2616 compatible. Unlike all other HTTP 1.1 features that can be negotiated down at run time, you must know beforehand that the target server is RFC 2616 compatible. The default value is <tt>on</tt> .

property.name: StopOnError
property.summary: Whether the flow stops when a particular type of error occurs
property.description: Controls whether the flow stops when a particular type of error occurs during the assembly execution.

property.name: ErrorTypes
property.summary: The type of error on which the flow stops
property.description: Specifies the type of error on which the flow stops. Use this property when the stop on error is enabled.

property.name: Output
property.summary: The name of a variable to store the invoke action output
property.description: Specifies the name of a variable to store the invoke action output. By default, the output is stored the <tt>message.body</tt> , <tt>message.headers</tt> , <tt>message.statuscode</tt> respectively.

property.name: DecodeRequestParams
property.summary: Whether to decode the request parameters
property.description: Controls whether to decode the request parameters that are referenced in the target URL. If set to on, request parameters are decoded. The default value is off.

property.name: EncodePlusChar
property.summary: Whether to encode plus characters in query strings
property.description: Controls whether to encode <tt>+</tt> characters in query strings. If set to on, <tt>+</tt> characters in the query parameter values of the target URL are encoded to <tt>%2F</tt> . The default value is off.

property.name: KeepPayload
property.summary: Whether to include the payload for DELETE requests
property.description: Controls whether to include the payload for DELETE requests. If set to on, the invoke action includes the payload for DELETE requests. The default value is off.

property.name: InjectUserAgentHeader
property.summary: Whether to inject the default User-Agent header
property.description: When the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header is not found in the incoming request, whether to inject it to the API request.

property.name: InjectProxyHeaders
property.summary: Whether to inject proxy-related headers
property.description: When the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> , <tt>X-Forwarded-Host</tt> , and <tt>X-Forwarded-Port</tt> headers are not found in the incoming request, whether to inject them to the API request.

property.name: HeaderControlList
property.summary: Whether to accept or reject based on headers
property.description: Indicates the control list that manages whether to accept or reject based on headers. The default behavior is to accept all headers.

property.name: ParameterControlList
property.summary: Whether to accept or reject based on URL parameters
property.description: Indicates the control list that manages whether to accept or reject based on URL parameters. The default behavior is to reject all URL parameters.

property.name: JWT
property.summary: The variable to store the generated JWT
property.description: Specifies the variable to store the generated JWT. The default value is <tt>generated.jwt</tt> . When the variable is not set, the generated JWT is written to the Authorization Header as a Bearer token.

property.name: JWTIDClaims
property.summary: Whether to add a JWT ID claim to the JWT
property.description: Controls whether to add a JWT ID (jti) claim to the JWT. When enabled, a UUID is generated and set as the value of the JWT ID claim.

property.name: IssuerClaim
property.summary: Where to retrieve the Issuer claim value
property.description: Specifies the variable from which to retrieve the Issuer (iss) claim value. The default value is <tt>iss.claim</tt> . The maximum length is 256 characters.

property.name: SubjectClaim
property.summary: Where to retrieve the Subject claim value
property.description: Specifies the variable from which to retrieve the Subject (sub) claim value. The maximum length is 256 characters.

property.name: AudienceClaim
property.summary: Where to retrieve the Audience claim value
property.description: Specifies the variable from which to retrieve the Audience (aud) claim value. The maximum length is 256 characters. The value of this variable can be a single string, a comma-separated string of values, or an array of one or more values when you set the variable with GatewayScript.

property.name: ValidityPeriod
property.summary: The validity period for calculating the expiration (exp) claim
property.description: Specifies the length of time, that is added to the current date and time, in which the JWT is considered valid. Enter a value in the range 1 - 31622400. The default value is 3600.

property.name: PrivateClaim
property.summary: Where to retrieve the private claim value
property.description: Specifies the variable from which to retrieve a valid set of JSON claims. These claims are added to any set of claims that are specified previously.
Specifies the context variable that contains the JWK to use to sign the JWT.
property.summary: The context variable that contains the JWK to sign the JWT
property.name: SignJWK

property.description: <p>The cryptographic algorithm to use. Use one of the following values.</p><ul><li><tt>HS256</tt> - HMAC using SHA-256</li><li><tt>HS384</tt> - HMAC using SHA-384</li><li><tt>HS512</tt> - HMAC using SHA-512</li><li><tt>RS256</tt> - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256</li><li><tt>RS384</tt> - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA 384</li><li><tt>RS512</tt> - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-512</li><li><tt>ES256</tt> - ECDSA using P-256 and SHA-256</li><li><tt>ES384</tt> - ECDSA using P-384 and SHA-384</li><li><tt>ES512</tt> - ECDSA using P-521 and SHA-512</li><li><tt>none</tt> - Do not sign the JWT, which is unsecured and provides no integrity protection but can be used for a nest JWT</li><li>An inline parameter to read at runtime</li></ul>
property.summary: The cryptographic algorithm to use
property.name: CryptoAlgorithm

property.description: Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to sign the JWT.
property.summary: The cryptographic object to sign the JWT
property.name: SignCrypto

property.description: <p>The encryption algorithm to use. Use one of the following values.</p><ul><li><tt>A128CBC-HS256</tt> - AES_128_CBC_HMAC_SHA_256 authenticated encryption algorithm</li><li><tt>A192CBC-HS384</tt> - AES_192_CBC_HMAC_SHA_384 authenticated encryption algorithm</li><li><tt>A256CBC-HS512</tt> - AES_256_CBC_HMAC_SHA_512 authenticated encryption algorithm</li><li><tt>A128GCM</tt> - AES GCM using 128-bit key</li><li><tt>A192GCM</tt> - AES GCM using 192-bit key</li><li><tt>A256GCM</tt> - AES GCM using 256-bit key</li><li>An inline parameter to read at runtime</li></ul>
property.summary: The encryption algorithm to use
property.name: EncryptAlgorithm

property.description: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWK to use to encrypt the JWT.
property.summary: The context variable that contains the JWK to encrypt the JWT
property.name: EncryptJWK

property.description: <p>The key encryption algorithm to use. Use one of the following values.</p><ul><li><tt>RSA1_5</tt> - RSAES-PKCS1-V1_5</li><li><tt>RSA-OAEP</tt> - RSAES OAEP using default parameters</li><li><tt>RSA-OAEP-256</tt> - RSAES OAEP using SHA-256 and MGF1 with SHA-256</li><li><tt>A128KW</tt> - AES Key Wrap with default initial value using 128 bit key</li><li><tt>A192KW</tt> - AES Key Wrap with default initial value using 192 bit key</li><li><tt>A256KW</tt> - AES Key Wrap with default initial value using 256 bit key</li><li><tt>dir</tt> - Direct use of a shared symmetric key as the CEK</li><li>An inline parameter to read at runtime</li></ul>
property.summary: The key encryption algorithm to use
property.display: Key encrypt algorithm for JWT encryption
property.name: KeyEncryptAlgorithm

property.description: Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to encrypt the JWT.

property.name: JWT
property.summary: The context variable that contains the JSON Web Token (JWT) to be validated
property.description: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWT to be validated. The default value is <tt>request.headers.authorization</tt> . The format of the authorization header must be <tt>Authorization: Bearer jwt-token</tt> where <tt>jwt-token</tt> indicates the encoded JWT.

property.name: OutputClaims
property.summary: The context variable to store all the claims that the JWT contains
property.description: Specifies a context variable to store all the claims that the JWT contains when the validation of the JWT succeeds. The default value is <tt>decoded.claims</tt> .

property.name: IssuerClaim
property.summary: PCRE to use to validate the issuer claim
property.description: Specifies the optional PCRE to use to validate the issuer "iss" claim. When specified, the issuer claim in the JWT is validated. If the issuer claim fails, the JWT validation fails. The maximum length of the value is 256 characters.

property.name: AudienceClaim
property.summary: PCRE to use to validate the audience claim
property.description: Specifies the optional PCRE to use to validate the audience "aud" claim. When specified, the audience claim in the JWT is validated. If the audience claim fails, the JWT validation fails. The maximum length of the value is 256 characters.
Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to decrypt the JWT.
property.summary: The cryptographic object to decrypt the JWT
property.name: DecryptCrypto

property.description: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWK to use to decrypt the JWT.
property.summary: The context variable that contains the JWK to decrypt the JWT
property.name: DecryptJWK

property.description: Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to verify the JWT.
property.summary: The cryptographic object to verify the JWT
property.name: VerifyCrypto

property.description: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWK to use to verify the JWT.
property.summary: The context variable that contains the JWK to verify the JWT
property.name: VerifyJWK

object.description: <p>The validate JSON Web Token (JWT) action specifies credentials and methods to validate a JWT in the request. The following guidelines apply. <ul><li>All claims that are specified in the validate JWT action are validated. If any specified claim fails, the JWT validation fails.</li><li>You can use a cryptographic object or a JWK to decrypt or verify the JWT. When both are specified, the cryptographic object is used.</li><li>If the original message is signed with a shared secret key, the cryptographic object that is specified must also be a shared secret key.</li><li>If the original message is signed with a private key, the cryptographic object that is specified must be a crypto certificate (public certificate).</li><li>If a JWK header parameter is included in the header of the JWT, the parameter must match the cryptographic object or JWK that is specified in the action. Otherwise, the JWT validation fails.</li></ul></p>

property.description: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context that contains the input message to convert. The content of the <tt>body</tt> field is the input. The default variable is <tt>message</tt> , so the input to convert is <tt>message.body</tt> .

Specifies the name of a variable in the API context to store the conversion results. The conversion results are written to the <tt>body</tt> field of the specified variable. The output variable cannot be a read-only variable. <ul><li>When you want the converted output to be returned to the client, you must use <tt>message</tt> as the output variable.</li><li>When you do not specify an output variable, the variable name matches the input variable name. For example, if the input variable is <tt>message</tt> , the output variable is also <tt>message</tt> . Therefore, if the input variable is <tt>foo</tt> , the output variable is also <tt>foo</tt> .</li><li>When you use an output variable other than <tt>message</tt> , the content is converted but not returned to the client.</li></ul>

For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.
property.summary: The path which correlates the assembly action to a specific part of the API specification.
property.name: CorrelationPath
ActionDebug
property.summary: Whether to enable GatewayScript debugger in assembly actions
property.description: <p>Controls whether to enable the GatewayScript debugger to troubleshoot the following GatewayScript file or script. <ul><li>Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is called from the assembly GatewayScript action.</li><li>Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is invoked by the GatewayScript associated XSLT extension functions or elements, such as the <tt>gatewayscript()</tt> extension function, from the assembly XSLT action.</li><li>Troubleshoot the GatewayScript script that is invoked through the <tt>value</tt> or the <tt>default</tt> property in the JSON file from the assembly map action.</li></ul></p><p>To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met:</p><ul><li>The file contains one or more <tt>debugger;</tt> statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging.</li><li>The GatewayScript debugger is enabled.</li></ul><p>Then you can run the <tt>debug-action</tt> command to debug.</p>

property.name: Mode
property.summary: Mode to use for the assembly log action
property.description: <p>Specifies the mode to use for the assembly log action.</p><p>Analytics data must strictly conform to the format required by your analytics server. If you are using the IBM API Connect analytics server without offloading data to a third-party log server, the format is set correctly by default. Input and output payloads can be redacted, but the data format must not be modified. In this case, you must use gather only mode.</p>

object.description: <p>An assembly log action writes transaction data to the API context to send to the analytics server. The API activity logging settings specified in the API definition determine the type of transaction data that is gathered.</p><p>This action is not supported in IBM Cloud. Any assembly that includes it will fail.</p>

property.name: Location

object.description: <p>A map action applies data transformations to the assembly flow according to a specified map file. The map file is a JSON file that defines all mapping operations.</p><p>Prepare a valid map file as follows: <ol><li>If you do not get the map file automatically, you need to create the map file manually. See the reference information about map file examples on IBM API Connect Knowledge center.</li><li>Make sure that the map file is JSON formatted. If the map file is YAML formatted, convert it to JSON format.</li><li>Import the JSON file to the DataPower Gateway. The file must be in the <tt>local:///</tt> directory, the <tt>temporary:///</tt> directory, or one of their subdirectories.</li></ol></p>

property.description: Specifies a URL to a file that contains serialized XML or JSON properties to be merged into the dynamic object. These properties override any existing literal or default properties. The URL can contain variable references, and fields within the associated file can also contain variable references.

A parse settings configuration defines the constraints on the documents to parse. You can configure the constraints by specifying a URL reference from which to retrieve the constraints definition. You can also specify a literal configuration string in XML management interface or REST management interface format that contains the constraints definition. You can also select a parse settings configuration from the list in Object reference to retrieve constraints definition. Precedence rules apply when the constraint for the same aspect of an input document is configured with more than one method.
property.summary: Specifies the parse settings configuration for the parse action
property.name: ParseSettingsReference
Input
property.summary: The name of a variable in the API context. Data represented by the variable can be parsed.
property.description: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the <tt>body</tt> field of the variable is the input to the parse action. The default variable name is <tt>message</tt> .

property.name: WarnOnEmptyInput
property.summary: Whether to generate a warning-level log message instead of an error when the payload of the input message is empty.
property.description: Specifies whether to generate a warning-level log message instead of an error when the payload of the input message is empty.

property.name: UseContentType
property.summary: Whether to attempt a parse with the specified content-type
property.description: Specifies whether to attempt a parse with the specified content-type. This is only applicable if the expected content-type is either json or xml. With this option enabled, a parse action will result in failure if content-type does not match the parse-settings (i.e Content-type:application/json and parse-settings is configured for xml). If the parse-setting is configured to detect input content, it will be forced to the specified content-type.

Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the <tt>body</tt> field of the variable represents the parse result. The parse metrics of the parsed document can be stored in different parts of the message. The default variable name is the same as that of the variable specified in the <tt>Input message</tt> property. Therefore, by default, the input message for parsing is overwritten by the output message.
property.summary: The name of a variable in the API context where the result of parsed data is stored.

object.description: You use the parse action to parse a request or a message as XML or JSON, or parse binary data into a binary large object (BLOB).

property.name: Action
Name
property.summary: The variable name
property.description: Specifies the name of the variable that you want to set, add, or clear. You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the $(api.properties.property_name) format, where <tt>property_name</tt> is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short form $(property_name) when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.

property.name: Type
property.summary: The data type of the variable
property.description: Specifies the data type of the variable that you want to set or add.

property.name: Value
property.summary: The value of the variable
property.description: <p>Specifies the value of the variable that you want to set or add. You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the $(api.properties.property_name) format, where <tt>property_name</tt> is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short form $(property_name) when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.</p><p>When you assign value to the variable, follow these rules. Otherwise, error occurs and the current set variable action is terminated. <ul><li>The value must match the specified data type: number, string, or Boolean.</li><li>When you assign value to the <tt>message.status.code</tt> variable, the value must be a valid HTTP status code.</li></ul></p>

value.description: <p>Indicates that you can set a variable. This is the default value.</p><ul><li>When the specified variable does not exist, a new variable is added with assigned value.</li><li>When the specified variable exists and it is not read-only, the assigned value overrides the existing value.</li></ul>
value.name: set

value.description: Indicates that you can add a variable. For example, this can be used to add new headers or to append a new entry of the same header. Note: You cannot add the <tt>message.status.code</tt> , <tt>message.status.reason</tt> , <tt>policy.gatewayscript.enableDebugger</tt> , <tt>error.message</tt> , <tt>message.body</tt> , or <tt>request.body</tt> variable. Instead, you can set it. For details about these variables, see the Variables in the API context topic.
value.name: add

value.description: Indicates that you can delete a variable. For example, this can be used to remove a header when the data is processed in the assembly flow.
value.name: clear

value.description: Read the variable value as-is. This is the default value.
value.name: any

value.description: Treat the variable value as a string.
value.name: string

value.description: Treat the variable value as a number.
value.name: number

value.description: Treat the variable value as a boolean and the value can be <tt>true</tt> or <tt>false</tt> .
value.name: boolean

property.description: <p>Controls whether to enable the GatewayScript debugger to troubleshoot the following GatewayScript file or script. <ul><li>Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is called from the assembly GatewayScript action.</li><li>Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is invoked by the GatewayScript associated XSLT extension functions or elements, such as the <tt>gatewayscript()</tt> extension function, from the assembly XSLT action.</li><li>Troubleshoot the GatewayScript script that is invoked through the <tt>value</tt> or the <tt>default</tt> property in the JSON file from the assembly map action.</li></ul></p><p>To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met:</p><ul><li>The file contains one or more <tt>debugger;</tt> statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging.</li><li>The GatewayScript debugger is enabled.</li></ul><p>Then you can run the <tt>debug-action</tt> command to debug.</p>

property.name: ErrorID
property.summary: The identifier of the error
property.description: <p>Specifies the identifier of the thrown error. The identifier contains a maximum of 64 characters. The following characters are valid: <ul><li>a - z</li><li>A - Z</li><li>0 - 9</li><li>Underscore(_)</li><li>Dash(-)</li></ul></p><p>You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the $(api.properties.property_name) format, where <tt>property_name</tt> is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short form $(property_name) when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.</p>

Specifies the text for the error message. You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the $(api.properties.property_name) format, where <tt>property_name</tt> is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short form $(property_name) when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.
property.summary: The text for the error message
property.name: ErrorText

object.description: You can customize an error in the throw action. When the throw action is triggered, the custom error is thrown. After the throw action is triggered, the API Gateway does not run subsequent assembly actions and the current assembly rule is ended. The thrown error, including the error identifier and text for the error message, is saved in the API context.
