Metric
property.summary: Preference for the route
property.description: <p>Optionally specify the preference for the route. The lesser the value, the greater the preference. For each IP family, the supported range differs.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 0.</li><li>For IPv6, enter a value in the range 0 - 65536. The default value is 512.</li></ul>

value.description: The weighted least connection algorithm uses an internal CPU-based weight with the number of current connections to each member to distribute incoming connections among available member. A member receives a new connection that is based on a combination of its weight (or preference) and its number of active connections. The algorithm attempts to balance the connection completion rate across members so that each member has the same number of active connections.
value.name: wlc

value.description: The round robin algorithm maintains a list of members and evenly distributes incoming connections among available members. The algorithm attempts to balance the incoming connection rate across members.
value.name: rr

value.description: For interfaces that do autonegotiation, performs standard IEEE 802.3 autonegotiation for interface speed and direction. Preference is given to the highest speed. Preference is for full-duplex over half-duplex.
value.name: Auto

value.description: Advertises 10000BASE-T PHY (10 Gbps) in full-duplex mode.
value.name: 10000baseTx-FD

value.description: Advertises 1000BASE-T PHY (1 Gbps) in full-duplex mode.
value.name: 1000baseTx-FD

value.description: Advertises 100BASE-TX PHY (100 Mbps) in full-duplex mode.
value.name: 100baseTx-FD

value.description: Advertises 100BASE-TX PHY (100 Mbps) in half-duplex mode.
value.name: 100baseTx-HD

value.description: Advertises 10BASE-T PHY (10 Mbps) in full-duplex mode.
value.name: 10baseT-FD

value.description: Advertises 10BASE-T PHY (10 Mbps) in half-duplex mode.
value.name: 10baseT-HD

value.description: For interfaces that support autonegotiation, performs standard IEEE 802.3 autonegotiation for flow control.
value.name: auto

value.description: Disables flow control. The interface does not send flow control PAUSE frames and ignores received PAUSE frames. Use this value only when IBM support diagnosed that you are encountering a problem.
value.name: disabled

object.name: EthernetInterface

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>
A descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.name: UserSummary
IPConfigMode
property.summary: Set the configuration mode for the interface.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the configuration mode for the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.</p><ul><li>With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface.</li><li>With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li><li>With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The configuration mode of the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.</p><ul><li>With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface. <ul><li>Assign the primary network address.</li><li>Manage secondary, or auxiliary, network addresses.</li><li>Assign the default IPv4 gateway.</li><li>Assign the default IPv6 gateway, if you define IPv6 IP addresses.</li><li>Manage static routes in the routing table.</li></ul></li><li>With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li><li>With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li></ul>

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: Set the primary IP address and netmask.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>

property.name: DefaultGateway
property.summary: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway.
property.hoverhelp: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.
property.description: The IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.

property.name: DefaultIPv6Gateway
property.summary: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway.
property.hoverhelp: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway.
property.description: The IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway. If you do not use IPv6 network addresses, do not define this property.

property.name: SecondaryAddress
property.summary: Set secondary IP addresses and netmasks.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the IP address and netmask of the secondary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The IP addresses and netmasks of secondary IP addresses. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>

property.name: StaticRoutes
property.summary: Manage the static routes in the routing table.
property.hoverhelp: Manage the static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network.
property.description: The static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network. When the appliance connects to a remote address, the static route with the longest prefix match is used. If multiple routes have the same prefix match, the static route with the lowest metric is used. If the metric is the same, the static route is chosen randomly.

property.name: DADTransmits
property.summary: Set the number of IPv6 duplication address detection attempts.
property.description: The number of IPv6 duplication address detection (DAD) attempts. The default value is 1.

property.name: DADRetransmitTimer
property.summary: Set the delay between IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) attempts.
property.hoverhelp: Set the delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.
property.description: The delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. The default value is 1000. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.

property.name: StandbyControl
property.summary: Indicate whether to allow a standby configuration.
property.description: <p>Whether to allow a standby configuration. The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: Group
property.summary: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.
property.description: <p>The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP).</p><p>The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration.</p><ul><li>Belong to the same group.</li><li>Use the same primary virtual IP address.</li><li>Use the same authentication, or security token.</li></ul>

property.name: VirtualIP
property.summary: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.
property.description: <p>The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: SecondaryVirtualIP
property.summary: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.
property.description: <p>Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: Preempt
property.summary: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group. <b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>
property.description: <p>Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure.</p><ul><li>When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member.</li><li>When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member.</li></ul><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>

property.name: Priority
property.summary: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.
property.description: <p>The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.</p><p>For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.</p>

property.name: SelfBalance
property.summary: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul><p>The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint.</p><ul><li>In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause.</li><li>In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.</li></ul>

property.name: Authentication
property.summary: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: Set the authentication string, or security token in hex. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.
property.description: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

property.name: HelloTimer
property.summary: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages
property.hoverhelp: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40.
property.description: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.

property.name: HoldTimer
property.summary: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.
property.hoverhelp: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120.
property.description: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.

property.name: DistAlg
property.summary: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.
property.description: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.

property.name: LinkAggMode
property.summary: Indicate whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface. When part of a link aggregation interface, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.
property.description: Whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface. When part of a link aggregation interface, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.

property.name: MTU
property.summary: Set the maximum transmission unit for the Ethernet interface.
property.hoverhelp: Set the maximum transmission unit for the Ethernet interface. Set the value to greater than 1500 bytes only when you know that all other interfaces on this network are similarly configured. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128.
property.description: <p>The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the Ethernet interface. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation. Set the value greater than 1500 bytes only when you know that all other interfaces on this network are similarly configured. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500.</p><ul><li>When the Ethernet interface is part of a VLAN interface, the MTU of the VLAN interface cannot be greater than the MTU for the Ethernet interface The appliance adds 4 bytes when a VLAN interface is enabled on this interface.</li><li>When the Ethernet interface is part of a link aggregation interface, the MTU of the aggregate interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface.</li></ul>

property.name: MACAddress
property.summary: Override the assigned 48-bit MAC address.
property.hoverhelp: Override the assigned 48-bit MAC address. By default, the appliance uses the burned-in MAC address from the network interface controller. Enter a 48-bit hex MAC address in the 00:12:34:56:78:9c format. The value must be a unicast address, where the first byte must be even.
property.description: The MAC address of the Ethernet interface. By default, the appliance uses the burned-in MAC address from the network interface controller that was assigned when the system was manufactured. Enter a 48-bit hex MAC address in the 00:12:34:56:78:9c format. The value must be a unicast address, where the first byte must be even.

property.name: Mode
property.summary: Set the Ethernet physical mode.
property.hoverhelp: Set the Ethernet physical mode. Use this property to set speed and direction explicitly when your networking equipment does not negotiate properly.
property.description: The phyical mode is the interface speed and direction of the Ethernet unshielded twisted pair physical (PHY) layer. Use this property to set speed and direction explicitly when your networking equipment does not negotiate properly. If you manually configure one end of the link, you must manually configure the other end of the link to the same setting.

property.name: ForceMode
property.summary: Indicate whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior. Enable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.
property.description: Whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior. By default, this option is disabled, which means that autonegotiation is used. When this option is enabled, the physical mode is forced, and there is no autonegotiation performed at the Ethernet driver level. Enable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

property.name: HardwareOffload
property.summary: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.
property.description: <p>Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled.</p><ul><li>When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of Ethernet device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance.</li><li>When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.</li></ul><p>If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.</p>

property.name: FlowControl
property.summary: Set the flow control mode.
property.hoverhelp: Set the flow control mode. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.
property.description: The flow control mode of the Ethernet interface. The default value is <b>Auto</b>. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

object.description: Configure and manage Ethernet interfaces.

object.name: FTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: TargetDirectory
property.label: Target directory
property.summary: The directory to poll.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the path of the directory to poll. For example: 'ftp://user:password@host:port/path/'. If the user name or password contains colon (;), at symbol (@), or slash (/), use their URL-encoded values instead. The path must end with a slash.
property.description: <p>Specify the directory to poll. The path must end in a slash. The path denotes a directory.</p><ul><li>FTP examples: <ul><li>Absolute to the root directory: <tt>"ftp://user:password@host:port/%2Fpath/"</tt><p>If the user name or password contains the characters colon (:), at symbol (@), or slash (/), use their URL-encoded values in accordance with the specification.</p></li><li>Relative to the home directory of the user: <tt>"ftp://user:password@host:port/path/"</tt></li></ul><p>Include a password in the URL with caution. The use of user:/password@host results in a server connection. However, with this configuration, the connection could be unable to send multiple commands to the FTP server. For a stable connection, define a basic authentication policy in the user agent. The user agent is in the XML manager associated with the DataPower service.</p></li><li>NFS example: <ul><li><tt>"dpnfs://static-mount-name/path/"</tt></li></ul></li><li>SFTP examples: <ul><li>Absolute to the root directory: <tt>"sftp://host:port/path/"</tt></li><li>Relative to the home directory of the user: <tt>"sftp://host:port/~/path/"</tt></li></ul></li></ul><p>Do not configure one poller to point at a host name that is a virtual name of a load balancer group. This configuration is not the correct way to poll multiple hosts. To poll multiple hosts, use the same DataPower service and configure one poller object for each real host.</p>

property.name: DelayBetweenPolls
property.summary: Interval between polling sequences
property.description: <p>Enter the number of milliseconds to wait after the completion of one poll sequence before starting the next one. A <em>polling sequence</em> is the actual polling action plus the time to complete all transactions that were started by the poll action. The next polling action will start the specified number of milliseconds after the last transaction completes.</p><p>Enter any value of 25 - 100000000. The default is 60000.</p>

property.name: InputFileMatchPattern
property.label: Input file match pattern
property.summary: File name pattern to base poll search criteria.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the Perl Compatible Regular Expressions (PCRE) to use to match the contents of the directory that is polled. If there is file-renaming or there is a response, this PCRE must create PCRE back references using () pairs. For example, if the input files are NNNNNN.input , the match pattern would be '([0-9]{6})\.input$' .
property.description: <p>Enter the PCRE to use to match the contents of the directory being polled. If there is file-renaming or there is a response, this PCRE must create PCRE back references using () pairs.</p><p>For example, if the input files are <tt>NNNNNN.input</tt> , the match pattern would be <tt>"([0-9]{6})\.input$"</tt> .</p>

<p>Enter the PCRE to use to rename a file that is being processed. This functionality allows multiple pollers to poll the same directory with the same match pattern. There is no lack of atomicity if the rename operation on the server is atomic. The poller that succeeds in renaming the input file will proceed to process the file. Any other poller that tries to rename the file at the same time will fail to rename the file and will proceed to try the next file that matches the specified match pattern.</p><p>To ensure uniqueness, the resulting file name will be in the following format:</p><p><em>filename</em> . <em>hostname</em> . <em>serial</em> . <em>domain</em> . <em>poller</em> . <em>timestamp</em></p><p><dl><dt><em>filename</em></dt><dd>The file name for the renamed input file.</dd><dt><em>hostname</em></dt><dd>The hostname (system identifier) of the configured DataPower device.</dd><dt><em>serial</em></dt><dd>The serial number of the configured DataPower device.</dd><dt><em>domain</em></dt><dd>The domain of the polling object.</dd><dt><em>poller</em></dt><dd>The name of the polling object.</dd><dt><em>timestamp</em></dt><dd>The timestamp</dd></dl></p><p><b>Note:</b> File renaming cannot be used with an FTP server that supports only 8.3 file names.</p><p>For example if the input files are <tt>NNNNNN.input</tt> and you want to rename them to <tt>NNNNNN.processing</tt> , then the match pattern would be <tt>"([0-9]{6})\.input$"</tt> and the processing pattern would be <tt>"$1.processing"</tt> . The resultant file name on the server would be:</p><p><tt>NNNNNN.processing. <em>hostname</em> . <em>serial</em> . <em>domain</em> . <em>poller</em> . <em>timestamp</em></tt></p><p><b>Note:</b> If no processing rename pattern is configured, the file will still be renamed. The only difference is that the <em>filename</em> portion of the resulting file is the name of the original input file, not the renamed input file.</p>
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that is being processed.
property.name: ProcessingRenamePattern
DeleteOnSuccess
property.summary: Delete an input file after successful processing.
property.description: <p>Select whether to delete the input file after successful processing.</p><ul><li>When enabled, deletes the input file.</li><li>When not enabled, renames the input file using the renaming pattern specified by Success File Renaming Pattern.</li></ul>

property.name: SuccessRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that has been processed successfully.
property.description: <p>When Delete File on Success is off, enter the PCRE to use to rename the input file on success. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are <tt>NNNNNN.input</tt> and you want to rename them to <tt>NNNNNN.processed</tt> , the match pattern would be <tt>"([0-9]{6})\.input$"</tt> and the rename pattern would be <tt>"$1.processed"</tt> .</p><p>Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be <tt>"(.*)"</tt> and the rename pattern would be <tt>"../processed/$1"</tt> .</p>

property.name: DeleteOnError
property.summary: Delete a file after failure to process.
property.description: <p>Select whether to delete the input or processing rename file when it could not be processed.</p><ul><li>When enabled, deletes the file.</li><li>When not enabled, renames the input or processing rename file using the renaming pattern specified by Error File Renaming Pattern.</li></ul>

property.name: ErrorRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that could not be processed.
property.description: When Delete File on Processing Error is not enabled, enter the PCRE to use to rename a file when it could not be processed.

property.name: GenerateResultFile
property.summary: Create a result file after processing an input file.
property.description: <p>Select whether to create a result file after processing an input file.</p><ul><li>When enabled, creates the result file using the naming pattern specified by Result File Name Pattern.</li><li>When not enabled, does not create the result file.</li></ul>

property.name: ResultNamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to build the name of a response file.
property.description: <p>When Generate Result File is on, enter the PCRE to use as the match pattern to build the name of the result file. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are <tt>NNNNNN.input</tt> and the desired result file name is <tt>NNNNNN.result</tt> , then the match pattern would be <tt>"([0-9]{6})\.input$"</tt> and the result pattern would be <tt>"$1.result"</tt> .</p><p>Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be <tt>"(.*)"</tt> and the result pattern would be <tt>"../result/$1"</tt> .</p>

property.name: ProcessingSeizeTimeout
property.summary: Time to wait to process a file that is in the processing state.
property.description: <p>Enter the time to wait before processing a file that is already in the processing state. Enter any value of 0 - 1000. The default is 0, which means not enabled.</p><p>Processing seizure allows failure handling of a poller when more than one poller polls the same target. If another poller renames a file and does not process and rename or delete it in the specified time, another poller can take over processing. A poller attempts to take over processing when the following conditions are met when compared to the processing seize pattern.</p><ol><li>The seize pattern includes the portion of the file name with the configured processing suffix to match.</li><li>The time stamp is further in the past than the wait time specified by the timeout.</li></ol><p>When these conditions are met, another poller renames the file with a fresh time stamp and processes the file. The processing assumes that the rename operation succeeded.</p>

property.name: ProcessingSeizePattern
property.summary: PCRE to find files that were renamed to indicate that they are in the "being processed" state but the processing never completed.
property.description: <p>Enter the PCRE to find files that were renamed to indicate that they are in the "being processed" state but the processing was never completed.</p><p>The seize pattern contains two phrases. The first phrase is the portion of the file name with the configured processing suffix. The second phrase is the time stamp.</p><p>For example: <tt>(.*.processing).*[.*]([0-9]*)</tt> . This assumes that <tt>$1.processing</tt> was supplied as the renaming pattern.</p>

property.name: XMLManager
property.summary: An XML manager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets and documents. The XML Manager can also control the size and depth of messages processed by this host. Specify an existing XML Manager. More than one service may use the same XML Manager.

property.name: MaxTransfersPerPoll
property.summary: Maximum number of files to be transferred during each cycle of the poller connection
property.display: Maximum File Transfers Per Poll Cycle
property.description: <p>The number of allowed concurrent client connections in a polling sequence.</p><p>Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The value must be less than the number of simultaneous connections that the polled server accepts. The default value is 0 which means unlimited number of connections based on available system resources. To avoid the consumption of all the systems resources, enter a value other than 0.</p>

object.description: Use this front side option to have file based input from a configured FTP directory. The directory must exist and have the appropriate permission to perform the designated operations. For these configured directories, ensure that the read, write, and delete permissions are available, as required.

property.description: The command to send to the remote FTP server. The command must not be one that would create an FTP data connection. Normally this will be a SITE command. This command must return a result code in the 200 series.
property.summary: Quoted Command
property.name: QuotedCommand

object.name: FTPQuoteCommands

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: FTPQuotedCommands
property.summary: Quoted Commands
property.description: The list of commands to send to the remote FTP server.

object.description: The configturation creates a named list of FTP commands to be quoted to a remote FTP server before a file transfer. These commands are referenced by the FTP Policies section of a User Agent configuration.

value.description: The FTP server will have an ephemeral virtual file system with subdirectories created by configuration. The contents of this file system are private to an individual FTP control connection to the FTP server. The contents of this file system will not persist after this FTP control connection ends.
value.name: virtual-ephemeral

value.description: The FTP server will have a persistent virtual file system with subdirectories created by configuration. The contents of this file system are shared by all FTP control connections to this FTP server with the same authenticated user identity. The user identity is determined by the FTP user name and, if used, by the TLS certificate. The contents of this file system will persist after all FTP control connections end for a duration defined by Persistent Filesystem Timeout. This mode is required to support checkpoint/restart using the REST command.
value.name: virtual-persistent

value.description: The FTP server has a transparent file system. The files and directories shown are those on the back end of the associated DataPower service.
value.name: transparent

property.description: Enter the directory in the virtual file system of the FTP server where the FTP client can find this directory.
property.summary: Directory in virtual file system of the FTP server
property.name: VirtualPath

property.description: Enter the directory in the virtual file system of the FTP server where the responses to files that are stored in this directory will go.
property.summary: Virtual directory in which to put responses
property.name: ResponseDirectory

value.description: Allows, but does not require, the FTP client to use the PASV command to open data connections to the FTP server.
value.name: allow

value.description: Does not allow the FTP client to use the PASV command to open data connections to the FTP server. The FTP server will open all data connections to the FTP client (as directed by the FTP PORT command). This mode is not always compatible with firewalls.
value.name: disallow

value.description: Requires the FTP client to use the PASV command to open all data connections with the FTP server. This mode is useful when the FTP server is behind a firewall device that requires clients to use passive mode.
value.name: require

value.description: Does not allow the FTP client to encrypt data connections.
value.name: disallow

value.description: Allows, but does not require, the FTP client to encrypt data connections. TLS must be allowed on data connections.
value.name: allow

value.description: Requires the FTP client to encrypt data connections. TLS should be required on data connections.
value.name: require

value.description: Indicates that no response is made available to the client. Any response from the backend server is dropped.
value.name: none

value.description: Indicates that the response is made available as a file in the virtual file system that can be read by the FTP client. The directory for responses is configured on a per-virtual directory basis. The suffix specified by Response Suffix is added to the input file name and stored in the directory specified by Response Storage.
value.name: virtual-filesystem

value.description: Stores response files in temporary storage on the system. This storage has limited size. Using temporary storage reduces the available system storage for processing. Temporary storage should not be used when using a virtual persistent file system. In virtual persistent file systems, it is highly unlikely that there would be enough space. After a system restart or power cycle, response files are not available.
value.name: temporary

value.description: Stores response files on the top level directory of the specified NFS server. Only the NFS server limits the storage space.
value.name: nfs

object.name: FTPServerSourceProtocolHandler

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.label: IP address
property.summary: Local IP address
property.hoverhelp: Enter the IP address to listen on for incoming FTP server traffic. The default value 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service listens on all IP addresses.
property.description: <p>Enter the address on which the FTP server service listens. The default of 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases can help ease migration tasks among machines. If the FTP server service is listening on a virtual IP address managed by a standby control group with the self-balancing feature enabled, incoming control and data connections will always go to the active member of the standby control group.</p>

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Local TCP port for the FTP server
property.label: Port
property.hoverhelp: Enter the port number to listen on for incoming FTP server traffic. Specify a number in the range of 1 - 65535. The default value is 21.
property.description: <p>Enter the port that is monitored by the FTP Server service. This port is the port on which FTP control connections can be established. This port does not control the TCP port that is used for the data connections. If the FTP client uses the <tt>PASV</tt> command, data connections will use an arbitrary, unused TCP port. Defaults to 21. Valid range is 1 through 65535.</p>

property.name: FilesystemType
property.summary: The type of filesystem the FTP server will present
property.description: <p>Select the file system type that is presented by the FTP server.</p><ul><li>If Virtual Ephemeral or Virtual Persistent is chosen, the client can write files to all directories. These files are shown in directory listings but cannot be retrieved. For file system responses, the responses are shown and can be retrieved, renamed, and deleted by the client.</li><li>If Transparent is chosen, the file system shows the contents of the equivalent path of the server on the back-end of the DataPower service with which this FTP server is associated.</li></ul><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: PersistentFilesystemTimeout
property.summary: Controls how long a Virtual Persistent file system with no active connections is retained
property.description: Enter the duration in seconds that a connection to a virtual file system is retained after all FTP control connections from user identities are disconnected. When the timeout expires, the virtual file system object is destroyed. All of the response files that were not deleted by the FTP client are deleted from their storage area. Default to 600 (10 minutes). Valid range is 1 to 43,200 seconds (12 hours).

property.name: VirtualDirectories
property.summary: Create directory in virtual file system of FTP server
property.description: In virtual mode, create a directory in the virtual file system that is presented by this FTP server. The FTP client can use all of these directories to write file to be processed. The root directory (/) is always present and cannot be created. Its response directory is always the root directory.

property.name: DefaultDirectory
property.summary: Default for current working directory
property.description: Enter the initial working directory on the FTP server (after users connect and authenticate). When using a virtual file system and the working directory is not the root directory, the specified directory must be one of the configured virtual directories. The default is the root directory (/).

property.name: MaxFilenameLength
property.summary: Maximum length of a file name on the server
property.description: Enter the maximum file name length on the FTP server. Defaults to 256 characters. Valid range is 1 through 4000.

Select an Access Control List to apply. The ACL allows or denies access to the FTP server based on the IP address of the FTP client. When attached to a server, the default for an ACL is to deny all access. To deny access to only select IP addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0). Then, create deny entries for the desired hosts.
property.name: ACL
RequireTLS
property.summary: Control whether FTP control connections require TLS encryption
property.description: <p>Specify whether FTP control connections require explicit TLS encryption. If required, the following rules apply: <ul><li>The FTP client must use the FTP <tt>AUTH TLS</tt> command before any other command.</li><li>You must specify a TLS profile to secure connections.</li></ul></p><p>This property does not control encryption of data transfers.</p>

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile.
property.description: The TLS proxy profile references the required cryptographic configurations for the secure connection.

<p>Selects the AAA Policy to perform authentication of user names and passwords provided to the FTP server by the client with the <tt>USER</tt> and <tt>PASS</tt> commands. If the authentication succeeds, the FTP client may use all the features of the FTP server. If the authentication fails, a 530 error is returned, and the user can attempt to authenticate again. Without this AAA Policy configured, any user name and password will be accepted.</p>
property.summary: AAA policy for validating user name and password
property.name: PasswordAAAPolicy

property.description: <p>Selects the AAA Policy to perform secondary authentication of the information provided in the TLS certificate provided during TLS negotiation after the <tt>AUTH TLS</tt> command to the FTP server. Primary authentication is done by the TLS Profile, it can completely reject a certificate. This authentication stage controls whether an FTP password will be demanded or not. If the result of this authentication succeeds, the FTP client will only have to use the <tt>USER</tt> command to login after the <tt>AUTH TLS</tt> . If this authentication fails, the FTP client will have to use both the <tt>USER</tt> and <b>PASS</b> commands to complete the login process. If no Certificate AAA Policy is configured, <tt>USER</tt> and <b>PASS</b> will always be required. If the <tt>AUTH TLS</tt> command is not used by the FTP client, <tt>USER</tt> and <b>PASS</b> will always be required.</p>
property.summary: AAA Policy for determining whether password is required
property.name: CertificateAAAPolicy
AllowCCC
property.summary: Control use of CCC command
property.description: <p>Specify whether the FTP <b>CCC</b> command can be used to turn off TLS encryption of the FTP control connection after user authentication. If allowed, the <b>CCC</b> command can be used to turn off encryption after authentication. Turning off encryption is necessary when the FTP control connection crosses a firewall or NAT device that needs to sniff the control connection. Turning off encryption eliminates the secrecy of the files being transferred and allows TCP packets injection attacks.</p>

property.name: Passive
property.summary: Control use of passive mode
property.description: Control use of the FTP PASV and EPSV commands by the FTP client, as an alternative to the PORT and EPRT commands. The default is to allow PORT, EPRT, PASV, and EPSV. Other settings either require PASV or EPSV, or require PORT or EPRT. If an acceptable PORT, EPRT, PASV, or EPSV command is not received, the STOR, STOU, RETR, LIST, and NLST data transfer commands will fail. (This FTP server will never attempt to connect to the deprecated default FTP data port at TCP port 20.)

property.name: UsePasvPortRange
property.summary: Enable using a limited range of TCP port numbers for Passive connections.
property.display: Limit Port Range for Passive Connections
property.description: <p>When enabled, when a PASV or EPSV command is received from the FTP client, instead of selecting any free listening TCP port in the range 1024 to 65534, allow configuration of a restricted port range. This may be used when a firewall wants to allow incoming FTP data connections only on a limited range of ports, particularly when it cannot "sniff" the FTP control connection.</p><p>Note that the size of the range specified limits how many FTP clients can be in the state between receiving the 227 response code to the PASV or EPSV command, and establishing the FTP data TCP connection. Pressure on this limited resource can be controlled by adjusting the passive data connection idle timeout.</p><p>While it is perfectly legal to configure multiple FTP servers on the same system to use the same (or overlapping) passive port ranges, realize that they are contending for a common resource in the TCP implementation.</p><p>However, it is not wise to use a port range that overlaps with other services (HTTP servers, etc.) that are configured on the system. There is no configuration checking for such conflicts, and other configured services will allocate the ports first, and they will not be available for the FTP server. (The FTP server allocates these listing ports dynamically.)</p>

property.name: PasvMinPort
property.summary: Lowest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the lowest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not greater than Maximum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvMaxPort
property.summary: Highest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the highest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not less than Minimum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvIdleTimeOut
property.summary: Idle timeout for a passive data connection
property.description: <p>Specifies the number of seconds that the server waits for a client to establish a passive connection. Use an integer in the range of 5 through 300. The default is 60.</p><p>This setting controls the amount of time in seconds between when the FTP server issues code 227 (Entering Passive Mode) in response to the <tt>PASV</tt> or <tt>EPSV</tt> command from the FTP client and when the FTP client must establish a TCP data connection to the listening port and issue a data transfer command.</p><ul><li>If the data connection is not established within the timeout period, the listening port will be closed. If a data transfer command is issued after the port is closed, the command fails with code 425 and the <tt>Failed to open data connection</tt> message.</li><li>If the data connection is established but no data transfer command is issued within the timeout period, the TCP data connection will be closed. Any data transfer command after the timeout will be treated as if the <tt>PASV</tt> or <tt>EPSV</tt> command was never issued. The command fails with code 425 and the <tt>Require PASV or PORT command first</tt> message.</li></ul>

property.name: DisablePASVIPCheck
property.summary: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check
property.display: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check
property.description: <p>This option will disable the IP security check that is done when processing the FTP PASV command. The check verifies that the IP address of the client connecting to the data connection is the same as the one that established the control connection.</p><p>The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server. Turn the option on if there is a specific reason the incoming connection will not be coming from the same client as the control connection (i.e. from a load balancer).</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: DisablePORTIPCheck
property.summary: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check
property.display: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check
property.description: <p>This option will disable the IP security check that verifies that outgoing data connections can only connect to the client.</p><p>The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server.</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: UseAlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Use Alternate PASV IP Address
property.description: <p>When on, this option will enable the ability to override the IP address that is presented to the FTP client when the server is in passive mode.</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: AlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Alternate PASV IP Address
property.description: <p>The numeric IP address that will be returned to the FTP client in response to a PASV command. This does not change the IP address that the FTP server will listen on, which is always the IP address that the FTP data connection was made to. This is used in certain situations when the FTP server is behind a firewall that is not FTP-aware.</p>

property.name: AllowLISTCmd
property.summary: Enable LIST command support
property.description: <p>When on, the server will make a distinction between the LIST and NLST commands. When off, the server will always respond with an NLST when requesting a file listing.</p><p>The default value for this option is off</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: AllowDELECmd
property.summary: Enable DELE (delete) support
property.description: <p>When on, allows the DELE (delete) command to be passed to the FTP back-end server. This is only valid in Transparent Filesystem type.</p><p>The default value for this option is off</p><p>This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.</p>

property.name: DataEncryption
property.summary: Control use of data encryption for file transfers
property.description: Select the use of encryption for data connections (file transfers). Data encryption is controlled by the FTP PROT P command.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Control use of MODE Z command to compress data transfer
property.description: <p>Specify whether the FTP client can use FTP <tt>MODE Z</tt> compression. After enabling FTP compression, the FTP client can use the zlib method to compress data transfers.</p>

property.name: AllowSTOU
property.summary: Control use of STOU command for unique file names
property.description: <p>Specify whether the FTP client can use the FTP <tt>STOU</tt> command. When enabled, the FTP server generates a unique file name for each transferred file.</p>

property.name: UniqueFilenamePrefix
property.summary: Prefix of all unique filenames generated by STOU
property.description: <p>Enter the prefix (leading characters) for file names that are generated when using the FTP <tt>STOU</tt> command. When defining the prefix, the directory separator (/) is not allowed. The default is to not add a prefix, which is an empty string.</p><p><b>Note:</b> The software adds a numeric suffix.</p>

property.name: AllowREST
property.summary: Control use of the REST command for interrupted file transfers
property.description: <p>Controls whether the FTP client can use the FTP <tt>REST</tt> command to continue the transfer of a file after an interruption in the data transfer. This is supported in the BSD stream style described in draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt. (The MODE B style that is described in RFC 959 is not supported.) The FTP server must be configured with a virtual persistent file system.</p><p>For written files, the server will delay the actual processing until a timeout expires or until the next FTP command other than a <tt>SIZE</tt> or <tt>REST</tt> command. This processing allows the FTP client can return and resume to the transfer using the <tt>SIZE</tt> , <tt>REST</tt> , and <tt>STOR</tt> commands. The argument to the <tt>REST</tt> command must be the same as the byte count returned by the <tt>SIZE</tt> command.</p><p><b>Note:</b> The response code to all <tt>STOR</tt> commands on this server will always be 226. The response codes does not reflect the success of the transaction.</p><p>This capability is also supported for reading the response files, if the server is configured for a Response Type of Virtual Filesystem.</p><p><b>Note:</b> The generation of response files are delayed until the transaction is completed.</p>

property.name: RestartTimeout
property.summary: Time that the STOR command waits for a restart
property.description: <p>When restart ( <tt>REST</tt> ) is enabled, the number of seconds that the FTP client has to reconnect to the server and use the <tt>SIZE</tt> , <tt>REST</tt> , and <tt>STOR</tt> commands to continue an interrupted file transfer. If this period of time elapses, the data that was received to this point on the TCP data connection will be passed to the DataPower service. This timeout is canceled if another command (other than <tt>SIZE</tt> or <tt>REST</tt> ) is received on the FTP control connection.</p>

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.summary: Inactivity limit on FTP control connection
property.description: Enter the number of seconds that the FTP control connection can be idle. After the specified duration elapses, the FTP server closes the control connection. Defaults to 0, which disables the timeout.

property.name: ResponseType
property.summary: How to make response available to FTP client
property.description: Select how to make response files available for gateway transactions started by an FTP STOR or SOUT operation.

property.name: ResponseStorage
property.summary: Where to store response files
property.description: Select where response files are stored.

property.name: TemporaryStorageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of temporary file system
property.description: Enter in megabytes the maximum size for the temporary file system size. Defaults to 32 MB. Valid range is 1 MB through 2048 MB.

property.name: ResponseNFSMount
property.summary: NFS mount to store response files in
property.description: <p>When Response Type is Virtual File System and Response Storage is NFS, select an NFS static mount to apply. Each response file will have a unique file name in the NFS directory. The name of the response file is not related to the file name that the virtual file system presents to the FTP client. Generally, this NFS directory is not made available through the FTP server. This directory should not be used for any other purpose.</p>

property.name: ResponseSuffix
property.summary: URL file name suffix to response file
property.description: When the response type is a virtual file system, enter the suffix to add when generating response files. The directory separator (/) is not allowed. If the response type is a virtual file system and the FTP client is writing in virtual directories that do not have a response directory or if the response directory is the same as the virtual directory, this value must have a non-empty value. If empty, the response would try to overwrite the request, which is not allowed. Defaults to an empty string.

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: <p>The TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway. If a TLS profile is assigned, the FTP <tt>AUTH TLS</tt> server command will be enabled, and the client will be able to start TLS encryption of the FTP control connection.</p><p>The chosen TLS profile controls the TLS credentials that the FTP server will present to the client after the <tt>AUTH TLS</tt> command, and how the TLS credentials presented by the client will be evaluated.</p>

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway
property.description: The TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

object.description: <p>The FTP Server handler provides an FTP server that can be used to submit files for processing by the system. Each file that is written results in one transaction.</p><p>There can be multiple FTP servers, but only one server can listen on the default port 21 on a given IP address. There can be multiple simultaneous connections from FTP clients to the same FTP server.</p><p><b>Notes:</b></p><ul><li>The 226 FTP response code at the end of an FTP <tt>STOR</tt> or <tt>STOU</tt> command is conditional on successful completion of the internal steps and backside operation of the transaction.</li><li>Changes in the configuration affect only new connections to this FTP server. Existing connections continue to use their current configuration until they disconnect.</li></ul>

value.description: Adds a log entry at the specified log priority.
value.name: notify

value.description: Rejects the transaction and adds a log entry at the specified log priority.
value.name: reject

value.description: Adds a log entry at the specified log priority. Messages are buffered and processed at a rate that is less than the threshold. When the buffer is full, messages are rejected.
value.name: shape

value.description: An emergency-level message. The system is unusable.
value.name: emerg

value.description: An alert-level message. Immediate action must be taken.
value.name: alert

value.description: A critical message. Immediate action should be taken.
value.name: critic

value.description: An error message. Processing might continue, but action should be taken.
value.name: error

value.description: A warning message. Processing should continue, but action should be taken.
value.name: warn

value.description: A notice message. Processing continues, but action might need to be taken.
value.name: notice

value.description: An information message. No action required.
value.name: info

value.description: A debug message for processing information to help during troubleshooting.
value.name: debug

object.name: FilterAction
object.summary: Defines the administrative action to take

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Type
property.summary: Action (Control procedure)
property.description: Select the action to take The default is notify.

property.name: LogLevel
property.summary: Log message priority
property.description: Specify the priority of the log message that is generated when a monitored message type exceeds a threshold value.

property.name: BlockInterval
property.summary: The amount of time a monitor stays triggered
property.description: Specify an optional interval during which an over-threshold message type is denied service. Meaningful only when the message is rejected due to policy or shaping queue overflow. This value is the duration of service denial in milliseconds. The default value is 0, indicates that over-threshold messages are dropped but no service denial penalty is imposed.

object.description: A message filter action defines the administrative action to take. Filters can be cautionary or stringent.

value.description: Do not attach a cookie attribute policy.
value.name: no
value.summary: Do not attach a cookie attribute policy.

value.description: Attach a cookie attribute policy.
value.name: yes
backend
value.summary: Retrieve forms from their mapped locations on the application server.

value.name: appliance
value.summary: Stores forms locally on the file system.

value.description: Use the value of the <tt>var://service/URL-in</tt> variable as the host information.
value.name: urlin

value.description: Use the value of the <tt>Host</tt> HTTP header field as the host information.
value.name: host
value.summary: Value of the Host HTTP header field

value.description: Use static HTML login, logout, and error pages from an explicit location. These HTML pages can be on the DataPower Gateway or on a remote server.
value.name: static

value.description: Use a custom stylesheet or a GatewayScript file that generates the HTML login, logout, error pages, and the form.

object.name: FormsLoginPolicy
object.summary: Policy that defines HTML form behavior

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LoginForm
property.summary: URL fragment of login form
property.description: The URL fragment of the login page on the application server. The login page collects user name and password information. The default is /LoginPage.htm.

property.name: UseCookieAttributes
property.summary: Indicate whether to attach a policy that describes cookie attributes.
property.description: Whether to attach a cookie attribute policy. If you do not use a cookie attribute policy, the configuration use the properties of the forms login policy. The default behavior is not to attach a cookie attribute policy.

property.name: CookieAttributes
property.summary: Set the policy that describes cookie attributes.
property.description: <p>Use a cookie attribute policy to allow predefined or custom attributes to be included in forms login cookie. Properties in the policy override common attributes of the forms login policy. <ul><li><tt>Max-Age</tt> overrides inactivity timeout and session lifetime.</li><li><tt>Path</tt> replaces the form POST action URL.</li><li><tt>Secure</tt> replaces the use TLS for login.</li></ul></p>

property.name: UseSSLForLogin
property.summary: Whether to use TLS for the login
property.description: Whether to use a secure connection for the login exchange. If enabled, you must provide the TLS port. The default is enabled.

property.name: EnableMigration
property.summary: Whether to allow sessions to migrate between cluster members if a DataPower Gateway fails
property.description: Whether to permit session failover between cluster members. If enabled, you must specify a shared secret. The default is disabled.

property.name: SSLPort
property.summary: Port for TLS login redirection
property.description: The port the service uses for TLS redirection during the login transaction. Specify the port of the HTTPS handler that the Web application firewall uses for secure communication. The default is 8080.

property.name: SharedSecret
property.summary: Shared secret, common to all DataPower Gateways to which a session may migrate
property.description: Shared secret object that will be used to protect the migration cookie. All cluster members must specify the same shared secret.

property.name: ErrorPage
property.summary: URL fragment of error page
property.description: The URL fragment of the error page on the application server. The error page is displayed after a login failure. The default is /ErrorPage.htm.

property.name: LogoutPage
property.summary: URL of logout page
property.description: The URL fragment of the logout page on the application server. An empty string disables logout. The default is /LogoutPage.htm.

property.name: DefaultURL
property.summary: URL fragment to go to after successful login
property.description: The URL fragment to visit after a successful login when no other target is available. In most cases, login is triggered via an attempt to access a URL in the application, and the client is redirected to this URL after successfully logging in. However, if users explicitly visit the URL of the login form, they are redirected to this URL after logging in. This URL fragment is relative to the root directory. Although the default is /, you must specify the filename of the page to go after a successful login.

property.name: FormsLocation
property.summary: Location of HTML pages
property.description: The location for where the DataPower Gateway retrieves the login, logout and error pages. The default is the remote application server.

property.name: LocalLoginForm
property.summary: Location of local login form
property.description: The location of the login form on the DataPower Gateway. The default is store:///LoginPage.htm.

property.name: LocalErrorPage
property.summary: Location of local error page
property.description: The location of the error page on the DataPower Gateway. The default is store:///ErrorPage.htm.

property.name: LocalLogoutPage
property.summary: Location of local logout page
property.description: The location of the logout page on the DataPower Gateway. The default is store:///LogoutPage.htm.

property.name: UsernameField
property.summary: Attribute value of the user name field
property.description: The value of the 'name' attribute for the user name field on the login form. The default is j_username.

property.name: PasswordField
property.summary: Attribute value of the password field
property.description: The value of the 'name' attribute for the password field on the login form. The default is j_password.

property.name: RedirectField
property.summary: Attribute value of the hidden field for the target URL
property.description: The value of the 'name' attribute for the hidden field on the login form. This field stores the original target URL, which is the URL that the client is attempting to access. The default is originalUrl.

property.name: FormProcessingURL
property.summary: Processing URL fragment
property.description: The URL fragment to which the login form posts its results when a user submits the request. The default is /j_security_check.

property.name: InactivityTimeout
property.summary: Allowable duration for an inactive session
property.description: The number of seconds before an inactive session is invalidated. The default is 600. A value of 0 disables the inactivity timer.

property.name: SessionLifetime
property.summary: Maximum time before requiring re-authentication
property.description: The maximum time in seconds that a session can persist before that session becomes invalid and requires re-authentication. The minimum value is 1. The default is 10800.

property.name: RedirectURLType
property.summary: How to retrieve host information for HTTP URL-redirects
property.description: Control how the service retrieves host information for HTTP URL-redirects. The default behavior is to use the variable value.

property.name: FormSupportType
property.summary: Source for HTML pages
property.description: Manage the source for HTML pages. The default behavior is to use static HTML pages from an explicit location.

property.name: FormSupportScript
property.summary: Location of the custom processing to generate HTML pages and form
property.description: <p>Specify the location of the custom XSLT stylesheet or GatewayScript file that generates the HTML pages.</p><p>This stylesheet or GatewayScript file must generate the following HTML pages:</p><ul><li>A login form request allows processing to generate a login form with the <tt>login</tt> operation.</li><li>A logout page request allows processing to generate a logout page with the <tt>logout</tt> operation.</li><li>An error page request allows processing to generate an error page with the <tt>error</tt> operation.</li></ul>

object.description: The HTML forms login policy defines the details for collecting user authentication information.

Host aliases can ease migration tasks among appliances.</p><ul><li>0 or 0.0.0.0 indicates all configured IPv4 addresses.</li><li>:: indicates all configured IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.</li></ul><p><b>Attention:</b> For management services, the value of 0.0.0.0 or :: is a security risk. Use an explicit IP address to isolate management traffic from application data traffic.</p>

property.name: UserSummary
FrozenEnabled
property.summary: Whether to freeze the GatewayScript built-in object prototypes
property.description: <p>Controls whether to freeze the built-in object prototypes. <ul><li>When frozen, you cannot modify, add or removal prototypes. This is the default setting.</li><li>When not frozen, you can manipulate prototypes.</li></ul></p>

property.name: UntrustedCodeMitigated
property.summary: Whether to enable untrusted code mitigations to protect against SSCA
property.description: <p>Controls whether to enable untrusted code mitigations to protect against Speculative Side-Channel Attacks (SSCA) vulnerabilities. <ul><li>When enabled, untrusted code is protected against SSCA. This is the default setting.</li><li>When not enabled, untrusted code is not protected against SSCA.</li></ul></p>

property.name: TerminateTime
property.summary: Maximum allowed synchronous processing duration
property.description: Specifies the maximum allowed number of seconds that the GatewayScript action can continuously use the CPU, without yielding back to the system event loop. When the maximum synchronous execution duration elapses and the GatewayScript action is still processing, the action is terminated and causes the transaction to throw an error. Enter a value in the range 1 - 300. The default value is 0 second, which indicates an unlimited duration.

Freeze means preventing the modification of existing property attributes and values, the addition of new properties, or the removal of existing properties of the built-in objects.</li><li>The maximum allowed number of seconds that the GatewayScript action can continuously use the CPU.</li></ul>
