IPConfigMode
property.summary: Set the configuration mode for the interface.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the configuration mode for the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.</p><ul><li>With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface.</li><li>With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li><li>With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The configuration mode of the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.</p><ul><li>With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface. <ul><li>Assign the primary network address.</li><li>Manage secondary, or auxiliary, network addresses.</li><li>Assign the default IPv4 gateway.</li><li>Assign the default IPv6 gateway, if you define IPv6 IP addresses.</li><li>Manage static routes in the routing table.</li></ul></li><li>With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li><li>With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li></ul>

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: Set the primary IP address and netmask.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>

property.name: DefaultGateway
property.summary: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway.
property.hoverhelp: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.
property.description: The IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.

property.name: DefaultIPv6Gateway
property.summary: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway.
property.hoverhelp: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway.
property.description: The IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway. If you do not use IPv6 network addresses, do not define this property.

property.name: SecondaryAddress
property.summary: Set secondary IP addresses and netmasks.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the IP address and netmask of the secondary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The IP addresses and netmasks of secondary IP addresses. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>

property.name: StaticRoutes
property.summary: Manage the static routes in the routing table.
property.hoverhelp: Manage the static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network.
property.description: The static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network. When the appliance connects to a remote address, the static route with the longest prefix match is used. If multiple routes have the same prefix match, the static route with the lowest metric is used. If the metric is the same, the static route is chosen randomly.

property.name: DADTransmits
property.summary: Set the number of IPv6 duplication address detection attempts.
property.description: The number of IPv6 duplication address detection (DAD) attempts. The default value is 1.

property.name: DADRetransmitTimer
property.summary: Set the delay between IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) attempts.
property.hoverhelp: Set the delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.
property.description: The delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. The default value is 1000. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.

property.name: StandbyControl
property.summary: Indicate whether to allow a standby configuration.
property.description: <p>Whether to allow a standby configuration. The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: Group
property.summary: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.
property.description: <p>The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP).</p><p>The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration.</p><ul><li>Belong to the same group.</li><li>Use the same primary virtual IP address.</li><li>Use the same authentication, or security token.</li></ul>

property.name: VirtualIP
property.summary: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.
property.description: <p>The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: SecondaryVirtualIP
property.summary: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.
property.description: <p>Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: Preempt
property.summary: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group. <b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>
property.description: <p>Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure.</p><ul><li>When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member.</li><li>When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member.</li></ul><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>

property.name: Priority
property.summary: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.
property.description: <p>The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.</p><p>For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.</p>

property.name: SelfBalance
property.summary: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul><p>The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint.</p><ul><li>In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause.</li><li>In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.</li></ul>

property.name: Authentication
property.summary: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: Set the authentication string, or security token in hex. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.
property.description: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

property.name: HelloTimer
property.summary: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages
property.hoverhelp: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40.
property.description: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.

property.name: HoldTimer
property.summary: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.
property.hoverhelp: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120.
property.description: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.

property.name: DistAlg
property.summary: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.
property.description: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.
The mode to use for link aggregation. When the link aggregation interface uses LACP, you can change the selection policy and the distribution algorithm for outbound packets.
property.summary: Set the mode for link aggregation.
property.name: Type
Links
property.summary: Manage Ethernet interfaces in the link aggregation interface.
property.description: <p>The Ethernet interfaces in the link aggregation interface. Although you can add members in the following situations, the operational state of the link aggregation interface is down. <ul><li>The Ethernet interface is part of a VLAN interface.</li><li>The Ethernet interface is part of another link aggregation interface.</li><li>The Ethernet interface is not enabled for link aggregation.</li></ul></p>

property.name: MTU
property.summary: Set the maximum transmission unit for the link aggregation interface.
property.hoverhelp: Set the maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the link aggregation interface. The MTU of the link aggregation interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128.
property.description: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the link aggregation interface. The MTU of the link aggregation interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation.

property.name: LACPAggregatorSelectionPolicy
property.summary: Set the algorithm for the LACP selection policy.
property.hoverhelp: Set the algorithm for the Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) selection policy. When there is more than one LACP aggregator for the members of an LACP aggregation, the appliance uses the algorithm to determine which aggregator to use. In other words, the algorithm determines which group of link aggregation interfaces is active.
property.description: The algorithm for the Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) selection policy. When there is more than one LACP aggregator for the members of an LACP aggregation, the appliance uses the algorithm to determine which aggregator to use. In other words, the algorithm determines which group of link aggregation interfaces is active.

property.name: TransmitHashingAlgorithm
property.summary: Set the distribution algorithm for outbound packets among the active physical interfaces in an LACP aggregation.
property.description: The distribution algorithm for outbound packets among the active physical interfaces in an Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) aggregation. The default algorithm uses uses both MAC addresses and IP addresses.

property.name: LACPRate
property.summary: Set the rate in the LACP aggregation.
property.description: The rate of the LACP aggregation, which can be slow (every 30 seconds) or fast (every 1 second).

property.name: HardwareOffload
property.summary: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.
property.description: <p>Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled.</p><ul><li>When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of Ethernet device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance.</li><li>When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.</li></ul><p>If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.</p>

object.description: A link aggregation interface combines multiple Ethernet ports. When combined and used in parallel, the aggregate interface increases link speed beyond a single Ethernet port. Because the aggregate interface combines Ethernet ports, redundancy is increased to provider higher availability.

value.description: Maintains a simple list of servers and forwards a new connection to the next server in the list.
value.name: round-robin

value.description: Maintains a weighted list of servers and forwards new connections in proportion to the weight that is assigned to each server.
value.name: weighted-round-robin
value.summary: Balance the servers proportionally according to weight

value.description: <p>Uses the IP address of the client or the value of an HTTP header as the basis for server selection.</p><p>With the hash algorithm, the same client is served by the same server. Use this algorithm only when clients access applications that require the storage of server-side state information, such as cookies. Hashing algorithms cannot ensure even distribution.</p><p>The HTTP header approach is applicable with only Multi-Protocol Gateway and Web Service Proxy services.</p>
value.name: hash
value.summary: Base on IP address or HTTP header of the client

value.description: Maintains a record of current active server connections and creates a new connection to the server with the least number of active connections.
value.name: least-connections

value.description: Based on the concept of a primary and some number of backup servers. Assuming that the primary server is up, all connections are forwarded to this server. Connections are forwarded to backup servers only if the health state of the primary server is down or softdown.
value.name: first-alive

value.description: Maintains a record of the number of active server connections and creates a new connection to the server with the least number of current connections. The weighting provides a distribution of connections whereby the percentage of connections sent to any given server will match the relative weight assigned to that server. When 'persistent connections' is disabled, the number of connections in use is roughly equal to the number of requests that are outstanding. Therefore, the distribution of the requests will closely follow the weight distribution. When 'persistent connections' are enabled, the long lived connection may be reused many times before a new connection is established. In the case of persistent connections, the number of individual requests to any given server may not match the weight distribution.
value.name: weighted-least-connections
value.summary: Server with fewest weighted outstanding connections

value.description: Specifies that the method and format of the information to be retrieved will be that of a WebSphere Cell.
value.name: use-websphere

value.description: Use the HTTP protocol as the transport protocol to members.
value.name: http

value.description: The HTTPS protocol as the transport protocol to members.
value.name: https

property.name: Server
property.summary: Host name or IP address
property.description: Specifies the host name or IP address of the real server.

property.name: Weight
property.summary: Weight
property.description: <p>When balancing with Weighted Round Robin, the weight property indicates the relative priority of this server versus the other members of the group. The greater the weight indicates the higher the preference. Use an integer between 1 and 65000.</p><p>For example, assume three server pool members, A, B, and C, with assigned weights of 5, 3, and 2 respectively. As a result of this weighting, server A can expect to receive approximately 50% of client requests, server B can expect to receive approximately 30% of client requests, with server C receiving the remaining 20%.</p>

<p>Specifies the port on the real server. If non-zero, the associated real server is contacted on this port. Normally the real server is contacted on the same port number as that of the virtual server and this should not be set to a value other than zero. However, if you have services that run on different ports for different members of the group, you might need to define this value.</p><p>The DataPower Gateway checks this port when the health check type is IMS Connect.</p>
property.summary: Port number
property.name: MappedPort

property.description: DEPRECATED.
property.name: Activity

property.description: Specifies the TCP Port number to test.
property.summary: Port number
property.name: HealthPort
LBMemberState
property.summary: Administrative State of the Load Balancer Member
property.description: Enable or Disable the Load Balancer Member. If the Administrative State is disabled, the member are not used in health or forwarding checks.

property.name: Active
property.summary: Enable this health check?
property.description: Enables or disables a health check. The check will not run unless enabled

property.name: URI
property.summary: XXX in http://www.foobar.com/XXX
property.description: The relative URI to test for each member of the group. XXX in http://www.foobar.com/XXX.

property.name: Port
property.summary: Port to test
property.description: Enter the TCP Port number to test. The remote port and the member server health port interact differently depending on the type of the health check. <ul><li>Standard: The member server health port is used if specified. If not specified, the remote port in the load balancer group health check is used.</li><li>LDAP: The remote port in the load balancer group health check only is used. A specification of a health port for the member server is ignored.</li><li>IMS: The health port of the member only is used. The remote port in the load balancer group health check is ignored.</li></ul>

property.name: SSL
property.summary: Type of health check operation
property.description: Type of health check to perform. In TCP mode (TCP Connection health check type), a health check is performed with a TCP connection request. In HTTP mode (Standard health check type), a health check is performed with an HTTP GET or HTTP POST.

property.name: Post
property.summary: Send SOAP Request?
property.description: When set to on, the SOAP Request Document will be submitted to the web service via an HTTP POST operation. When set to off (without a request document), an HTTP Get operation is sent. The expected response is always valid XML and it is then analyzed using the Xpath Expression to verify the state of health of the server.

property.name: Input
property.summary: The SOAP Request Document is only used if the send SOAP request is true.
property.description: Enter the URL of the SOAP Request Document. This may be a file on the local flash filesystem (for example, local:///healthcheck.xml). This document is POSTed to the server if Send SOAP Request is on.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Number of seconds to allocate for check
property.description: Enter an integer between 2 and 86400 to indicate the number of seconds to wait for a response to a health check post. The default is 10.

property.name: Frequency
property.summary: Number of seconds between checks
property.description: Enter an integer between 5 and 86400 to indicate the number of seconds to wait between health check posts. The default is 180.

property.name: XPath
property.summary: An XPath Expression for a healthy SOAP response
property.description: Enter an XPath Expression that verifies the health of the server. The expression is applied to the server's response to the health check POST. If the expression is true, the server is healthy. Otherwise, the server health state is softdown until it passes a health check.

property.name: Filter
property.summary: Filter that analyzes response
property.description: Enter the URL of the stylesheet that evaluates the server response using the XPath Expression entered above. The default is supplied on this DataPower device.

property.name: SSLProxyProfile
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.
property.description: Select an existing TLS proxy profile for use with this health check. This is required if the back end server is using TLS communications with the DataPower device.

property.name: EnforceTimeout
property.summary: Enforce Health Check Timeouts
property.description: Indicates whether the health check timeout value is used to interrupt and end a health transaction. By default, the health check timeout only compares the actual time that the request took. With the default behavior, the health check timeout is not used to interrupt the transaction.

property.name: IndependentChecks
property.summary: Independent Health Checks
property.description: Indicates whether the health checks within a Load Balancer Group run independently of one another. By default, health checks within a Load Balancer Group run sequentially. With the default behavior, if a server hangs, all the other health checks for the other members are delayed.

property.name: GatewayScriptChecks
property.summary: Enable GatewayScript Health Check Processing
property.description: Enables or disables GatewayScript health check processing. If enabled, content of health check requests and responses can be of any type and the response evaluator will be a GatewayScript file.

property.name: GatewayScriptReqMethod
property.summary: Set the HTTP method for health check requests
property.description: The HTTP method to use for Standard health checks with GatewayScript. If Custom is selected, a custom method name must also be specified.

property.name: GatewayScriptCustomReqMethod
property.summary: Enter the custom method
property.description: The name of the custom method to use for Standard health check requests when GatewayScript processing is enabled.

property.name: GatewayScriptReqDoc
property.summary: The Request Document is only used if the HTTP method is POST, PUT, or Custom
property.description: Enter the URL of the Request Document. This might be a file on the local flash filesystem (for example, local:///healthcheck.xml). This document is included in the request to the server if the POST, PUT, or Custom method is selected for Standard health checks with GatewayScript. If the HTTP method is Custom, the request document is optional.

property.name: GatewayScriptReqContentType
property.summary: The content type of the Request Document
property.description: Enter the content type of the Request Document for Standard health checks with GatewayScript.

property.name: GatewayScriptRspHandlerMetadata
property.summary: Metadata used by the GatewayScript response evaluator
description: Enter a string to be used by the GatewayScript Response Evaluator to help determine the state of the server's health.

Enter a string (UTF-8). The value entered can be accessed via the evaluator session parameter. The GatewayScript Response Evaluator must issue the following: "session.parameters.evaluator" to retrieve this data.

property.name: GatewayScriptRspHandler
property.summary: The GatewayScript file used to evaluate the health check response
property.description: Enter the URL of the GatewayScript file that evaluates the server response using the Response Evaluator Metadata. The default GatewayScript file is supplied on the DataPower Gateway.

property.name: TCPConnectionType
property.summary: Type of TCP connection to attempt for health check operation
property.description: When set to full, a TCP Connection health check will perform a complete three-way handshake to establish a connection, followed by a four-way handshake to close the connection. When set to partial, a TCP Connection health check will perform a half-open connection to check a member's health. The three-way handshake to establish a connection will not be completed for partial connection types.

property.name: SSLClientConfigType
property.summary: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets
property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.name: SSLClient
property.summary: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets
property.description: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.name: EnableSA
property.summary: Enable Session Affinity
property.description: Enables or disables session affinity operations.

property.name: InsertionCookieName
property.summary: Insertion Cookie Name
property.description: Name of the cookie inserted into the response when active or active-conditional session affinity is required.

property.name: InsertionPath
property.summary: Insertion Path
property.description: The path added to the insertion cookie in the response when active or active-conditional session affinity is required.

property.name: InsertionDomain
property.summary: Insertion Domain
property.description: The domain added to the insertion cookie in the response when active or active-conditional session affinity is required. The domain name cannot begin with a dot.

property.name: AffinityWLMOverride
property.summary: Override WebSphere Cell Session Affinity
property.description: Overrides the WebSphere Cell Session Affinity cluster configuration with the DataPower Gateway configuration information below.

property.name: AffinityMode
property.summary: Set the session affinity mode
property.description: The mode of session affinity applied to this load balancer group.

property.name: InsertionAttributes
property.summary: Which attributes to insert in the cookie
property.description: Specifies the attributes to insert in the cookie in the response when active or active-conditional session affinity is required.

value.description: Forces session affinity for every HTTP request irrespective of the need for session affinity by the remote application.
value.name: active

value.description: Forces session affinity when the remote application indicates that session affinity is required. The list of monitored cookies is used to verify that the remote server is requesting session affinity.
value.name: activeConditional

value.description: The server is checked with an HTTP GET or a SOAP request to the server's health port, or if one is not specified, to the remote port.
value.name: Standard

value.description: Deprecated - The load balancer group contains LDAP servers. The health check is performed with a TCP connection request on the remote port.
value.name: LDAP

value.description: Deprecated - The load balancer group contains IMS Connect servers. The health check is performed with a TCP connection request on the mapped server port.
value.name: IMSConnect

value.description: The server is checked by sending a TCP connection request to the server's health port, or if one is not specified, to the remote port.
value.name: TCPConnection
GET
value.summary: Use the HTTP GET method for the health check request.

value.name: HEAD
value.summary: Use the HTTP HEAD method for the health check request.

value.name: POST
value.summary: Use the HTTP POST method for the health check request.

value.name: PUT
value.summary: Use the HTTP PUT method for the health check request.

value.name: Custom
value.summary: Use a custom method for the health check request.

value.description: Perform a three-way handshake to establish a connection and a four-way handshake to close the connection.
value.name: Full

value.description: Perform an incomplete three-way handshake, or half-open connection, by responding to a member's SYN-ACK with a RST.

object.name: LoadBalancerGroup
object.summary: Configure the members of a virtual group

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Contains a brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Algorithm
property.summary: Algorithm to balance the real servers.
property.description: Select the algorithm to use to balance the real servers.

property.name: RetrieveInfo
property.summary: Retrieve Workload Management Information
property.description: Use this setting to control whether this Load Balancer Group has membership and weight information automatically retrieved from the work load management repository WebSphere Cell. When disabled, the static configuration is used.

property.name: WLMRetrieval
property.summary: Workload Management Retrieval
property.description: Contains the back end work load management repository selection type. Select 'WebSphere Cell' if your back-end is a WebSphere Application Server (WAS) Network Deployment (ND) or WAS Virtual Enterprise (VE).

property.name: WebSphereCellConfig
property.summary: WebSphere Cell
property.description: If you selected 'WebSphere Cell' for Workload Management Retrieval, you need to select a WebSphere Cell object that retrieves this information. If no objects are available in the pull down, you must create one.

property.name: WLMGroup
property.summary: Workload Management Group Name
property.description: The Workload Management Group Name is used to define a group. In a WebSphere Application Server environment, the back end group is a cluster name. Once specified, the Load Balancer Group will be populated with the members and weights retrieved from the back end.

property.name: WLMTransport
property.summary: Protocol used for this Load Balancer Group
property.description: Specify either HTTP or HTTPS for the Load Balancer Group protocol. This protocol is used to forward traffic between the DataPower Gateway and the members of the Load Balancer Group.

property.name: Damp
property.summary: Timeout for down server
property.description: When a real server is observed to be non-functioning, it is temporarily disabled. When the damp time has elapsed, it is re-enabled. Allowable values are in the range 1 - 86400.

property.name: NeverReturnSickMember
property.summary: Block Connection Attempt When All Members Are Down
property.description: During normal operation, when all members of the load-balancing group are down and a new request for that group is made, the first member of the group is automatically selected. If this property is turned on, no attempt will be made to connect under these circumstances.

property.name: LBGroupMembers
property.summary: Group Membership

property.name: TryEveryServerBeforeFailing
property.summary: Try Every Server In Group Before Failing
property.description: This property applies only when none of the group members are in the "up" state. If this value is set, every server in the group is tried before failing the connection attempt. It is a "last best-effort" attempt.

The members of a Load Balancer Group can be periodically polled to verify the health of the server. If the server is found to be unresponsive, it is removed from the list of actively available servers until the unresponsive server passes a health check.
property.summary: Periodically Executed Health Check
property.name: LBGroupChecks

property.description: If you set this value, the host name presented to the server will be the name of the group instead of the name of the member being used for that specific transaction.
property.name: MasqueradeMember
ApplicationRouting
property.summary: Enables application routing with a WebSphere Cluster
property.description: <p>If set to on, the load balancer group will route to the back end cluster depending on the following conditions.</p><ul><li>the application for which this request is targeted</li><li>the application status on the back end servers</li></ul><p>Application Routing is required for Application Edition (group or atomic) rollout. If you need Application Edition support, set the Update Type to Subscribe in the WebSphere Cell object.</p>
Session affinity allows applications to maintain sessions with clients.
property.summary: Session Affinity
property.name: LBGroupAffinityConf
MonitoredCookies
property.summary: Monitored Cookies
property.description: The DataPower Gateway enforces session affinity when the application server attempts to establish session affinity using one of these cookie names.

object.description: <p>The DataPower device distributes traffic to members of a Load Balancer Group. These are back end servers and not additional DataPower devices. A Load Balancer Group lists members of a virtual server group and sets the algorithm for balancing them. Periodic health checks can be performed. Load Balancers may also be used to provide redundant LDAP server access.</p><p>When created, a DataPower service can use a Load Balancer Group by associating it with an XML manager that is associated with this service.</p><p>The back end destination URL is set to the name of the Load Balancer Group (example: "BackEndServers").</p>

<p>Indicate whether to include log messages for objects that the specified object instance references.</p><ul><li>When enabled, includes referenced objects.</li><li>When disabled, excludes referenced objects.</li></ul><p>Included objects are a static snapshot when you apply the object filter. If referenced objects are added after you apply the object filter, messages for these referenced objects are not logged. For example, if you specify a particular service that has handlers and a handler is added after you apply the object filter, messages are not logged for the added handler.</p>

object.name: LogTarget

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>
Specify a brief, descriptive summary.
property.summary: Descriptive summary
property.name: UserSummary
Type
property.summary: Type of log target
property.description: Specify the type of the log target. The default type is file.

property.name: Priority
property.summary: Log target priority
property.description: Control the log scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority operations will be favored over lower priority operations.

property.name: SoapVersion
property.summary: SOAP version for log target
property.description: Specify the SOAP version for SOAP log targets.

property.name: Format
property.summary: Format of log entries
property.description: Specify the format in which to represent log entries.

property.name: TimestampFormat
property.summary: Format of log timestamp
property.description: Specify the format of the timestamp for log entries. The default format is ISO UTC format.

property.name: FixedFormat
property.summary: Fix the format of logs
property.description: Makes the format of logs unchanging. The log format fixed at V6.0.1. New fields added to log formats afterwards are ignored.

property.name: LocalIdentifier
property.summary: Local system identifier
property.description: Specify a descriptive string that identifies the log target to remote recipients. For syslog destinations, do not include spaces.

property.name: EmailAddress
property.summary: Email address
property.description: Specify the email address to which to send log entries.

property.name: SenderAddress
property.summary: Email address
property.description: Specify the email address of the sender. The value must match the email address of the cryptographic key if email messages are signed.

property.name: SMTPDomain
property.summary: SMTP client domain
property.description: Specify the fully-qualified domain name of the SMTP client. This information will be part of the SMTP session initiation (HELO command).

property.name: Size
property.summary: Maximum log size
property.description: Specify the maximum size of file-based log targets. Enter a value in the range 100 through 50000. The default value is 500.

property.name: URL
property.summary: POST URL
property.description: Specify the HTTP URL to which to send log entries. The DataPower Gateway sends the entries with the POST method. The DataPower Gateway uses the default User Agent.

property.name: NFSMount
property.summary: Instance of the NFS Static Mount
property.description: Specify the name of an NFS Static Mount over which to write the log.

property.name: SSLProxyProfile
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.
property.description: The TLS proxy profile with the cryptographic profiles to secure connections.

property.name: LocalFile
property.summary: Name of the file for the file-based log target
property.description: Specify the name of the log file. Examples: <tt>logtemp:///filename.log</tt> or <tt>logstore:///filename.log</tt> .

property.name: NFSFile
property.summary: Path to the file for the NFS-based log target
property.description: Specify the path to the log file. The path is relative to the NFS mount. Use a regular expression in the <tt>^[_a-z0-9A-Z/][-_a-z0-9A-Z/.]*$</tt> format. Do not end the path with a forward slash (/).

property.name: ArchiveMode
property.summary: Method to archives
property.description: Specify the method to create archives.

property.name: UploadMethod
property.summary: Protocol to upload log files
property.description: Specify the protocol to upload log files. If you use SCP to upload multiple log targets at the same time, a system error might occur. The DataPower Gateway supports only one SCP connection at a time. To minimize the risk when using SCP, configure log targets with different settings, such as different event subscriptions and different log sizes.

property.name: Rotate
property.summary: Maximum number of rotations
property.description: Specify the maximum number of rotations to permit. Enter a value in the range 1 through 100. The default value is 3.

property.name: UseANSIColor
property.summary: Use ANSI color scheme
property.description: Enables the use of ANSI X3.64 escape sequences to color-code messages by log level.

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.summary: Host name or IP address
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the remote server. To establish a secure TLS connection to the server, set this value to the value of the remote host of a TLS Proxy service on the DataPower Gateway. The local TLS Proxy service then securely forwards the log entries to its configured remote server.

property.name: RemotePort
property.summary: Port number
property.description: Specify the listening port on the remote server. If using a local TLS Proxy service to establish a secure TLS connection, set this value to the value of the remote port of the TLS Proxy service.

property.name: RemoteLogin
property.summary: Account (user name)
property.description: Specify the account or user name to access the remote server.

property.name: RemotePassword
property.summary: Password
property.description: Specify the password for the account or user name for non-public key authentication. Public key authentication can be configured through the default instance of the User Agent.

property.name: RemoteDirectory
property.summary: Directory on the remote server
property.description: <p>Specify an existing writable directory on the remote server to which to upload files.</p><ul><li>To denote an absolute directory from the root directory, specify a single forward slash character (/) or equivalent encoded character (%2F) before the fully qualified path. <ul><li>For SCP or SFTP, enter / to resolve to //.</li><li>For FTP, enter %2F to resolve to /%2F.</li></ul></li><li>To denote a directory that is relative to the user's home directory, do not specify a forward slash character or encoded character before the fully qualified file name.</li></ul>

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local interface address
property.description: Specify a host alias or IP address of a local interface.

property.name: SyslogFacility
property.summary: syslog facility
property.description: Set the log facility (per RFC 3164) to include in messages sent to the syslog log target.

property.name: RateLimit
property.summary: The maximum number of events logged
property.description: <p>Set the maximum number of events to be logged per second. Enter a value in the range 1 - 1000. The default value is 100.</p><ul><li>Remote log targets might receive more than this number of events within a second, depending on network latency and buffering. syslog over TCP log targets are exclusive, because only a single TCP connection is made to the server.</li><li>In the case of syslog over TCP log targets, the rate limit is the maximum number of events transmitted over the connection within one second. A value of 0 disables rate-limiting by the logging target.</li></ul>

property.name: ConnectTimeout
property.summary: Number of seconds to wait for a connection to the server to be established before generating an error.
property.description: Set the number of seconds to wait for a connection to the server to be established before generating an error. A log message will be generated in the default log and connection retry attempts will be made. Enter a value in the range 1 - 90. The default value is 60.

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.summary: Number of seconds to wait before closing an established but inactive connection to the server.
property.description: <p>Set the number of seconds to wait before closing an established but inactive connection to the server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 600. The default value is 15.</p><p>Attention: If multiple log targets have the following configuration, they might share connections.</p><ul><li>The same local address and port</li><li>The same remote address and port</li></ul><p>Because of potential connection-sharing, set the same idle timeout value for these log targets.</p>

property.name: ActiveTimeout
property.summary: Number of seconds to wait before closing an established and active connection to the server.
property.description: <p>Set the number of seconds to wait before closing an established and active connection to the server. Enter a value in the range 0 - 60. A value of 0 allows the log target to most efficiently send messages to the server by maintaining a healthy connection indefinitely. The default value is 0.</p><p>Attention: If multiple log targets have the following configuration, they might share connections.</p><ul><li>The same local address and port</li><li>The same remote address and port</li></ul><p>Because of potential connection-sharing, set the same active timeout value for these log targets.</p>

property.name: FeedbackDetection
property.summary: Whether to suppress events from logging subsystem
property.description: Indicate whether to suppress events from the logging subsystem itself. A log target always suppresses its own events, but will record events from other log targets. Under certain circumstances with multiple log targets, these events could create a positive feedback loop that could cause resource contention. Enable to suppress all log events from the logging subsystem and prevent resource contention.

property.name: IdenticalEventSuppression
property.summary: Suppress identical events
property.description: Indicate whether to suppress identical events from the same object over a set time period. When enabled, the log target records only one instance of the event until the suppression period expires.

property.name: IdenticalEventPeriod
property.summary: Duration to suppress identical events
property.description: Set the duration of the suppression period. The default value is 10.

property.name: LogEventCode
property.summary: Filter to log specific event codes
property.description: Subscription filters allow only those log messages that contain the configured event codes to be written to this log target. With this filter, it is possible to create a log target that collects only log messages for a specific set of event codes.

property.name: LogEventFilter
property.summary: Filter to suppress specific event codes
property.description: Suppression filters suppress those log messages that contain the configured event codes to be written to this log target. With this filter, it is possible to create a log target that collects a wide range of log messages except for a specific set of event codes.

property.name: LogObjects
property.summary: Filter to log events for specific objects
property.description: Object filters allow only those log messages for specific objects to be written to this log target. Object filters are based on object classes. With this filter, you can create a log target that collects only log messages generated by particular instances of the specified object classes.

property.name: LogIPFilter
property.summary: Filter to log events for specific IP addresses
property.description: IP address filters allow only those log messages from specific IP addresses to be written to this log target.

property.name: LogTriggers
property.summary: Event Trigger Points
property.description: <p>Event triggers perform actions only when triggered by a specified message ID or event code. With this filter, it is possible to create a log target that collects only the results of the specified trigger action. For example, to trigger the generation of an error report when a certain event occurs use the <b>save error-report</b> command.</p>

property.name: SSLClientProfile
property.summary: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets
property.description: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.name: SSLClientConfigType
property.summary: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets
property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Time to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection
property.description: Specify the number of seconds to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection to the syslog server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 600. The default value is 1.

property.name: RetryAttempts
property.summary: The number of attempts to retry the failed connections
property.description: <p>Specify the number of attempts for a failed connection to the syslog server. After the number of attempts is reached, connection attempts use the value set by <b>Long Retry Interval</b>. When the long interval is disabled, the log target repeatedly attempts to reconnect to the syslog server with the value set by <b>Retry Interval</b>.</p><p><b>Note:</b> 0 means the <b>Long Retry Interval</b> will not be used and will retry forever using <b>Retry Interval</b>.</p>

property.name: LongRetryInterval
property.summary: Long retry interval before retrying the failed connections
property.description: <p>Specify the time to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection to the syslog server after the number of attempts is reached. Enter a value in the range 0 - 600. The default value is 20.</p><p><b>Note:</b> The <b>Long Retry Interval</b> must be greater than the <b>Retry Interval</b> or it will take no effect.</p>

property.name: LogPrecision
property.summary: Log Timestamp Precision
property.description: Log Timestamp Precision configuration of the format of the timestamp of the log messages.

property.name: Backup
property.summary: Log Target
property.description: Sets another Log Target object as a backup to receive redirected events in case of an error on the current file-based log target. This setting has no effect on network-based log targets. For network-based log targets, set a load balancer group as the remote host.

property.name: LogEvents
property.summary: Log event subscription
property.description: <p>Subscribes the log target to particular event categories. Some example categories include:</p><dl><dt>auth</dt><dd>Authorization events</dd><dt>mgmt</dt><dd>Configuration management events</dd><dt>xslt</dt><dd>XSLT processing events</dd></dl><p>For each event category chosen (including the <tt>all</tt> category), you can establish a priority level that must be met before the log message will be captured by the log target. Without event subscriptions, no events are included by default. To allow the log target to capture messages, the configuration must include at least one event subscription. The category can be the <tt>all</tt> category.</p>

object.description: <p>Log targets capture messages that are posted by the various objects and services that are running on the appliance. Target types enable additional capabilities that include rotating files, encrypting and signing files or messages, and sending files to remote servers.</p><p>Messages in log targets can be restricted (filtered) by priority, event code, event category, object type, or IP address. By default, a log target cannot accept messages until it is subscribed to one or more events.</p>

value.description: Does not use security option other than the network trust link (NTL).
value.name: none

object.description: An HA group on the SafeNet Luna Network HSM appliance allows you to define multiple Luna HSM partitions as a group for load balancing and failover.

property.summary: The name of the processing rule to invoke to retrieve the value.

property.name: CustomRuleValue
property.summary: The value to match
property.description: <p>Enter the value to match against the value that is retrieved from the named processing rule. Enter either a string that must match the outcome of the rule or enter an asterisk (*) to match any value.</p><p>When the value is a string, an identical literal string comparison result is a match. When the value is an asterisk, any value other than NULL or an empty string results in a match.</p>

A service runs an error action depending on whether or not a corresponding matching rule selects the action for processing. A service can have one policy active at a time. When an error occurs in the Multi-Protocol Gateway from an HTTP or HTTPS request flow and no precedent error handler handles the error, the service calls the error policy.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: QueueManager
property.label: Queue manager
property.summary: An IBM MQ Queue Manager name
property.hoverhelp: Specify the queue manager that manages the distributed send and receive queues of IBM MQ. The queue manager provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring or polling queues, and by ensuring that messages are directed to the correct receive queue or routed to another queue manager. The queue manager on the DataPower Gateway corresponds to a queue manager running on another host on the network.
property.description: Select a Queue Manager from the list of available Queue Managers. The queue manager provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring or polling queues, and by ensuring that messages are directed to the correct receive queue or routed to another queue manager. The queue manager on the DataPower Gateway corresponds to a queue manager running on another host on the network.

property.name: GetQueue
property.label: GET queue
property.summary: The GET queue associated with the queue manager
property.hoverhelp: Specify the GET queue associated with the queue manager. The handler will get messages from this queue.
property.description: Enter the name of the GET queue associated with the identified Queue Manager. The handler will get messages from this queue.

property.name: GetMessageOptions
property.summary: Options flags for the MQGMO structure
property.description: Specifies the cumulative value of the MQGET options that are applicable to an IBM MQ message in decimal or hex format. The value is passed directly to the IBM MQ API. The default value is 32769, which is the decimal value for the MQGMO_WAIT and MQGMO_LOGICAL_ORDER options.

property.name: ConcurrentConnections
property.summary: The number of concurrent IBM MQ conversations allocated for this source protocol handler
property.display: The number of concurrent IBM MQ conversations
property.description: The number of concurrent IBM MQ conversations allocated for this handler. The default value is 1, but it can be increased to improve performance.

property.name: PollingInterval
property.summary: The number of seconds before MQGET operation returns if no messages are available
property.label: Polling interval
property.hoverhelp: Enter the time, in seconds, before the MQGET operation returns if no message is available. The next attempt is performed immediately. Setting a low value helps to detect network connectivity issues and queue manager power shutdown but increases network traffic. The minimum value is 1. The default value is 30.
property.description: The number of seconds before MQGET operation returns if no messages are available, the next attempt will be performed immediately. Setting this value to minimum will help to detect quickly network connectivity issues and queue manager power shutdown but at the same time will increase network traffic.

property.name: RetrieveBackoutSettings
property.summary: Controls retrieval of backout settings from the IBM MQ server
property.description: <p>Controls whether to retrieve backout setting from the IBM MQ server.</p><p>When enabled, retrieves the <b>Backout Threshold</b> and <b>Backout Requeue Queue Name</b> settings from the IBM MQ server and checks these values. On a reattempt, the IBM MQ handler uses the higher priority backout settings from the server. If the server does not contain backout settings, The handler uses any existing backout values, either empty or populated, from the local IBM MQ queue manager. If there are no backout settings, the backout function is disabled.</p><p>When an alias queue is used, its attributes are retrieved, not those of the base queue.</p>

property.name: IgnoreBackoutErrors
property.summary: Controls whether to ignore backout errors
property.description: <p>Controls whether to ignore backout errors</p><p>When disabled, the default, roll back and retry the transfer.</p><p>When enabled, ignore the error in sending the transfer to the backout queue and commit the transfer from the get queue.</p>

property.name: UseQMNameInURL
property.summary: Whether to use the queue manager or the queue manager group in the front side URL
property.description: <p>Indicates whether the var://service/URL-in variable returns the name of IBM MQ Queue Manager or the name of the IBM MQ Queue Manager Group when this configuration defines a queue manager group as the queue manager.</p><ul><li>When <b>on</b>, the variable returns the name of the queue manager.</li><li>When <b>off</b>, the default, the variable returns the name of the queue manager group.</li></ul>

value.name: mq
value.summary: Use IBM MQ as the transport protocol

value.name: http
value.summary: Use HTTP as the transport protocol

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: HostName
property.summary: Host name or IP address with port
property.description: <p>Specify the host name or IP address with the listening port of the IBM MQ server where the queue manager is running. If you do not specify the port, the default is 1414.</p><p>The value depends on IP family.</p><ul><li>For IPv4 <ul><li>hostname:port -- For example, server1:1414</li><li>hostname(port) -- For example, server1(1414)</li><li>hostname -- For example, server1</li><li>address:port -- For example, 10.10.1.2:1414</li><li>address(port) -- For example, 10.10.1.2(1414)</li><li>address -- For example, 10.10.1.2</li></ul></li><li>For IPv6 <ul><li>hostname:port -- For example, server1:1414</li><li>hostname(port) -- For example, server1(1414)</li><li>hostname -- For example, server1</li><li>[address]:port -- For example, [2202::148:248]:1414</li><li>address(port) -- For example, 2202::148:248(1414)</li><li>address -- For example, 2202::148:248</li></ul></li></ul>
Specify the name of the queue manager when the queue manager is not the default on the identified host.
property.summary: Name of queue manager
property.name: QMname
CCSID
property.summary: Coded character set identifier (CCSID)
property.description: Specify the CCSID to present to the Queue Manager when the DataPower Gateway connects to it. This setting has the same effect as setting the MQCCSID environment variable for an IBM MQ client. Refer to the IBM MQ Knowledge Center for more information and a list of specific CCSID values. Unless necessary, use the default value.

property.name: ChannelName
property.summary: Name of channel connection
property.description: Specify the name of the channel to use as an alternative to the default SYSTEM.DEF.SVRCONN.

property.name: CSPUserId
property.summary: User ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter
property.description: <p>Specify the user ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.</p><p>The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the IBM MQ Queue Manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between the DataPower Gateway and the IBM MQ server.</p><p><b>Notes:</b></p><ul><li>If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, the DataPower Gateway connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings.</li><li>If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.</li><li>If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.</li></ul>

property.name: CSPPassword
property.summary: Password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter
property.description: <p>Specify the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.</p><p>The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the IBM MQ Queue Manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between DataPower and the IBM MQ server.</p><p><b>Notes:</b></p><ul><li>If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, DataPower connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings.</li><li>If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.</li><li>If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.</li></ul>

property.name: CSPPasswordAlias
property.summary: Password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter
property.description: <p>Specify the password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.</p><p>The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the IBM MQ Queue Manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between DataPower and the IBM MQ server.</p><p><b>Notes:</b></p><ul><li>If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, DataPower connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings.</li><li>If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.</li><li>If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.</li></ul>

property.name: Heartbeat
property.summary: Time between heartbeat flows
property.description: Specify the approximate time in seconds between heartbeat flows on a channel when waiting for a message on a queue. Use an integer between 0 and 999999. If 0, there will not be heartbeat flows exchanged when waiting for a message on the channel. This property does not set the heartbeat on the channel. Instead, it is used to negotiate the heartbeat value with the channel. The greater of the two values is used.

property.name: UserName
property.summary: Name that identifies this client
property.description: Specify the plaintext string to send to the server for identifying the client.

property.name: MaximumMessageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of messages to accept
property.description: Specify the maximum size in bytes of allowed messages. Use a value that is equal to or greater than the MaxMsgLength attribute of the channel and of the queue on the IBM MQ server. Messages that are bigger than this size are rejected. Use an integer between 1024 and 104857600.

property.name: CacheTimeout
property.summary: Maximum period to retain a dynamic connection in the connection cache
property.description: <p>Specify the number of seconds that the DataPower Gateway retains (keeps alive) a dynamic connection in the connection cache. Use a value that is greater than the negotiated heartbeat interval but less than the keep alive interval.</p><ul><li>The negotiated heartbeat interval is between the DataPower Gateway and the backend IBM MQ server. Use the <b>Channel Heartbeat</b> property to define the starting value for the negotiation.</li><li>The keep alive (timeout) interval is on the backend IBM MQ server. The <tt>KAINT</tt> attribute on the IBM MQ server defines the timeout value for a channel. Not all channels have a defined, explicit keep alive interval on the IBM MQ server. Some queue managers use an automatic timeout setting when the <tt>KAINT</tt> attribute set to <tt>AUTO</tt> . In these cases, the keep alive interval is the negotiated heartbeat interval plus 60 seconds.</li></ul><p>When an inactive connection reaches this threshold, the DataPower Gateway removes that dynamic connection from the cache. When the cache no longer contains dynamic connections, the DataPower Gateway deletes the dynamic queue manager. Without a dynamic queue manager, there is no connection with the backend IBM MQ server.</p><p>The timeout value for the <b>Cache Timeout</b> property is the only way to configure a timeout value from the DataPower Gateway to the backend IBM MQ server. No other configuration setting on the DataPower Gateway can time out an IBM MQ connection.</p>

property.name: UnitsOfWork
property.summary: Whether to use units-of-work
property.description: <p>When set to 0 (zero), the default, causes the DataPower Gateway to get and put messages with no provision for roll back. Either the operation succeeds or not. Undeliverable messages are silently discarded, which leaves higher level protocols with the responsibility to detect and retransmit lost packets</p><p>When set to 1, the DataPower Gateway uses synch points. A synch point commits and rolls back each IBM MQ message, not the entire transaction. When specified, the DataPower Gateway does not remove the message that it gets from a queue until it completes its transaction using that message (such as placing the message on a server queue for processing). If the transaction fails and the message is left available on the queue, the DataPower Gateway can attempt to get the message and process it again.</p><p><b>Only the values 0 (zero) or 1 are valid.</b></p>

property.name: AutomaticBackout
property.summary: Enables automatic routing of undeliverable messages
property.description: <p>Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the automatic backout of poison messages. A poison message is any message that the receiving application does not know how to process.</p><p>Usually an application rolls back the GET of this message, which leaves the message on the input queue. However, the backout count (MQMD.Backoutcount) is incremented.</p><p>As the IBM MQ Queue Manager continues to re-get the message, the backout count continues to increase. When the backout count exceeds the backout threshold, the IBM MQ Queue Manager moves the message to the backout queue.</p><p>If disabled, the poison message remains on the GET queue and continues to be reprocessed by the DataPower Gateway until the Queue Manager that manages the GET queue removes it or the DataPower Gateway reroutes the offending message. The message could be rerouted by a custom stylesheet in the request rule.</p>

property.name: BackoutThreshold
property.summary: Number of processing attempts
property.description: <p>Specify the total number of processing attempts. After this number of processing attempts fails, the following actions occur.</p><ul><li>The poison message is moved to the backout queue.</li><li>The unit of work that contains this message is committed.</li></ul><p>Enter a value that is equal to or greater than 1.</p>

property.name: BackoutQueueName
property.summary: Queue for undeliverable messages
property.description: Specify the queue to contains messages that exceeded the backout threshold. This queue must be managed by the same IBM MQ Queue Manager as the defined GET queue. The backout queue, typically SYSTEM.DEAD.LETTER.QUEUE contains messages that cannot be processed or delivered.

property.name: TotalConnectionLimit
property.summary: Total number of TCP connections
property.description: Specify the total number of open TCP connections to allow. Use an integer between 1 and 10000. The default value is 250.

property.name: InitialConnections
property.summary: Number of preallocated TCP connections
property.description: Specify the number of TCP connections to open immediately when the IBM MQ Queue Manager starts. Use an integer between 0 and 10000. The default value is 1.

property.name: SharingConversations
property.summary: Maximum number of conversations to share in a TCP connection
property.description: Specify the maximum number of conversations to share a single TCP/IP connection. Use an integer of 0 - 5000. To enable conversation sharing, specify a value that is greater than 1. A value of 0 (the default value) or 1 disables conversation sharing.

property.name: ShareSingleConversation
property.summary: Use a single shared conversation
property.description: Specifies whether to enable conversation sharing between the DataPower Gateway and the IBM MQ server when the number of shared conversations is 1.

property.name: SSLkey
property.summary: Filename of the key database
property.description: <p>Specify the location of the key database file in which keys and certificates are stored.</p><p>Use this property with the TLS Cipher property to enable TLS communication when the TLS artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit).</p><p><b>Note:</b> To integrate with IBM MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the TLS Client Profile property.</p><p>Each key database file has an associated stash file. The stash file holds encrypted passwords that allow programmatic access to the key database. The stash file must reside in the same directory as the key database file, have the same file name as the key database file, and have the <tt>.sth</tt> file extension. For example, if the key database file is <tt>MQkeys.pem</tt> or <tt>MQkeys.kidb</tt> , the stash file must be <tt>MQkeys.sth</tt> .</p><p>If these file are not on the DataPower Gateway, upload or fetch them.</p>

property.name: PermitInsecureServers
property.display: Permit Connections to Insecure TLS Servers When TLS Key Repository is used
property.description: When using TLS Key Repository, specifies whether to permit connections to IBM MQ servers that do not support RFC 5746. Such servers are vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks as documented in CVE-2009-3555. The default is off which means reject insecure connections during the TLS handshake.
When using TLS Key Repository, specifies whether to allow SSL v3 cipher to be used. The default is off which means no SSL v3 Cipher allowed.
property.name: PermitSSLv3

property.description: <p>Select the cipher suite for TLS communication when using a TLS key repository. The cipher suite must match the ciphers in use by the IBM MQ Queue Manager.</p><p>Use this property with the TLS Key Repository property to enable TLS communication when the TLS artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit).</p><p><b>Note:</b> To integrate with IBM MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the TLS Client Profile property.</p>
property.summary: Cipher suite
property.name: SSLcipher
SSLProxyProfile
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.
property.description: <p>Select a TLS Proxy Profile.</p><p>The following table maps the relationship between the TLS Cipher Specification property and the setting required on the Crypto Profile of the TLS Proxy Profile that is assigned to the IBM MQ Queue Manager. Use this information when configuring the TLS Proxy Profile to communicate with the IBM MQ Queue Manager.</p><table border="1"><tr><th>IBM MQ TLS Cipher</th><th>TLS Cipher Specification</th><th>TLS 8-SHA256</td><td>OpenSSL-default+Disable-SSLv2+Disable-SSLv3+Disable-TLSv1+Disable-TLSv1d1</td></tr><tr><td>TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA256</td><td>AES256-SHA256</td><td>OpenSSL-default+Disable-SSLv2+Disable-SSLv3+Disable-TLSv1+Disable-TLSv1d1</td></tr></table>

property.name: ConvertInput
property.summary: Enable conversion of the incoming message to the default CCSI
property.description: <p>Indicates whether the queue manager can convert input messages to a different CCSI (Coded Character Set Identifier) than the one in the incoming message. This conversion is done by the remote queue manager, not the DataPower device.</p><p>Click <b>off</b> to disable automatic conversion of incoming messages to the CCSI established for this IBM MQ Queue Manager.</p>

property.name: AutoRetry
property.summary: Advanced recovery after critical error
property.description: <p>Define whether to attempt to reconnect to remote server after a connection failure. When enabled, the DataPower Gateway automatically attempt to reconnect to the remote host. This is on by default.</p><p>This setting does not affect attempts to put or get messages over an established connection.</p>

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Specify the time interval in seconds between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host.
property.description: <p>Specify the time interval in seconds between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host. The default value is 10.</p><p>This setting does not affect attempts to PUT or GET messages over an established connection.</p>

property.name: RetryAttempts
property.summary: The number of attempts to retry the failed connections
property.description: <p>Specify the number of attempts to retry the failed connections. After the number of attempts is reached, the long interval is used. The default value is 6.</p><p>When 0, the long retry interval is not used. The retry interval is used forever.</p>

property.name: LongRetryInterval
property.summary: Long retry interval before retrying the failed connections
property.description: <p>Specify the retry interval to use after the number of retry attempts is reached. The default value is 600.</p><p>The long retry interval must be greater than the retry interval, or it will take no effect.</p>

property.name: ReportingInterval
property.summary: Log a connection failure as an error at this interval
property.description: Specify the number of seconds between the creations of log messages at the error level when failed connections are retried. This setting filters the generation of identical error messages to IBM MQ logging targets. The default value is 10.

property.name: AlternateUser
property.summary: Enables ALTERNATE_USER_AUTHORITY flag
property.description: <p>Determines whether to use the <tt>MQOD.AlternateUserId</tt> as the value of the <b>User Name</b> property.</p><p>When enabled (on), uses <tt>MQOD.AlternateUserId</tt> . When disabled, uses <tt>MQMD.UserIdentifier</tt> .</p>

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local address for channel
property.description: <p>Specify the local address for outbound connections to a specific local interface and port. Supported formats are 1.1.1.1 or 1.1.1.1(1) or just (1) to tell TCP to bind to port 1 and for a range of ports use (1,10) or 1.1.1.1(1,10).</p><p><b>Note:</b> If the port is set, the range must be greater than the total number of allowed connections.</p>

property.description: Select an XML Manager.

property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.name: SSLClient
