property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>
This property is read-only.
property.summary: This property is read-only.
property.name: UserSummary
Interface
property.summary: The network interface for the standby group.
property.description: The network interface that the standby group uses.

property.name: Group
property.summary: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.
property.description: <p>The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP).</p><p>The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration.</p><ul><li>Belong to the same group.</li><li>Use the same primary virtual IP address.</li><li>Use the same authentication, or security token.</li></ul>

property.name: VirtualIP
property.summary: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.
property.description: <p>The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: SecondaryVirtualIP
property.summary: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.
property.description: <p>Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

property.name: Preempt
property.summary: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group. <b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>
property.description: <p>Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure.</p><ul><li>When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member.</li><li>When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member.</li></ul><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>

property.name: Priority
property.summary: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.
property.description: <p>The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.</p><p>For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.</p>

property.name: SelfBalance
property.summary: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul><p>The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint.</p><ul><li>In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause.</li><li>In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.</li></ul>

property.name: Authentication
property.summary: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.
property.hoverhelp: Set the authentication string, or security token in hex. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.
property.description: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

property.name: HelloTimer
property.summary: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages.
property.hoverhelp: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40.
property.description: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.

property.name: HoldTimer
property.summary: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.
property.hoverhelp: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120.
property.description: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.

property.name: DistAlg
property.summary: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.
property.description: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.

object.description: <p>The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

A list of processing rules their corresponding matching rule that this policy will evaluate. If a match is found, the corresponding processing rule is run. The policy runs the first processing rule with a successful match. Therefore, the order of rules in this list is important.
property.name: PolicyMaps

object.description: Create, Edit or Delete a Processing Policy. A policy consists of one or more Processing Rules. Rules execute depending upon the direction of the message and on whether or not a corresponding matching rule selects the document for processing. A service may have only one policy active at a time. Click Services in the left-hand navigation menu and then click the appropriate policy link to use the graphical interface to create and edit policies.

value.description: Performs schema-based validation against XML documents using a user-specified method.
value.name: validate

value.description: Accepts or rejects check on incoming documents.
value.name: filter

value.display: Route using Stylesheet or XPath Expression
value.description: Performs stylesheet-based routing or XPath expression-based routing. For stylesheet-based routing, provide the dynamic stylesheet that specifies the destination. For XPath expression-based routing, provide the XPath Routing Map that specifies the destination.
value.name: route-action

value.description: Invokes an Access control policy. An access control policy identifies a set of resources and procedures that determine whether a requesting client is granted access to a specific service, file, or document. Access control policies are filters in that they accept or deny requests for specific clients.
value.name: aaa

value.description: Uses a processing instruction in an XML document to transform that XML document. This action passes embedded parameters to the specified XSLT stylesheet. The stylesheets and parameters are embedded in the document to be processed.
value.name: xformpi

value.description: Transforms a non-XML document, such as binary or flat text, using an XSL stylesheet. The stylesheet, in turn, uses a flat file descriptor (FFD) file.
value.name: xformbin

value.description: Signs, verifies, encrypts, or decrypts binary data. This action uses the syntax and methodologies described in RFC 2311, S/MIME Version 2 Message Specification, dated March, 1988, and RFC 2315, PKCS #7: Cryptographic Message Syntax 1.5, dated March, 1998.
value.name: cryptobin

value.description: Transforms an XML document using a specified XSLT stylesheet.
value.name: xform

value.description: Converts non-XML CGI-encoded input (an HTTP POST, an HTML form, or URI parameters) into an equivalent XML message. This action in the active rule alerts the service to treat input as non-XML CGI-encoded input. For a service to use this action, the request type for that service must be set to XML.
value.name: convert-http

value.description: Sends the contents of the input context as a log message to the identified location. The contents are sent with the log level and log type that are specified. The response, if any, is stored in the output context, if defined. When no output context is defined, this action sends the contents and does not wait for a response.
value.name: log

value.description: Sends a message to a URL. A results action can optionally specify a context in which to store the response.
value.name: results

value.description: Asynchronously sends a message to a URL. This action does not support sending a message to an output context. With this action, processing continues without waiting for a response.
value.name: results-async

value.description: Creates a variable for use in subsequent processing in a specified context. Variables are expressed in the var://URL format. Variables cannot be set when the context is the PIPE keyword.
value.name: setvar

value.description: Uses a user agent to retrieve a document from a specified location.
value.name: fetch

value.description: Applies an XPath expression to a specified context and stores the result in another context.
value.name: extract

value.description: Rewrites HTTP headers or URLs using a URL rewrite policy.
value.name: rewrite

value.description: Performs dynamic, variable-based routing.
value.name: route-set

value.description: Removes all or specified MIME attachments from a specified context.
value.name: strip-attachments

value.description: Invokes a named, reusable rule. After the action completes, processing continues to the next action, if any.
value.name: call

value.description: <p>Defines a named rule that enables user-defined error handling when subsequent processing encounters errors. The on-error action either stops processing or continues to the next processing step. Optional, the action calls the named rule to handle the error condition. Without an on-error action, the default error handling is to stop processing and log a message.</p><p>A processing rule can contain one or more on-error actions. Each action defines error handling for subsequent actions until another on-error action is found. When another action is found, error-handling procedures are set to the new on-error action. As such, this action enables conditional error handling in a procssing context.</p><p>Note that a processing policy can contain on-error actions and an error rule. When a processing policy contains both on-error actions and an error rule, the on-error action overrides the error rule. An error rule, if the processing policy contains one, is invoked when an error occurs during processing. In this case, the error rule acts as an error handler.</p>
value.name: on-error

value.description: Collects information for WS-Management agents and Service Level Monitors.
value.name: checkpoint

value.description: Assigns and enforces an SLM Policy Statement to a processing rule. The SLM Policy operates on the Input context.
value.name: slm

value.description: Establishes a connection to a configured database and runs SQL statements against the configured SQL data source. The results can be used for further processing.
value.name: sql

value.description: Evaluates a list of XPath expressions against the input context, and then runs the action that is associated with the first one that matches.
value.name: conditional

value.description: Loops through either all of the nodes in a nodeset or otherwise all of the natural numbers through the upper count limit. For each loop iteration, it runs the LoopAction.
value.name: for-each

value.description: Looks through the list of named actions and waits for each of them to complete asynchronously in this session at least once. Once they all have, then if any of them failed, then this action will fail with one of their errors. If they all eventually finish and succeeded, then this action will succeed, and control flow will continue. If this instruction times out while waiting for them to all finish (or even to be started), then this instruction will fail. This instruction can not be Asynchronous, it is inherently part of synchronous processing of asynchronous actions.
value.name: event-sink

value.description: Rewrites the HTTP method to a new method type.
value.name: method-rewrite
value.summary: Add an HTTP method rewrite action

value.description: Transforms an input document (XML or non-XML, such as binary or flat text), using an optional processing control file.
value.name: xformng

value.description: Executes a GatewayScript
value.name: gatewayscript

value.description: Sign a message using JSON Web Signature standard
value.name: jose-sign
value.summary: Add a JSON Web Sign action

value.summary: Process the map provided in exported files

value.description: <p>This option is only valid with maps that have exactly one input card and one output card. Further, the type of at least one of the cards must have XML intent. Note that, while legal, if both cards have XML intent, this option disables all transformation, which effectively makes the map an identity transform.</p><p>If the input is non-XML, the input TypeTree alone is used to transform the input to an XML representation of the underlying binary format. That XML representation is then be sent directly to the output context without transformation. Note that the format of the XML representation corresponds to the <i>input</i> TypeTree and might not match the XML format described by the output TypeTree.</p><p>If the output is non-XML, the output TypeTree alone is used to transform the XML input to the output binary format. Note that the format of the XML input must correspond to the <i>output</i> TypeTree and might not match the XML format described by the input TypeTree.</p><p>The XML format produced or consumed by the binary-to-XML transformation corresponds directly to the relevant input or output TypeTree, where each ITEM or GROUP is represented by an element whose name is the absolute name of the type. Spaces are replaced by two dashes and other non-NCName characters are escaped as "-nn-", where nn is the decimal value of the character's code-point without leading zeros. If the first character in the name, after any escaping, is not an XML letter or underscore, the name is preceded by an underscore. Therefore, a Type named <tt>Foo Bar Root</tt> corresponds to an element named <tt>Foo--Bar--Root</tt> , a Type named <tt>Foo_Bar Baz? Root</tt> corresponds to an element named <tt>Foo_Bar--Baz-63---Root</tt> , and a Type named <tt>#93 Root</tt> corresponds to an element named <tt>_-35-93--Root</tt> .</p><p>Only concrete, or unpartitioned, ITEM or GROUP is represented in the XML format. When a binary input ITEM or GROUP is partitioned, the XML representation that is produced has an element corresponding to the actual partition that is seen in the input, not the partitioned base type. When a binary output ITEM or GROUP is partitioned, the input XML must contain an element that corresponds to the actual partition to produce, not the partitioned base type.</p>
value.name: no-map
value.summary: Process only input/output TypeTrees without mapping logic

value.description: Processes map in DPA file without special options. The map file must be a map file that was created in Design Studio with the DataPower option and must be compiled in Design Studio before it is transferred to the DataPower Gateway. The map file has the .dpa file extension.

property-group.description: There are three pieces of the Parse Settings. <ul><li><b>Default</b>: A static Parse Settings object for defaults.</li><li><b>Literal</b>: A literal XML or JSON string with overrides. Use this to avoid duplicating static objects when there's only a small change.</li><li><b>URL</b>: A URL to XML or JSON definition of dynamic override properties.</li></ul>
property-group.name: parsesettings
property-group.summary: The static and dynamic pieces of the parse settings.

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Type
property.summary: Action
property.description: Select an action to be performed by the processing rule. The default is Transform.

property.name: Input
property.summary: The target context
property.description: Input identifies the context that contains the document acted upon by this action. Enter the context name or string PIPE used for streaming execution mode, or the string INPUT which identifies the original input into this policy rule. <p>Not used when the action type is rewrite, method-rewrite, or route-set and otherwise required.</p>

property.name: Transform
property.summary: Location of the XSL stylesheet or transform file
property.description: <p>Specify the location of the XSL stylesheet or transform file to use for document filtering or transformations. Specify the location with one of the following formats: <ul><li>Use a URL, for example, <tt>store:///myTest.xsl</tt></li><li>Use a context variable that expands to a URL, for example, <tt>var://context/contextName/varName</tt></li><li>Use a context, for example, <tt>var://context/Name</tt> or <tt>var://context/Name/</tt> . The context runs as a stylesheet.</li></ul></p>

property.name: ParseSettingsReference
property.summary: Use any or all of the following ways to define the parse settings configuration for the parse action.
property.description: A parse settings configuration defines the constraints on the documents to parse. You can configure the constraints by specifying a URL reference from which to retrieve the constraints definition. You can also specify a literal configuration string in XML management interface or REST management interface format that contains the constraints definition. You can also select a parse settings configuration object from the list in Object reference to retrieve constraints definition. Precedence rules apply when the constraint for the same aspect of an input document is configured with more than one method.

property.name: ParseMetricsResultType
property.summary: Specifies the language format to save the parse metrics results
property.description: Specifies the language format to save the parse metrics results.

property.name: ParseMetricsResultLocation
property.summary: Specifies the name of the context to save parse metrics results
property.description: When "XML" or "JSON" is specified for parse metrics result type, the parse metrics results are saved in the specified context in the requested language format.

property.name: DFDLSettingsReference
property.summary: Specify the DFDL Settings to use when processing binary content with DFDL schemas.
property.description: Identifies the DFDL Settings used by this action when processing data as understood by a DFDL schema. This reference, if provided, overrides the reference on the XML manager. If no DFDL Settings are specified on both objects, the default values are applied.

property.name: InputLanguage
property.summary: Language of input to the transformation

property.name: DFDLInputRootName
property.summary: Set the root element in the DFDL model from which to start a parse.
property.description: <p>Set the root element in the DFDL model from which to start a parse. This property is only meaningful in the context of a DFDL parse.</p><p>For the input root name, specify the global xsd:element in the XSD file to use to begin parsing the binary input. The input root name can be selected from the specified XSD file or specified as a variable. If a variable is used, it must resolve to a valid namespace URL written with the name between braces ({}) as a prefix to the local part.</p><p>For instance, if in the DFDL Schema, the target namespace is "http://example.com/messages" and the local element is &lt;xsd:element name="Message">...&lt;/xsd:element>, the variable must resolve to {http://example.com/messages}Message.</p><p>The schema author might specify the root parse element by using the ibmSchExtn:docRoot="true" element within the schema. For instance, &lt;xsd:element ibmSchExtn:docRoot="true" name="Message">...&lt;/xsd:element>. In this case, the input root name shows in the selection as the element name followed by (@ibmSchExtn:docRoot="true"). Use of another value for the DFDL input root name overrides the value that is specified in the schema.</p>

property.name: InputDescriptor
property.summary: Descriptor of the input to the transformation as understood according to the input language
property.description: <p>Specify the input descriptor, understood according to the input language.</p><ul><li>If input language is DFDL, the input descriptor must be a URL to a schema file that defines the input. The input descriptor can be a URL to a directory from which you can select a schema file, or the input descriptor can be a variable that resolves to a schema at run time.</li><li>If input language is XML, do not specify an input descriptor because the input is not type-assessed.</li><li>If input language is XSD, the input descriptor must be a URL to an XML schema for type assessing the input to the transformation.</li><li>If input language is JSON, do not specify an input descriptor because the input is not type-assessed.</li></ul>

property.name: OutputDescriptor
property.summary: Descriptor of the output from the transformation as understood according to the output language
property.description: Specify the output descriptor, understood according to the output language. If output language is DFDL, then output descriptor must be a URL to a DFDL schema for serializing the output from the transformation.

property.name: TransformLanguage
property.summary: Language of the transformation
property.description: <p>Specifies that the transform is specified either as an XQuery file or as None to indicate an identity transformation that is only changing the message via input or output descriptors.</p><ul><li>If transform language is None, do not specify a Transform.</li><li>If transform language is XQuery, then specify a way to find that XQuery script in the Transform property.</li></ul>

property.name: OutputLanguage
property.summary: Language of output from the transformation
property.description: <p>Specify the output language, to Default or DFDL.</p>

property.name: TxMap
property.summary: Location of Transformation Extender map file
property.description: <p>Enter the URL of the IBM Transformation Extender map file for the transform. You must create the map file by exporting the file from Design Studio. In DPA mode, the generated map file is hosted locally on the DataPower Gateway or on a remote HTTP or HTTPS server. Use one of the following formats.</p><ul><li>When the file is local, use &lt;directory>:///&lt;file></li><li>When the file is remote, use HTTP://&lt;path_qualified_file> or HTTPS://&lt;path_qualified_file></li></ul><p>Do not specify an XSL stylesheet when you use a map file.</p>

property.name: GatewayScriptLocation
property.summary: Location of the GatewayScript file
property.description: <p>Specify the location of the GatewayScript file. The file location can be specified in one of the following formats.</p><ul><li>Use a URL. Select the local:, store:, or temporary: directory, and select, upload, or fetch the script file.</li><li>Use a context variable that expands to a URL, such as <tt>var://context/contextName/varName</tt> .</li><li>Use a context, for example, <tt>var://context/Name</tt> or <tt>var://context/Name/</tt> . The context content runs as GatewayScript.</li></ul>

property.name: ActionDebug
property.summary: Enable GatewayScript Debug

property.name: TxTopLevelMap
property.summary: Name of the Transformation Extender map to run
property.description: Enter the name of the specific IBM Transformation Extender map in the map file for the transform. A map file might contain more than one map. When not specified, the transform uses the first map in the file.

property.name: TxMode
property.summary: Transformation Extender mode in which to run the map
property.description: Select the IBM Transformation Extender mode in which to run the map. DPA is the recommended mode.

property.name: TxAuditLog
property.summary: The context name to save the Transformation Extender audit log
property.description: Enter the context name to save the IBM Transformation Extender audit log. This property is valid only in DPA mode.

property.name: Output
property.summary: The destination context
property.description: Output identifies the destination context that receives the document upon completion of the specified action. Enter the context name or string PIPE used for streaming execution mode (except for the last action), or the string OUTPUT which identifies the final input output from this policy rule. Depending on the rule's direction, OUTPUT specifies the transmission to the requesting client or responding server. If the action type is results, and no output is specified, the target context is transmitted to OUTPUT.

property.name: NoTranscodeUtf8
property.summary: Whether the output from the convert action retains the input encoding or uses ISO 8859-1
property.description: Control whether the output from the convert action retains the input encoding or is converted to ISO 8859-1. An encoding is also known as a character set. For illustrative purposes, assume UTF-8 is the input encoding. <ul><li>When enabled and the input encoding is UTF-8, the output is UTF-8.</li><li>When disabled and the input encoding is UTF-8, the output is ISO 8859-1. This behavior is the default behavior.</li></ul>

property.name: NamedInOutLocationType
property.summary: Locate Named Inputs and Outputs
property.description: Named Inputs and Outputs can be specified explicitly or dynamically, or can default to the unnamed regular input and output. Select the value appropriate for your IBM Transformation Extender configuration.

property.name: NamedInputs
property.summary: Create all of the named inputs needed for the Transformation Extender transform.
property.description: Create all of the named inputs that are needed for the IBM Transformation Extender transform.

property.name: NamedOutputs
property.summary: Create all of the named outputs needed for the Transformation Extender transform.
property.description: Create all of the named outputs that are needed for the IBM Transformation Extender transform.

property.name: Destination
property.summary: A remote URL
property.description: <p>Specify the location of the resource (source or destination). Specify the location as either a URL or as a variable that expands to a URL. If a variable, use the var://context/name form.</p><p>Required for a fetch, log, results-async, or route-set action. Optional for a results action. When not defined for a results action, the input context is written to the output context. Not used for all other actions.</p><ul><li>For fetch, specify the source.</li><li>For route-set, specify the destination.</li><li>For log, results, and results-async, specify the destination (a foreign server to which to send the data).</li></ul>

property.name: SchemaURL
property.summary: An XML schema
property.description: <p>Used only when the action type is validate, identifies an XML schema used for document validation regardless of any <tt>xsi:schemaLocation</tt> attributes contained with the document. Identify the schema with one of the following formats.</p><ul><li>Use a URL, for example, <tt>store:///valHigh.xsd</tt></li><li>Use a context variable that expands to a URL, for example, <tt>var://context/contextName/varName</tt></li><li>Use a context, for example, <tt>var://context/Name</tt> or <tt>var://context/Name/</tt> . The context runs as a schema validation.</li></ul>

property.name: JSONSchemaURL
property.summary: A JSON schema
property.description: <p>Used only when the action type is validate, identifies a JSON schema used for JSON document validation. Identify the schema with one of the following formats.</p><ul><li>Use a URL, for example, <tt>local:///valHigh.jsv</tt></li><li>Use a context variable that expands to a URL, for example, <tt>var://context/contextName/varName</tt></li><li>Use a context, for example, <tt>var://context/Name</tt> or <tt>var://context/Name/</tt> . The context runs as a JSON schema validation.</li></ul>

property.name: WsdlURL
property.summary: The URL of the WSDL file
property.description: <p>The URL of the WSDL file that defines the operations to use during the validate action. The WSDL file can reside on the local system or on the network. By default, the WSDL validation always applies to the entire input message. This can be modified by compile options on the XML manager.</p><p>Identify the WSDL with one of the following formats.</p><ul><li>Use a URL, for example, <tt>local:///myTest.wsdl</tt></li><li>Use a context variable that expands to a URL, for example, <tt>var://context/contextName/varName</tt></li><li>Use a context, for example, <tt>var://context/Name</tt> or <tt>var://context/Name/</tt> . The context runs as a WSDL validation.</li></ul>

property.name: Policy
property.summary: A URL Rewrite Policy
property.description: Specifies the URL rewrite policy to change the active URL of the current transaction.

property.name: AAA
property.summary: AAA policy to use
property.description: Select an AAA Policy to assign the authentication and authorization policy to the DataPower service.

property.name: DynamicSchema
property.summary: A dynamic schema
property.description: Select a dynamic schema from the values list.

property.name: DynamicStylesheet
property.summary: Dynamic stylesheet
property.description: Specifies the dynamic stylesheet to transform an input document.

property.name: InputConversion
property.summary: An HTTP Input Conversion Map
property.description: Select an HTTP Input Conversion Map that provides encoding rules.

property.name: XPath
property.summary: An XPath expression
property.description: Specifies the XPath expression that is applied to the context identified by Input. Enter the XPath expression or a variable in the form var://context/name which expands to an XPath expression.

property.name: Variable
property.summary: Create a variable
property.description: <p>Enter the variable URL, in one of the following forms. <ul><li>var://context/CONTEXT-NAME/VAR-NAME</li><li>var://local/VAR-NAME</li><li>var://system/CONTEXT-NAME/VAR-NAME</li><li>var://service/SERVICE-NAME</li></ul></p><p>var://context/CONTEXT-NAME/VAR-NAME is the primary way to reference variables. var://context/CONTEXT-NAME/_roottree is a special variable that holds the value of the context when used as an input to an action. var://context/CONTEXT-NAME (or var://context/CONTEXT-NAME/) is treated as shorthand for var://context/CONTEXT-NAME/_roottree.</p><p>var://local/VAR-NAME can be used to reference variables in the Input context for this action (when reading the variable) or in the Output context for this action (when writing the variable). Because this reference is context-sensitive, The use of var://context/CONTEXT-NAME/VAR-NAME is recommended.</p><p>var://system/CONTEXT-NAME/VAR-NAME is used to reference global variables. These variables are rarely used.</p><p>var://service/SERVICE-NAME is used to reference certain internal state variables. These variables are defined by the firmware and cannot be created by users. Refer to the manuals or the resource CD for details.</p>

property.name: Asynchronous
property.summary: Marks this action as asynchronous
property.description: Marks this action as asynchronous. It will not need to complete for the next action to begin.

property.name: Condition
property.summary: XPath condition to check and action to run if it is found.
property.description: A single condition which maps an XPath condition to search for in the input context to an action to run if it is found. If it is not found, then other conditions can be checked.

property.name: ResultsMode
property.summary: How to handle multiple results targets
property.description: <p>Specify whether to use the first available target from the target list or to try to send to all targets. If "first-available", the action sends to potential targets one at a time, and stops with success when the input has been sent to any single target. If "require-all", the action sends to all of the potential targets, and fails if any one of the targets fails. If "attempt-all", the action succeeds even if some or all of the targets fail.</p>

property.name: RetryCount
property.summary: Number of times to retry the operation
property.description: <p>If connecting to a target fails, the connection attempt may be retried after an interval. This indicates the number of retry attempts; the default is 0, which indicates that the operation fails immediately if the connection fails.</p>

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Time between operation retries
property.description: <p>If connecting to a target fails, the connection attempt may be retried after an interval. This indicates the time between retries in milliseconds. The default value is 1000.</p>

property.name: MultipleOutputs
property.summary: Place parallel outputs into separate contexts
property.description: <p>A results action can target several targets simultaneously by specifying a variable containing an XML node-set as the results target. If this option is true, the context named as the output context of the action is ignored, but the status of individual attempts to reach the targets are recorded in separate contexts by appending a number to the provided name, resulting in context names such as "ctx_1" for an output context name of "ctx". If this option is false, only one result is kept: in require-all mode, it is the first target to have failed and have no retries left, or the last target on success; in attempt-all mode, the last target to be attempted; in first-available mode, the first target to succeed or the last failing target.</p>

property.name: IteratorType
property.summary: Type of iterator, an XPath expression or a loop count
property.description: Specify the type of the iterator. It will either be an XPath expression or a number designating the number of times to execute the loop.

property.name: IteratorExpression
property.summary: Iterator to operate on: an XPath expression
property.description: An XPath expression defining the content to iterate on.

property.name: IteratorCount
property.summary: Number of times to run the loop action
property.description: Specify the number of times to run the loop action. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32768.

property.name: LoopAction
property.summary: The action to execute within the loop

property.name: AsyncAction
property.summary: List of asynchronous actions to wait for

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: The time in milliseconds to wait for asynchronous actions to complete
property.description: Wait for this number of milliseconds for listed asynchronous actions to complete. Time out after this period and raise an error. Enter 0 to wait forever.

property.name: WSDLPortQName
property.summary: Validate messages from a specific wsdl:port
property.description: The QName of the WSDL port that defines the service traffic to validate. The value should be a QName in the form "{namespace-uri}local-part" or "*" for all ports that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for the named port are considered valid.

property.name: WSDLOperationName
property.summary: Validate messages that match the specified wsdl:operation
property.description: The name of the WSDL operation that defines the service traffic to validate. The value should be the unqualified name of the operation or "*" for all operations that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for operations that match the specified name are considered valid.

property.name: WSDLMessageDirectionOrName
property.summary: Validate messages from wsdl:input, wsdl:output, or wsdl:faults that match the given name or direction
property.description: <p>The name or direction of the WSDL input, output, or fault that defines the service traffic to validate. Use one of the following values.</p><ul><li>The name of one or more WSDL input, output, or fault components.</li><ul><li><tt><i>operation</i> Request</tt> for a specific request.</li><li><tt><i>operation</i> Response"</tt> for a specific response.</li><li>The value of the <tt>name</tt> attribute for the <tt>&lt;fault></tt> element.</li></ul><li><tt>#input</tt> for the request direction in the WSDL file.</li><li><tt>#output</tt> for the response direction in the WSDL file.</li><li><tt>*</tt> for all inputs, outputs, and faults in the WSDL file.</li></ul><p>When specified and not *, only messages that are defined for inputs, outputs, and faults that match the specified name or direction are considered valid. Faults are considered valid for the response direction.</p>

property.name: WSDLAttachmentPart
property.summary: Validate messages defined by mime:content in the WSDL that match the specified message part name
property.description: The name of the WSDL message part that defines the content of a MIME attachment (mime:content/@part). The value should be the unqualified name of the message part. The name is the same as the part attribute on the corresponding mime:content component in the WSDL file. When this property is not defined or has the special value "*", the root MIME part is validated. The root MIME part is bound to a soap:body.

property.description: <p>Select whether the Access Manager client uses Microsoft Active Directory instead of LDAP as the registry. The default registry for an Access Manager deployment is LDAP. This selection will cause this client to use Microsoft Active Directory. Active Directory type is not supported after ISAM 7.0 .</p><p><b>Note:</b> The type of registry that an Access Manager deployment supports is determined by the configuration of the Access Manager server. The registry that you define in this configuration is for a client and must match the registry of the server.</p>
<p>Select the Access Manager client version to use. The default value is 9.0.3.</p>
property.summary: The version of the Access Manager client
property.name: TAMVersion
ConfigurationFile
property.summary: Location of the configuration file for the Access Manager client
property.description: Select the location of the configuration file for the Access Manager client. To be available for selection, files must have .conf or .cfg as their file extension.

property.name: ADConfigurationFile
property.summary: Location of the configuration file for user directories
property.description: Select the location of the configuration file for user directories. To be available for selection, files must have .conf or .cfg as their file extension.

property.name: SSLKeyFile
property.summary: Location of the TLS key file
property.description: Select the location of the key file for TLS communication. To be available for selection, files must have .kdb as their file extension. Generally, these files are in the cert: directory or the sharedcert: directory.

property.name: SSLKeyStashFile
property.summary: Location of the TLS key stash file
property.description: Select the location of the key stash file for TLS communication. To be available for selection, files must have .sth as their file extension. Generally, these files are in the cert: directory or the sharedcert: directory.

property.name: UseLocalMode
property.summary: Use the policy database that is cached locally instead of accessed remotely
property.description: Select whether to create a local copy of the policy database. Set this property to cache the policy database locally instead of accessing the remote policy server. This property must match the behavior defined in the configuration files for the Access Manager client.

property.name: PollInterval
property.summary: Refresh interval for the local policy database
property.description: Enter the interval between requests to update the local policy database from the remote policy server. <ul><li><b>default</b> - Uses the default value, which is 600 seconds.</li><li><b>disable</b> - Disables requests to the policy database for requests.</li><li><i>seconds</i> - Specifies the time interval in seconds.</li></ul>

property.name: ListenMode
property.summary: Whether the DataPower Gateway accepts update notifications from the policy server
property.description: Select whether to accept notifications to update the local policy database from the policy server. When you set this property, it overrides the behavior defined in configuration files for the Access Manager client.

property.name: ListenPort
property.summary: Listening port for update notifications from the policy server
property.description: Enter the listening port on the DataPower Gateway to receive update notifications from the remote policy server.

property.name: ReturningUserAttributes
property.summary: Whether the registry returns user attributes.
property.description: Select whether the registry returns users attributes for successful authorization requests. When set, the registry returns user attributes.

property.name: LDAPUseSSL
property.summary: Whether to use TLS communication with the registry
property.description: Select whether to use TLS communication between the Access Manager client and the LDAP or Active Directory server.

property.name: LDAPSSLPort
property.summary: Listening port for TLS communication on the LDAP server
property.description: Enter the listening port that the LDAP server uses for TLS communication. This property does not apply for TLS communication with an Active Directory server.

property.name: LDAPSSLKeyFile
property.summary: Location of the key file with the certificates for TLS communication with the registry server
property.description: <p>Select the location of the key file that contains the certificates for TLS communication with the registry server.</p><ul><li>For server-only authentication, the key file must contain the signer certificate for the registry server.</li><li>For mutual authentication, the key file must also contain a personal certificate that the registry server can validate. If the personal certificate is not the default personal certificate in the key file, you must enter the label of the personal certificate.</li></ul><p>This file must be in the cert: or the sharedcert: directory.</p>

property.name: LDAPSSLKeyFilePassword
property.summary: Password for the key file for TLS communication with the registry server.
property.display: Registry Server TLS Key File Password (deprecated)
property.description: Enter the password for the key file that contains the certificates for TLS communication with the registry server.

property.name: LDAPSSLKeyFilePasswordAlias
property.summary: Password alias of the password for the key file for TLS communication with the registry server.
property.display: Registry Server TLS Key File Password Alias
property.description: Enter the password alias of the password for the key file that contains the certificates for TLS communication with the registry server.

property.name: LDAPSSLKeyFileLabel
property.summary: Label of the personal certificate in the key file for client authentication
property.display: Registry Server TLS Key File Label
property.description: <p>Enter the label of the personal certificate in the key file for client authentication.</p><ul><li>When using mutual authentication with the registry server and the personal certificate is not the default personal certificate in the key file, enter the label of the personal certificate. The personal certificate allows client authentication.</li><li>For server-only authentication, do not enter a value.</li></ul>

property.name: TAMUseFIPS
property.summary: Whether secure communication runs in FIPS mode
property.description: Select whether the secure communication between the Access Manager client and the authorization server runs in FIPS mode.

property.name: TAMChooseNIST
property.summary: Which compliance mode to use
property.description: In FIPS mode, there is a mandatory NIST compliance level to select. Select a level that is compatible with the corresponding Access Manager servers and registry servers. Note that the NIST and NSA options are available only in Access Manager versions 7.0 and later.

property.name: TAMUseBasicUser
property.summary: Whether to support basic users in the client
property.description: Control whether to support basic users in the client. When enabled, you can use LDAP user entries for authentication or authorization without importing them into the ISAM domain.

property.name: UserPrincipalAttribute
property.summary: The attribute that identifies the basic user in the LDAP user entry
property.description: Specify the attribute that identifies the basic user in the LDAP user entry. The default value is uid.

property.name: UserNoDuplicates
property.summary: Whether to allow duplicate principals
property.description: <p>Control whether to allow duplicate principals.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the search for basic users covers all suffixes to ensure that no users with the same name are found. If duplicate principals are found in this client, the system returns an error.</li><li>When disabled, the search for basic users ignores possible duplicates. By default, duplicate principals are not allowed.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSearchSuffixes
property.summary: The LDAP suffixes to be searched for principals
property.description: <p>Specify the ordered list of LDAP suffixes to be searched for principals. When specified and suffix optimization is disabled, the suffixes are searched in entry order. If suffix optimization is enabled, this order is overridden by the suffix optimization order.</p><p>If you do not specify any suffixes, the system searches all available suffixes.</p>

property.name: UserSuffixOptimiser
property.summary: Whether to search the suffixes in an optimized order
property.description: <p>Control whether to search the suffixes in an optimized order.</p><ul><li>When enabled and uplicate principals are allowed, the suffixes are searched in an optimized order based on hit count, with the most hit of the suffix at the head of the search suffix list. This can help reduce the number of suffixes searched. If duplicate principals are not allowed, the suffix optimization setting is disregarded and all suffixes are searched to check for duplicates.</li><li>When disabled, the search order is provided by the order that is defined by the search suffixes property.</li></ul>

property.name: TAMFedDirs
property.summary: List of LDAP federated directories
property.description: Specify a list of federated directories. Each entry describes a unique set of LDAP suffixes and LDAP server. Federated directories define all the suffixes that can be searched for user identities.

property.name: TAMAZReplicas
property.summary: List of remote authorization servers
property.description: <p>Replicas indicate the network location of remote authorization servers. You must configure at least one replica. You can configure additional replicas for failover purposes.</p><p><b>Note:</b> If you uploaded a file that was created previously, it must define at least one replica.</p>

<p>Trace logging is a useful debugging tool. By default, trace logging is not enabled. Trace logging collects large amounts of data in a short amount of time and might result in a significant performance degradation. Enable trace logging only at the direction of IBM Support.</p><p>When enabled, the DataPower Gateway creates two trace files for each library. The DataPower Gateway writes the files cyclically. Double the size of the files to obtain the total allowable file size.</p>
property.name: TAMRASTrace
AutoRetry
property.summary: Whether to attempt starting the client after an initial failure
property.description: <p>Select whether to attempt starting the Access Manager client after an initial failure. The DataPower Gateway automatically attempts to start the client after a critical error. This property controls the behavior after the initial attempt to restart.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the DataPower Gateway attempts to start the client with the defined configuration.</li><li>When disabled, the client is marked as <tt>down</tt> .</li></ul><p>The default behavior is to not attempt to start the client after an initial failure.</p>

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Interval to wait between attempts to start the client.
property.description: <p>Enter the number of seconds to wait between attempts to start the Access Manager client. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 180.</p>

property.name: RetryAttempts
property.summary: Number of attempts before using the long attempt interval.
property.description: Enter the number of attempts to perform for the Access Manager client. After performing these attempts and the client did not start, each additional attempt waits the number of seconds defined by the long interval. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. A value of 0 disables the long interval. The default value is 3.

property.name: LongRetryInterval
property.summary: Long attempt interval before trying the failed connection again
property.description: Specifies the number of seconds to wait after reaching the number of retry attempts. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 900.

object.description: <p>A DataPower Gateway can support multiple IBM Security Access Manager registry types: LDAP or Microsoft Active Directory. Support for the registry type is established for each Access Manager client that starts according to its configuration.</p>

value.description: A service or transaction assigned this priority setting will receive above normal scheduling priority and resource allocation.
value.name: high

value.description: A service or transaction assigned this priority setting will receive normal scheduling priority and resource allocation.
value.name: normal

value.description: A service or transaction assigned this priority setting will receive below normal scheduling priority and resource allocation.
value.name: low

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Enter the local IP address or host alias.
property.description: <p>Enter a host alias or the IP address that the service listens on. Host aliases can ease migration tasks among appliances.</p><ul><li>0 or 0.0.0.0 indicates all configured IPv4 addresses.</li><li>:: indicates all configured IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.</li></ul><p><b>Attention:</b> For management services, the value of 0.0.0.0 or :: is a security risk. Use an explicit IP address to isolate management traffic from application data traffic.</p>
A descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.name: UserSummary

property.description: Control the service scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority services will be favored over lower priority services.

property.name: Priority
LocalPort
property.summary: The TCP port number
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535) that specifies the port monitored by the TCP proxy

Specify the host name or IP address of the remote host for which this proxy is accepting TCP traffic. TCP traffic sent to the proxy will in turn be sent to this host. Click Ping to verify connectivity.
property.summary: Host name or IP address
property.name: RemoteAddress
RemotePort
property.summary: Port number
property.description: Specify the port number of the remote host, specify with Remote Host, for which this proxy is accepting TCP traffic.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Maximum idle time
property.description: Specify the maximum idle time that is allowed for the front side connection and the server side connection. After the time is reached, the idle connections are terminated. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The default value is 360. A value of 0 disables the idle timer.

object.description: Creates a TCP Proxy service.

value.description: The Tivoli Federated Identity Manager endpoint is acting as a token mapping service.

value.description: <p>Use the following namespace for all LTPA token versions:</p><ul><li>http://www.ibm.com/websphere/appserver/tokentype/5.0.2/#LTPA</li></ul>

object.name: TFIMEndpoint

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: mEndpointType
property.summary: TFIM endpoint type
property.description: Specify the endpoint type configured on the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager server.

property.name: mServerURL
property.summary: Host name or IP address
property.description: Specify the domain-qualified host name or IP address of the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager server.

property.name: mServerPort
property.summary: Port number
property.description: Specify the listening port on the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager server.

property.name: mCompatibleMode
property.summary: Compatibility Mode
property.description: <p>Select the currently configured version of Tivoli Federated Identity Manager. The selected value determines the details for the namespace and WS-Trust messages.</p><ul><li>For versions 6.0 or 6.1, version 1.2 of the WS-Trust specification is used.</li><li>For version 6.2, version 1.3 of the WS-Trust specification is used, which corresponds to the "Validate OASIS URI" Request Type. Version 6.2 also supports WS-Trust 1.2. <p><b>Note:</b> To use WS-Trust 1.2 messages with a TFIM version 6.2 server, use 6.1 as the compatibility mode. On a TFIM version 6.2 server, this corresponds to the "Validate" Request Type.</p></li></ul>

property.name: mReqToken60Format
property.summary: Request Token Format for version 6.0.1
property.description: Select the format of the request token when using Tivoli Federated Identity Manager version 6.0.1.

property.name: mReqToken61Format
property.summary: Request Token Format for version 6.1
property.description: Select the format of the request token when using Tivoli Federated Identity Manager version 6.1.

property.name: mReqToken62Format
property.summary: Request Token Format for version 6.2
property.description: Select the format of the request token when using Tivoli Federated Identity Manager version 6.2.

property.name: mReqCustomURL
property.summary: Custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file for request.
property.description: When Request Token Format is Custom, upload the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file to the DataPower Gateway. The custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file must be in the local: or store: directory.

property.name: mAppliesToAddress
property.summary: TFIM Applies-To field
property.description: <p>When Request Token Format is not Custom, enter the scope for this security token. For example, enter the services to which this token applies. For example:</p><ul><li>http://tfim.ibm.com:9080/EchoApplication/services/EchoServiceUsername</li><li>http://9.33.97.251:9080/EchoApplication/services/EchoServiceUsername</li></ul><p>Within the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager service, this information specifies the destination of the request. The TFIM trust service uses this information to determine which partner is being accessed.</p><p>To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your TFIM administrator. Within the WSDL document, this destination equates to the AppliesTo field.</p>

property.name: mIssuer
property.summary: Issuer
property.description: <p>When Request Token Format is not Custom, enter the identity that issued the request. In the WS-Security Management (WSSM) component, the issuer is either the WSSM token generator or the WSSM token consumer. For example:</p><ul><li>urn:itfim:wssm:tokenconsumer</li></ul><p>To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your Tivoli Federated Identity Manager administrator. Within the WSDL document, this destination equates to the <tt>Issuer</tt> field.</p>

property.name: mPortType
property.summary: Port Type
property.description: <p>When Compatibility Mode is version 6.1 or version 6.2 and when Request Token Format is not Custom, enter the Web services port type to use. A port type is a group of Web services operations. For example:</p><p><tt>EchoService</tt></p><p>To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your Tivoli Federated Identity Manager administrator. Within the WSDL document, this destination equates to the PortType field.</p>

property.name: mOperation
property.summary: Operation
property.description: <p>When Compatibility Mode is version 6.1 or version 6.2 and when Request Token Format is not Custom, enter the name of the Web services operation as defined in the WSDL document. For example:</p><p><tt>echo</tt></p><p>To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your Tivoli Federated Identity Manager administrator.</p>

property.name: mSSLProxy
property.summary: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.
property.description: Select the TLS proxy profile to manage TLS communications with the peer. The TLS Proxy Profile identifies the keys and certificates that are used in the handshake.

property.name: mSchemaValidate
property.summary: Schema Validate Response
property.description: Specify whether to schema-validate responses from the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager server. When enabled, responses are schema-validated using the WS-Trust version that is defined by the compatibility mode.

property.name: mLTPAValueTypeMode
property.summary: LTPA Binary Security Token Value Type
property.display: LTPA Binary Security Token Value Type
property.description: The namespace mode to use when populating the ValueType field of an LTPA BinarySecurityToken.

property.name: mSTSUsername
property.summary: Enforcement point username
property.description: Basic authentication user name when connecting to the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager OAuth secure token service.

property.name: mSTSPassword
property.summary: Enforcement point password
property.description: Basic authentication password when connecting to the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager OAuth secure token service.

property.name: mSTSPasswordAlias
property.summary: Enforcement point password alias
property.description: Password alias for the Basic authentication password when connecting to the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager OAuth secure token service.

property.description: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

property.description: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

object.description: Telnet services on the appliance are Telnet handlers. They are available for compatibility with earlier versions. A Telnet handler supports client-initiated access to the CLI. Telnet is an unsecure protocol and should be used with extreme caution. Telnet should be enabled only on the trusted management port or on a secure network segment. To ensure an encrypted connection and verify the cryptographic authenticity of the server, SSH is a more secure choice.

value.description: An emergency-level message. The system is unusable.

object.name: Throttler

property.name: mAdminState
property.label: Enable administrative state
property.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
property.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: ThrottleAt
property.summary: Memory throttle inbound traffic threshold
property.description: Enter a value of 0 - 100 to establish the threshold of minimal available memory (in percent) at which traffic is throttled. When the threshold is reached, the system waits for the timeout period before rebooting, to allow memory usage to recover.

property.name: TerminateAt
property.summary: Memory terminate operation threshold
property.description: Enter a value of 0 - 100 to establish the threshold of minimal available memory (in percent) at which the system reboots.

property.name: TempFSThrottleAt
property.summary: Temporary file space throttle inbound traffic threshold
property.description: Enter a value of 0 - 100 to establish the threshold of minimal available temporary file space (in percent) at which traffic is throttled. When this threshold is reached, the system waits for the timeout period before rebooting, to allow temporary file space to recover.

property.name: TempFSTerminateAt
property.summary: Temporary files space terminate operation threshold
property.description: Enter a value 0 - 100 to establish the threshold of minimal available temporary file space (in percent) at which the system reboots.

property.name: QnameWarnAt
property.summary: XML Names and JSON Keys warn threshold
property.display: XML Names and JSON Keys Warn At
property.description: Enter a value in the range 5 - 65 to establish the threshold of minimal available XML Names and JSON Keys (in percent) for any of the pools. As this threshold is approached, the system attempts to free unused XML Names and JSON Keys resources, so that this threshold is never reached. If this threshold is reached, then the system logs an alert. Note that the system reboots with less than 5% free XML Names or JSON Keys available, for any of the pools. To see the percentage currently available, use the XML Names and JSON Keys status provider.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Timeout period
property.description: Enter a value to set the number of seconds the system waits to take action when a throttling threshold is reached.

property.name: Statistics
property.summary: Periodic status Log
property.description: This setting controls the generation of throttle log messages. Select on or off.

property.name: LogLevel
property.summary: Status log level
property.description: Configure the level of the periodic status log.

property.name: EnvironmentalLog
property.summary: Monitor Environmental Sensors
property.description: This setting monitors system fan speeds and power supply status and generates log messages when a failure event occurs. Select on or off.

property.name: BacklogSize
property.summary: Backlog Size
property.description: Enter a value of 0 - 500 to specify the size of the backlog queue where incoming requests are routed if a throttling threshold is reached. If the size is set to 0, no requests are routed to the backlog queue.

property.name: BacklogTimeout
property.summary: Backlog Timeout
property.description: Enter a value to specify the number of seconds that a request remains in the backlog queue before it is rejected if a throttling threshold is reached.

object.description: This setting throttles, or disallows, traffic when the total memory available to the system reaches the thresholds established here.

property.name: mAdminState

property.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>

property.name: LocalTimeZone
property.summary: Set the local time zone.
property.description: The time zone to use in management interfaces. The default value is EST-5EDT.

property.name: CustomTZName
property.summary: Enter the symbolic name for the custom time zone.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the symbolic name for the custom time zone. The name must be three or more alphabetic characters. If you use any other characters, the time zone becomes UTC.
property.description: The symbolic name for the custom time zone. This name is appended to local times. The name must be three or more alphabetic characters. If you use any other characters, the time zone becomes UTC.

property.name: UTCDirection
property.summary: Set the direction relative to UTC for the custom time zone.
property.hoverhelp: Set the direction relative to UTC for the custom time zone. Asia is east. North America is west.
property.description: The direction relative to UTC for the custom time zone. Asia is east. North America is west. The default value is East.

property.name: OffsetHours
property.summary: Enter the number of hours the custom time zone is from UTC.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the number of hours the custom time zone is from UTC. If 2 hours and 30 minutes from UTC, enter 2.
property.description: The number of hours the custom time zone is from UTC. If 2 hours and 30 minutes from UTC, enter 2.

property.name: OffsetMinutes
property.summary: Enter the number of minutes the custom time zone is from UTC.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the number of minutes the time zone is from UTC. If 2 hours and 30 minutes from UTC, enter 30.
property.description: The number of minutes the time zone is from UTC. If 2 hours and 30 minutes from UTC, enter 30.

property.name: DaylightOffsetHours
property.summary: Enter the offset hours from DST.
property.description: The offset in hours when the custom time zone observes DST. Generally, the offset is 1 hour. The default value is 1.

property.name: TZNameDST
property.summary: Enter the symbolic name for the custom time zone during DST.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the symbolic name for the custom time zone during DST. The name must be three or more alphabetic characters. If you use any other characters, the time zone becomes UTC.
property.description: The symbolic name for the custom time zone during DST. This name is appended to local times. The name must be three or more alphabetic characters. If you use any other characters, the time zone becomes UTC.

property.name: DaylightStartMonth
property.summary: Set the month when DST starts for the custom time zone.
property.description: The month when DST starts for the custom time zone. The default value is March.

property.name: DaylightStartWeek
property.summary: Enter the instance of the day in the month when DST starts for the custom time zone.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the instance of the day in the month when DST starts for the custom time zone. If DST starts on the second Sunday in the month, enter 2.
property.description: The instance of the day in the month when DST starts for the custom time zone. If DST starts on the second Sunday in the month, enter 2.

property.name: DaylightStartDay
property.summary: Set the day of the week when DST starts for the custom time zone.
property.description: The day of the week when DST starts for the custom time zone. The default value is Sunday.

property.name: DaylightStartTimeHours
property.summary: Enter the hour when DST starts.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the hour when DST starts for the custom time zone. If the start boundary is 2:30 AM, enter 2.
property.description: The hour when DST starts for the custom time zone. If the start boundary is 2:30 AM, enter 2.

property.name: DaylightStartTimeMinutes

The current local time when last applied. This time is obtained from the timezone settings established on the Time Settings object and with the date and time settings set on the System Control page.
property.name: Time
property.summary: Current local time when last applied.

object.description: <p>The time zone for the appliance. The time zone affects the time that the appliance displays. All time stamps in the CLI and GUI use this time zone.</p><p><b>Note: </b>The appliance clock runs on Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</p><p>When daylight saving time (DST), or summer time, applies to a time zone, the appliance adjusts the time when a DST boundary is crossed.</p>

value.description: Writes log entries to the screen when using Telnet, SSH, or command-line access through the serial port.
value.name: console

value.description: Writes log entries to system memory.
value.name: cache

value.description: Forwards log entries using UDP to a remote syslog daemon. The local address, remote address, remote port, syslog facility can be set. The processing rate can be limited.
value.name: syslog
value.summary: Forwards to a remote syslog daemon (UDP)

value.description: Forwards log entries using TCP to a remote syslog daemon. The local address, remote address, remote port, syslog facility can be set. a TLS connection to the syslog host can be created. The processing rate can be limited.
value.name: syslog-tcp
value.summary: Forwards to a remote syslog daemon (TCP)

value.description: Forwards log entries as email to the configured remote SMTP servers and email addresses. Before sending, the contents of the log can be encrypted or signed. The processing rate can be limited.
value.name: smtp

value.description: Writes log entries to a file in the DataPower file system. The file can be archived using the rotate or upload method. The file can be sent as email. The entire file can be encrypted and signed.
value.name: file
value.summary: Writes to a file in the DataPower file system

value.description: Forwards log entries as SOAP messages. The log format must be XML or IBM Common Base Event (CBE). The URL can be set. The processing rate can be limited. Select a remote SOAP target. Routing logging messages to a local SOAP service can cause a large amount of logging feedback and increased resource consumption.
value.name: soap

value.description: Forwards log entries as SNMP traps to configured recipients. The processing rate can be limited.
value.name: snmp

value.description: Writes log entries to a file on a remote NFS server. The file can be archived using the rotate method. The processing rate can be limited. Note that network-file type messages are not logged to NFS log targets.
value.name: nfs
value.summary: Writes to a file on an NFS server

value.description: A service or transaction assigned this priority setting will receive above normal scheduling priority and resource allocation.

value.description: A service or transaction assigned this priority setting will receive normal scheduling priority and resource allocation.

value.description: Rotate the log file when the maximum size is reached. The DataPower Gateway creates a copy of the file and starts a new file. The DataPower Gateway retains the archived copies up to the specified number of rotations. After reaching the maximum number of rotations and the log file reaches its maximum size, the DataPower Gateway deletes the oldest file and copies the current file.
value.name: rotate

value.description: Upload the log file when the maximum size is reached. The DataPower Gateway uploads the file using the specified upload method.

property.description: <p>Optionally enter the name of an existing object of the selected type.</p><ul><li>To collect log messages for all instances of an object class, do not specify an object name.</li><li>To collect log messages for a specific instance of an object class, specify its object name.</li></ul>

<p>Indicate whether to include log messages for objects that the specified object instance references.</p><ul><li>When enabled, includes referenced objects.</li><li>When disabled, excludes referenced objects.</li></ul><p>Included objects are a static snapshot when you apply the object filter. If referenced objects are added after you apply the object filter, messages for these referenced objects are not logged. For example, if you specify a particular service that has handlers and a handler is added after you apply the object filter, messages are not logged for the added handler.</p>
